"The Asante wars had their origin in the seventeenth century in the course of attempts by Oti Akenten and Obiri Yeboah to establish the power of their segment of the Oyoko clan, based in Kokofu in Amansee, in the area now covered by Kumasi City. Obiri Yeboah died in war with the Dorma people, then located within four miles of Kumasi, and was succeeded by Osei Tutu (died 1717). Osei Tutu defeated the Dorma (Reindorf, 1895: 50; Fuller, 1968: 2) and led the Asante to conquer Denkyira (Bosman, 1705), their south-western neighbour and erstwhile overlords, in 1699-1708 [...] Between Osei Tutu and Osei Bonsu (1800-1824) the Asante conquered or otherwise brought into subjection to the Asantehene (King of Asante), nearly all the peoples now inhabiting all the regions of modern Ghana and also east-central and south-western Ivory Coast (Rattray, 1923: 287-293; Priestley and Wilks, 1960; Fynn, 1971: 105, 155; Meredith, 1812; Wilks, 1975; 43-79)."[239]

♠ Wars involving groups with different languages ♣ present ♥ Akan versus European languages.

♠ Wars involving groups with different language families ♣ present ♥ Niger-Congo versus Indo-European.

♠ Wars between groups from different archaeological cultures ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars between different religious sects ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Portuguese (Catholic) versus Dutch (Protestant) allied with Akan (tribal religion). Akan side of the involvement does not qualify this to be coded present.

♠ Wars between different world religions ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars of world religion against tribal religion ♣ present ♥ e.g. Portuguese (Catholic) versus Dutch (Protestant) allied with Akan (tribal religion). Akan side of the involvement does not qualify this to be coded present.

♠ Wars on Urbanism-Literacy frontier ♣ present ♥

♠ Wars on steppe frontier ♣ absent ♥

♠ Wars on agricultural frontier ♣ absent ♥

Intensity of warfare[edit]

♠ Annexation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Both these examples are next period.

"Mande-speaking immigrants conquered the Akyerekyere kingdom and later the Asantemanso kingdom to become the dominant power in the region, the Denkyira. In 1701, the Asantemanso under the leadership of Osei Tutu (d. 1717) rebelled and defeated the Denkyira."[240]

"Between Osei Tutu and Osei Bonsu (1800-1824) the Asante conquered or otherwise brought into subjection to the Asantehene (King of Asante), nearly all the peoples now inhabiting all the regions of modern Ghana and also east-central and south-western Ivory Coast".[241]

♠ Looting ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Slave raids may well have included sack, looting, and rape, but additional material is needed to make the case for this. We have assumed all of these present for the time being. This is open to re-evaluation.

♠ Sack ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Slave raids may well have included sack, looting, and rape, but additional material is needed to make the case for this. We have assumed all of these present for the time being. This is open to re-evaluation.

♠ Rape ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Slave raids may well have included sack, looting, and rape, but additional material is needed to make the case for this. We have assumed all of these present for the time being. This is open to re-evaluation.

♠ Deportation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Annexation and enslavement were more common.

♠ Expulsion ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature. Annexation and enslavement were more common.

♠ Enslavement ♣ present ♥ "It was therefore to the great advantage of these European traders to foster dissension and disunion among the Africans, to instigate them to constant hostilities, and to encourage raiding expeditions, so as to keep up the supply of war captives and other prisoners for sale." [242]

♠ Imprisonment ♣ present ♥ Sarbah mentions hostage-taking: "About the 5th April, 1666, the Dutch General of Kromantin Fort, while visiting Anumabu, with his retinue, to drink palm-wine and be merry, was arrested by the prince of that town, in whose district was Kromantin. The reason for this act was, that the Fanti ruler had promised the English at Cape Coast Castle to put them in possession of Dutch Kromantin Fort. With this promise he gave his son as hostage, but as the English on his application refused to release the hostage, the Dutch Governor was seized, so that he and his men might be exchanged for this prince's son. About the same time, the people of Axim killed the Dutch Comptroller-General, and refused to deal with the Dutch in preference to the English."[243]

♠ Destruction ♣ present ♥ Sarbah mentions destroyed towns: "Then certain of our men with the Hind's boat went into the bay which lieth to the eastward of the town, and within that bay they found a goodly fresh river, and afterwards they came and waved to us to come in, because they perceived the negroes to come down to that place, which he did: and immediately the negroes came to us, and made us signs that they had gold, but none of them would come aboard our boats, neither could we perceive any boats that they had to come withal, so that we judged the Portugals had spoilt their boats, because we saw half of their towns destroyed."[244]

♠ Torture ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mutilation ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ present ♥

"About the 5th April, 1666, the Dutch General of Kromantin Fort, while visiting Anumabu, with his retinue, to drink palm-wine and be merry, was arrested by the prince of that town, in whose district was Kromantin. The reason for this act was, that the Fanti ruler had promised the English at Cape Coast Castle to put them in possession of Dutch Kromantin Fort. With this promise he gave his son as hostage, but as the English on his application refused to release the hostage, the Dutch Governor was seized, so that he and his men might be exchanged for this prince's son. About the same time, the people of Axim killed the Dutch Comptroller-General, and refused to deal with the Dutch in preference to the English."[245]

♠ General massacre ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Extermination ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.


Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mass burials ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ suspected unknown ♥ No data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

Asante - Asante-Dutch alliance against the Portuguese (1637-1642 CE)

Asante-Dutch (1666 CE)

Asante-Danish (Unknown)

Asante - Slave Raids (Unknown)

Asante - Denkyira Invasion (c1675 CE?)

Asante-Denkyira (1701 CE)

Asante-Dorma (1700 CE)

Ritual variables[edit]

A collective ritual is a ritual in which two or more people participate. With the official cult we refer to the set of collective ritual practices that are most closely associated with legitimation of the power structure (including elites, if any).

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Note: The Yam and Apo festivals as well as the Monocot ceremony were imported from the Ashanti-period sheet (GhAshnL). It remains to be confirmed whether these rituals indeed predated the Ashanti expansion. We have provisionally presumed this to be the case.

The following descriptions were extracted from the eHRAF Culture Summary for the Akan: 'Indigenous Akan religion is based upon the worship of a High God, various spirits or deities, and ancestors. The High God-known as Onyame, Onyankopon, and by other names-is the Creator, now otiose; Asase Yaa, the goddess of the earth, accompanies him. The ancestors live in the land of the dead and may demand offerings, in the past including those of slaves.' [246] 'The Akan have largely been Christian since the nineteenth century, except for most kings, who have had to retain their indigenous religious status and practices. European Christian missions were highly successful, bringing not only Christianity but also education, and most Akan have been literate for a long time. Islam has a long history among the Akan, having been introduced by early traders from the north. Royalty made use of Muslim scribes for court duties. The Akan have a long history of "prophets" of many kinds-Christian, Muslim, and "heathen"-and of separatist Christian movements. All these various forms of religious belief and activity exist side by side, and most people have recourse to all of them, according to their particular needs and wishes.' [247] 'Spirits or deities are many, and the living can communicate with them through prayer, sacrifice, and possession. Each has its own OSOFO, or priest; an OKOMFO is a living spirit medium who interprets the words of a spirit who is consulted to remove sickness and human disasters.' [248] 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."' [249] 'Sickness is attributed to organic causes, preordained destiny, angry ancestors, witchcraft, and anti-social behavior. Herbalists have reliable cures for organic illnesses. Herbalists with knowledge of witchcraft and priests deal with psychosomatic illnesses. Warren (1973, no. 29) makes an interesting point that social stress can weaken a person's natural resistance to any one of a number of internal malarial and intestinal parasites, resulting in illness. The priest seeks to identify and remedy the social disturbance that causes the stress.' [250] 'At death one's blood (MOGYA) turns into a ghost (SAMAN) and enters the spirit world (SAMANDO) where it awaits reincarnation. One's life or spiritual force (OKRA) returns to God (NYANKOPON). One's ntoro remains behind to care for and protect one's patrikin. The funeral consists of five stages: i) washing the corpse, ii) pre-burial mourning, iii) internment, iv) post-burial mourning, and v) periodic mourning. At death the family is notified and the corpse is washed three times. This is followed by three (formerly seven) days of mourning, which includes fasting and the singing of funeral dirges. The body is interred and a public mourning for friends and relatives ensues, involving dancing and drumming. Observances are made on the 8th, 15th, 40th and 80th day and first anniversary after death.' [251]

We should code for 'indigenous' rather than Muslim ritual as the former appears to have been more wide-spread in pre-colonial times, although the boundaries between the two were more fluid than this categorization allows for.

Rattray provides a description of some stool rituals from the colonial period: As soon as my eyes grew accustomed to the light, I saw at the end of the room, opposite to the door, a long low platform, raised about three feet off the ground, made of upright poles with cross sticks laid upon them. Upon this table or rack were set the ancestral stools, as yet invisible, for all were covered with one large coarsely woven native cloth called nsa. The head stool-carrier came forward and removed the covering. There were thirteen blackened stools, many crumbling to pieces with age. Each stool lay upon its side, the seat facing towards us. They were caked with clotted blood, [It may be as well to place upon record the fact that the blood with which these ancestral stools are clotted was never that of a human sacrifice as is so often erroneously supposed. An Ashanti whom I once questioned on this point asked me how I could ask such a foolish question when I knew well that the flesh of the sacrifice was afterwards partaken of. There is one apparent but not real exception, the stool ( not an ancestral stool) brought from Gyaman by Yim Aware which was really a suman or fetish. Upon this formerly a mulatto's blood was sprinkled. Nowadays a brown sheep is sacrificed upon it and the flesh is not eaten by those taking part in the ceremony.] and pieces of fat could be seen round the centre supports of many of them. (For photographs of smoked stools, see Figs. 34 and 35, which were those at another Adae). [252] 'The thirteen stools were in three rows. Two brass bells were the only other contents of the room.' [253] 'On Monday, a most impressive rite took place. About 6 p.m. all the local gods, the shrines of which were permanently housed in the Ta Kese or other local temples, were formed up outside the Ta Kese house. Leading the procession were the shrines of fourteen lesser gods, carried upon the heads of young boys, and immediately behind these was Ta Kese and Ta Kwesi, each under its own enormous umbrella. On top of the shrines of these last-named deities were red fez caps-the badge of the Mohammedan in these parts. [I was told by some that this was to signify a victory over some Mohammedan chief in one of the wars of the past, and by another that it signified that the Allah of the Mohammedan was just the same as the 'Nyame of the Ashanti.] Priests covered in white powdered clay and in white skirts were in attendance. One man carried a very large branch of the tree the Ashanti call summe (Costus sp.). [Much used in religious ceremonies, the smell of the tree is sometimes said to drive away ghosts.] The blackened stools of former priests were also carried in the procession' [254] 'Many in the procession carried cow-tail switches and guns. A message was sent to the chief, saying: ‘The year has come round, to-day the festival ends and we wish to go to the river.’' [255] 'The chief replied: ‘May no misfortune happen this new year that is now approaching, and may another year once again come round.’' [256] 'Ntumpane drums are carried behind a chief [Except a drum called ‘Prempeh’ which is carried in front; it is not a talking drum.]; when he sits down to receive his courtiers, their position is behind him. On every occasion upon which a drummer is about to drum for the first time on a particular day, the following little ceremony takes place. Some wine or other spirit is brought in a cup, [Page 264] and the drummer, bending over his drums, pours a few drops upon the edges and addresses them as follows: ‘ Tweneboa Kodia, Kodia Tweneduru, gye nsa nom. Obofunu, gye nsa nom. Ofema dunsene, Gyaanadu Asare nsoa, gye nsa nom. Ofema dunsene, Gyaanadu Asare ntwinta, gye nsa nom. Esono obu akuma, gye nsa nom. Kokokyinaka Asamoa, gye nsa nom. Obayifo, gye nsa nom. Asase, gye nsa nom. Onyankopon Tweaduampon Bonyame, gye nsa nom.’ ‘Cedar tree Kodia, Kodia Cedar tree, accept (this) wine and drink. Obofunu rope, accept (this) wine and drink. Stump of the Ofema tree, Gyaanadu Asare, the Pegs, accept (this) wine and drink. Drum-sticks made of the Ofema tree (whose title is) Gyaanadu Asare, accept (this) wine and drink. Elephant who breaks the axe, accept (this) wine and drink. Kokokyinaka bird (whose title is Asamoa), accept (this) wine and drink. Witch, accept (this) wine and drink. Earth deity, accept (this) wine and drink. Supreme Being Nyankopon Tweaduampon Creator, accept (this) wine and drink.’ [257] 'The following day, the usual ceremonial return calls were paid. An interesting rite was next described which had not been recorded in connexion with other enstoolments so far noted, although it may very possibly have taken place. It was as follows: On that day the Barimfo (Mausoleum attendants) took white calico and mashed plantains ( eto) and dressed the gyadua (trees) in the town. A sheep was also sacrificed beneath the oldest gyadua (tree) and the eto placed on its roots while the following words were spoken: Gye eto ne ogwan yi di, na boa Ohene foforo yi ma no nkye, nya sika; mma n'ani mfura; mma n'aso nsi; mma no kote nwu; ma mmawofo nwo mma; ma kuro yi die edan nsi da, edan nsi ho; mma Ohene mfom; mma no manfo mpa n'aba. ‘Receive this eto and sheep and partake, and help this new Chief and let him have long life; let him get gold-dust; do not allow his penis to die; allow the bearers of children to bear children; let houses stand where no house stands; do not let the Chief commit mistakes; do not permit his people to fall from him like branches.’' [258]

Given the increased regional integration brought about by the Ashanti expansion, some of Rattray's material may not apply to the pre-colonial period. More information on changes in ritual practice from the pre-Ashanti to the Ashanti periods is needed.

Wilks gives an account of regal ceremonies and comments on some Ashanti innovations on the 'native' Akan system: 'In Kumase Apafram Memeneda (“Mimida”) and Apafram Kwasiada - Apafram Saturday and Sunday - fall within the cycle of the great annual festival of the Akan known as Odwira because it is a rite of purification ( dwira), but known to Europeans in the nineteenth century as “the Yam Custom” because it also has to do with the harvest. The concern with the well-being of the nation is expressed in an oration made by the incumbent Asantehene.' [259] 'The Apafram is embedded within the older Odwira festival. It has to do with the bonds between the Asantehene and those from whom he expects allegiance. On Apafram Memeneda the amanhene of the Asanteman entered Kumase with much pomp and circumstance. They were received at Apremoso, the Place of the Cannons, so named from the guns captured in the Denkyira war (and now, such are the turns of fortune, the site of the central police station). One by one the dignitaries renewed allegiance to the Asantehene, swearing on swords of state appropriate to their rank. The proceedings often lasted well into the night. The next day, Apafram Sunday, the skulls of slain enemies were brought to the palace from Bantama (the town of the Konti), and the Apafram from Asafo (that of the Akwamu). The rites that followed were not open to the public. Rattray obtained a description of them from a “white haired Ashanti friend.” The Asantehene “discarded his gorgeous robes and dressed himself in Kyenkyen (bark cloth), the garb of the poorest slave in the realm.” He then smeared the odwira suman, that is, the Apafram, with a red dye and gave it new yams and wine Osei Tutu Dwira, The Odwira of Osei Tutu, gye nsa nom. receive wine and drink it. Ohene biara a ompo se Any King who does not like osom me no, to serve me, Ma me nya no menku no, Let me get the chance of killing him Mfa ne ti mmeto to mu. And put his head into you. The ceremony thus inverts that of the previous day; on Apafram Saturday the amanhene publicly acknowledge that they serve the Asantehene; on Apafram Sunday the Asantehene privately communed with the suman on the fate of those who compromised their allegiance.' [260] 'The institution of the Apafram, and its incorporation into the Odwira, appears then to be the event which signalled the creation of the Asanteman, underwriting (as it were) the unity of Osei Tutu, in his new role as Asantehene, and the rulers of the “five” states that had joined the coalition against Denkyira. The matter was addressed in a document prepared [Page 117] “THE GREAT ANNUAL FESTIVAL OF THE AKAN KNOWN AS ODWIRA.” ASANTEHENE OSEI TUTU KWAME PRESIDING OVER THE ODWIRA IN KUMASE, 1817. THE FLAGS OF ASANTE'S TRADING PARTNERS, BRITAIN, THE NETHERLANDS AND DENMARK, ARE DISPLAYED. T. E. Bowdich, Mission from Cape Coast Castle to Ashantee (London, 1819). [Page 118] by the Edwesohene and others in 1933, having to do with the imminent restoration of the Asante “Confederacy”: 'This occasional meeting at Kumasi for the observance of the Odwira custom was the beginning of what was later to be subordination to the Kumasi Stool, and since that time Kumasi has ever continued to be the central meeting place of the Ashanti Chiefs. From the foregoing it would be seen that the meeting at Kumasi was decreed by Komfuo Anotchi [Okomfo Anokye] after the fall of Denkyira. This occasional meeting was turned to mean subjection.' “The Ashantis”-thus HAK-“became the most powerful of all the other countries around it.” True, but it was still to be a long haul.' [261]

The above passages do not constitute complete descriptions of the respective rituals, but indicate on which pages or in which chapters relevant material can be found.

'The object, however, of this work is not to deal with religious theories, deities, or matters of belief. In the Fanti districts, with their numerous free and independent communities, the priests who officiated at the shrine of Nanaam (that is ancestors), the national deities, situate at Mankesim, exercised large powers and wielded great [Page 52] influence, so much so that the opinion has been expressed that the high priest, a Braffo, was the sovereign ruler of the Fanti people. The physician was so often a priest that it is not surprising to discover him possessed of much influence; but this much may be said, the priests did not rule the people. The general name for God is Nyankupon (Nyankrupon according to the Akanfu), meaning the Only One, than who none is greater, or, as others say, the Great Friend. Nyankupon is invisible. He lives above the heavens, and the winds are His messengers. The common saying is, “Speak to the winds, and God will hear thee.” This word has different pronunciations, and the difficulty of finding its root may be through this cause. Rain is called Nyankum; rainbow is nyankunton. Nyan is to awaken, and it has been suggested that probably Onyan (the awakener) was an old name for the sky. One is rather inclined to form the opinion that Nyankupon is not derived from ye, meaning to do, act, create, as some say. This subject is certainly interesting, and requires further study and much thinking over.' [262] 'From the information at our disposal, we now know that the Ashanti makes a distinction between the following: the okomfo(priest); the sumankwafo or dunseni (the medicine-man); and the Bonsam komfo (witch-doctor). The word okomfo, without any further qualification refers to a priest of one of the orthodox abosom (gods). We see, however, that a witch-doctor is allowed [Page 40] the same name as a kind of honorary title or degree, being known as a Bayi 'komfo (a priest of witchcraft). Again, the ordinary medical practitioners are never termed akomfo; they are sumankwafo, dealers in suman; or dunsefo, workers in roots; or odu'yefo, workers in medicines.' [263] 'The Priest generally invests his practice with a certain amount of secrecy. He pretends to hold communion, not in a spiritual sense, but in a matter-of-fact way, with the spirits of the dead, and he will often bring you back a message from a dead friend, if desired. When a priest is called in from a distance to attend a case, he will generally tell the friends of the patient much about the family history, and indicate that a deceased relative is troubling the patient for some act of disobedience. The deceased relative must accordingly be propitiated. How does he come to know the history of the family to which he is a stranger? There is a Guild of Priests in the country to which all Priests belong, whose members are absolutely faithful to one ànother. Upon the [Page 107] arrival of the Priest in the town where his attendance is required, he immediately goes to meet his brother Priest, or some student of the Priest, if he is out of town, who gives him all the information he requires, and which he subsequently puts to such effective use. The people understand the deception, but they never expose it; for the Priest's office is a sacred one, and they philosophically look to the spiritual side of things and not to the letter.' [264]

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Yam Festival ♥ Akan communities celebrated the annual yam harvest with a public festival. 'An annual custom is always held in connection with the first fruits of each staple crop such as yam. The general name for a festival is Afahyε (afa, “festival”; hyε, “fix a day”). The chief's and head priest's house and things are refurbished [Page 35] by singing old women, the blackened stools are taken to the stream and sprinkled with water; pieces of sacrificed and new food crops are put on each stool. The spirits are invoked to start the new year and make it a good one, the new year beginning at different times in different localities.' [265]//'The Akan annual yam festival, a purificatory ceremony lasting one-two weeks usually in September or October, is called Odwira, meaning “to purify/cleanse”. (It is sometimes also called apafram). It is similar to the Apo in that all disputes are settled, bringing harmony back to the town. The central part of the festival is the re-purification of the stools and the abosom shrines. It is a festival involving remembrance of the dead, harvest, and thanksgiving.' [266]//The Yam Festival is also known as Odwira Festival in the literature: 'The Odwira Festival is the most important yearly celebration among the Ashanti people. It is held in autumn, the time when new yams are ready. They cannot be eaten until the second day of the festival, when they are paraded through the streets. The whole festival lasts for five days is celebrated slightly differently in each community. Throughout the festival, music and drumming abound. On the first day the path leading towards the chief's burial is cleaned. On the second day priests make offerings at the burial chambers and a great yam parade takes place. On the third day people mourn and fast. On the fourth a splendid feast for everyone in the community is held at the local chief's house. That night, everyone stay indoors, to avoid catching sight of the chief's thrones, symbols of the dead men's spirits, which are carried to the river to be ceremonially washed. On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best, parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief. Some are carried shoulder high on litters and shaded with brilliantly coloured umbrellas. Then people play music and dance late into the night.'[267]//Warren provides a description of the relevant narratives and proceedings among the Techiman-Bono:'The other major annual Bono Festival is the Yam Festival ( henerεk dibayerefoforo: literally, the chief is going to eat new yams). The myth explaining the origin of the festival states that when the Techiman-Bono people came from the cavern at Amowi, Onyame pointed out forest yams (aha bayere). Seeing that bush pigs and elephants had eaten some of the yams, they cooked a few and saw that the yam was good food. They gave some to their chief, who also enjoyed it. After that, they began to celebrate on an annual basis the day on which they first found yams. After their chief died, they fed his soul (saman) yams on the same day. Later the Bono began to plant yams, and the yam became the most important staple in the Bono diet. Every farmer celebrates the festival to thank Onyame after the harvest. The living and the deceased are all invited to share in the abundance. Every Bono chief and priest celebrates a yam festival, but before the celebrations begin, a man from the village of Kenten whose title is Akokohwedeε (woodhen) first tastes the yam. When he sees that the yam is ripe, early in the morning on the traditional day called Fodwo he informs the god Taa Mεnsah that the yam is ready to be prepared for εto (mashed yams mixed with palmoil).' [268]//'The Taa Mεnsah deity celebrates his yam festival on Fodwo, a Monday. The new yam is hung from rafters in the shrine room for some weeks before the Akokohwedeε comes to taste it. After the yam is hung, children may begin to eat new yam and the elders can [Page 57] [Page 58] begin to eat aso bayere (one species of yam). In the evening on Fodwo, the god Taa Mεnsah is prepared to eat yam after being carried on the main street from one end of the town to the other end three times and consulted. After this, the god informs the manhene that he is about to eat yam and the manhene gives the god permission to eat the yam. The manhene sends a yam to the god and it is always this yam which is cooked as εto and placed on the shrine. The next day, Tuesday, the manhene sends a sheep and wine to the god.' [269]//'Two weeks after the Taa Mεnsah Yam Festival, the yam festivals for the Queenmother, the Adontenhene, and the Nifahene are celebrated on a Monofie, a Friday. Nwonakusie, a Thursday, is the yam festival day for the Twafohene, the Adaatihene, the Akyeamehene, the Konkontiwahene, and the Krontihene. Fofie, another Friday, is the yam festival day for the manhene, the Gyaasehene, the Ankbeahene, and the Barimhene. The manhene provides about six sheep and a cow for his own yam festival. These are sacrificed, the blood being spilled on the ancestral stools; the meat is cooked and distributed.' [270]//The ethnographic material availabe refers mostly to the Ashanti and colonial periods. We have assumed here that some variant of this festival was celebrated prior to Ashanti expansion as well. The below codes were imported from Atkinson's and Whitehouse's ritual database (see also GhAshnL for reference).
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[271].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[272].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database, this ritual occurs 'annually'[273]. Thomas Cressy: The ritual description makes it clear this is a community ritual where the community members participate in the festivities and feasts etc, so I have changed this code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 120 ♥ hours. 'The whole festival lasts for five days is celebrated slightly differently in each community.'[274] However, according to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual database, this ritual is coded as '1 to 6 hours/ long'[275].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 17,000 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[276]. The largest community consists of approx. 22,500 people, meaning that this ritual may include some 17,000 people.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ elites ♥ adult male priesthood. According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[277].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[278].
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ According to the Ritual Database, 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' are 'present'[279]. Thomas Cressy: The ritual description makes it clear this is a community ritual where the community members participate in the festivities and feasts etc, so I have changed this code from 'whole polity' to 'not applicable'.

The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 0, the lowest possible score [288]..

Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ inferred present ♥ 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief.'[301]
♠ oath taking ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[302]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included oath taking, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information. However, it is worth noting that 'Narrative or story recounted' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database'[303].
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[304]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support in war, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[305]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support in war, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Unclear. 'On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief'[306]. The act of "paying homage" to the senior local chief may well have included promises of support to each other's families, but the source does not say, and the Ritual Database does not capture this sort of information.

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Apo Festival ♥ The Apo Festival was celebrated annually and included carnivalesque elements: 'Many festivals exist among the Akan; their foundations and functions are found in the traditional religion. The Apo festival is celebrated yearly among the Brong; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given. The people explain that if one's sunsum is hurt, the body becomes ill; often ill health is caused by evil and the hatred another person may have for you. In like manner, if you have a hatred for someone, it affects your own sunsum, so this time is set aside to allow any man to tell any other man what has offended him. This frees the spirit, and both sunsum become relaxed. During this festival there is theoretical sexual license; this isn't really taken [Page 33] Scene at a Festival [Page 34] advantage of since traditional court action can be initiated after the eight day festival. Punishment is therefore deferred until the rites are over. Should an aggrieved party take action he forfeits the right to investigation, to satisfaction, and he is also heavily fined. During this period all the priests and priestesses of the area are present with their shrines; they touch each shrine with every other one to re-establish communications which might have been lost. The major gods are taken to the river and cleansed of all evil. On the eighth day everyone makes a concerted effort to drive all evil from the area. Around twenty-five distinct Apo songs are sung, and there is a specific Apo dance for the festival.' [317]//Purification is a major element in the rituals performed: 'The festival period is, in fact, a period of coming together in which the people from all over the Techiman traditional area, including well-wishers and invitees from other states, meet in the capital to display the traditional Bono culture through singing, dancing, and drumming. The manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene, purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State (man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State. Finally, the Apo is a period during which the shrines of various gods and goddesses are purified. The shrine of the main deity in Techiman Township, Taa Kεse (Taa Mεnsah), is, at this time, purified at the River Agyentoamu during the last hour of the celebration; this serves as a sign of the completion of the Apo Festival.' [318]//The festival also served as a check on authority and as a forum for the resolution of mutual resentment: 'The functions of the Apo festival seem to be four: (1) psychological release, (2) a forum for public opinion, (3) a means to periodically check those in authority, (4) a method of enforcing sanctions of behaviour.' [319] According to Warren, the restoration of amicable relations is one of the major purposes of the festival: 'This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority-especially the manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [320]
The ethnographic material availabe refers mostly to the Ashanti and colonial periods. We have assumed here that some variant of this festival was celebrated prior to Ashanti expansion as well. The below codes were imported from Atkinson's and Whitehouse's ritual database (see also GhAshnL for reference).
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ not applicable ♥ Source does not mention ritual specialists [321].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [322]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [323] Thomas Cressy: Quote from the ritual database (see inclusive codes) makes it clear this is a community ritual where all or almost all of the community members participate in the ritual, it seems very likely people were taking no part and passively watching. so I have changed this code from 'yearly' to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 192 ♥ hours. 'Apo festival is celebrated yearly; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given.' [324]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 2,000,000 ♥ in absolute numbers. Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ not applicable ♥ Source does not mention ritual specialists [325].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals.
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present' for ritual number 69, meaning that size of the participating group is at least the size of the community. If the population is approx. 3,000,000, I'm guessing that this this ritual may involve some 2,000,000 individuals. ♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [326].

♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' and 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [328].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [329].
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [330].
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [331].

In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [345]

In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [351]

♠ other ♣ ♥

Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Monocot Ceremony ♥ The Monocot Ceremony was celebrated monthly and involved libations to ancestral stools: 'The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance. At the last Monokuo for the year, the manhene pours a libation on the god. On all other occasions during the year they only go to greet the god and then return to their houses.' [361][362]//'Although the Yam and Apo festivals are annual, the Bono celebrate the Monokuo ceremony every forty-two days, on the Wednesday called Monokuo. During the Monokuo, early in the morning, the manhene pours a libation on his ancestral stools. After that, the elders come to join him and they all go to the palace for the Taa Mεnsah shrine to say good morning to him. At the last Monokuo for the year, the manhene pours a libation on the god. Otherwise, they only go to greet the god and then return to their houses. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.' [363]//Warren also reports other ceremonies that were celebrated on a monthly basis, although the specific example used seems to be distinct from Monocot: 'The most important festival dealing with “the propitiation, solicitation, or worship of ancestral spirits is the Adae” (Rattray, 1923:92). Adae means “place for rest” or “lying down”; no work is done on these days when the living recall the deeds of the deceased and solicit them for mercy and favours. The blood of sacrificed sheep is smeared by hand on the ancestral stools (human blood is never spilled on shrines); a libation is poured on each stool. The offering, excluding the omentum, is removed in the evening by the stool-carriers. Everyone entering the stool room removes his shoes, and bares his shoulders as a sign of humbleness before the superior spirits. Many ceremonies such as this Adae follow a forty-two day cycle. The details vary from area to area; the Brong propitiate both the Samanfo and the bosom at the Adae while the Ashanti only propitiate the Samanfo. The day proceding any Adae is called dapaa, “good/lucky day”; this is a day of preparation and work, everything being scrubbed.' [364]//The ethnographic material available refers mostly to the Ashanti and colonial periods. We have assumed here that some variant of this festival was celebrated prior to Ashanti expansion as well. The below codes were imported from Atkinson's and Whitehouse's ritual database (see also GhAshnL for reference).
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[365][366]
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[367][368]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ monthly ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[369][370]
♠ Duration ♣ 3 ♥ hours. The Ritual Database has coded the ritual duration as 1-6 hours.
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ suspected unknown ♥ in absolute numbers
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ elites ♥ The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[371][372] 'Some members of community (<50% where that is more than 15 persons)' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[373][374]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ suspected unknown ♥
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[375][376]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[377][378]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[379]. 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[380].
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[381]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[382]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[383]. 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[384]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[385]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[386]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[387]
♠ other ♣ absent ♥ List the other(s) 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula', 'Foul or unpleasant sensations (heat, stinging), tastes or smells', 'Vomiting', 'Swallowing of undigestable objects (swords, stones)', 'Patient's body is sucked', and 'Other uncomfortable experiences' are all coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[388]
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[389]
♠ alcohol ♣ present ♥ 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[390] The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[391][392]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[393].
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[394]
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[395]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison) 'Marching/ procession/ Proambulation' is coded as absent in the Ritual Database[396]
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as present in the Ritual Database[397]
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ Drums. The Monocot ceremony occurs every forty-two days involving libations to ancestral stools. In the afternoon, each of the elders returns to Taa Mεnsah's palace with schnapps or pots of palmwine. The drinks are used to pour libations for each of the chiefs, after which they drink together, drums are beaten, and they dance.[398][399]
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ suspected unknown ♥ 'Speechmaking' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as absent in the Ritual Databaseref>Warren, Dennis M. The Akan of Ghana: an overview of the ethnographic literature, 33-35; Ritual Database</ref>[400]. However, this does not seem to be sufficient to code this variable as 'absent'[401].
♠ oath taking ♣ absent ♥ 'Speechmaking' and 'Recitation of texts' are coded as absent in the Ritual Databaseref>Warren, Dennis M. The Akan of Ghana: an overview of the ethnographic literature, 33-35; Ritual Database</ref>[402]
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ No orthodoxy checks are mentioned by the source. 'Distribution of ritual exegesis' is coded as 'Known by all competent participants (1)' [i.e., elders and chiefs] in the Ritual Database[403][404], but the fact that only elders/chiefs participated, this suggests that there were no significant orthodoxy checks.
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ inferred absent ♥ Monetary expenditure not mentioned by sources [405][406].
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ Schnapps or pots of palmwine.[407][408]
♠ health costs ♣ inferred absent ♥ (KB: Coded as inferred absent as description does not mention any health costs)
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded 'absent' in the Ritual Database[409][410]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database[411][412].
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database[413][414].
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database[415][416].
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ ♥ Healing ritual in ecstatic churches. This ritual is awaiting an expert check to decide whether it should be coded here or not Healing and possession rituals are also described in the colonial-era sources. But these seem to describe movements that emerged as a response to the colonial encounter, which is was some sources insinuate. We are thus unsure about making inferences in this case and have left the variables uncoded. We have nevertheless provided some descriptive paragraphs in case a 'predecessor' can be identified.//'A spirit may take possession of a man and he may appear to have gone mad, and this state may last sometimes even for a year. Then the priest of some powerful god may be consulted and he may discover, through his god, that it is some spirit which has come upon the man (or woman). The one upon whom the spirit has come is now bidden to prepare a brass pan, and collect water, leaves, and ‘medicine’ of specific kinds. The possessed one will dance, for sometimes two days, with short intervals for rest, to the accompaniment of drums and singing. Quite suddenly he will leap into the air and catch something in both his hands (or he may plunge into the river and emerge holding something he has brought up). He will in either case fold this thing to his breast, and water will be at once sprinkled upon it to cool it, when it will be thrust into the brass pan and quickly covered up. The following ingredients are now prepared: clay from one of the more sacred rivers, like the Tano, and the following medicinal plants and other objects: afema [Justicia flavia], Dama Bo [Abras precatorius]; the bark of the odom, a creeper called hamakyem, leaves and bark of a tree called domine, another creeper called hamakyerehene, any root that crosses a path, a projecting stump in a path over which passers-by would be likely to trip, also roots and stumps from under water, the leaves of a tree called aya-those are chosen which are seen to be quivering on the tree even though no wind is shaking them-the leaves, bark, and roots of a tree called Bonsam dua (lit. the wizard's tree), a nugget of virgin gold (gold that has been in use or circulation must not be used), a bodom (so called aggrey bead), and a long white bead called gyanie. The whole of these are pounded and placed in the pan, along with the original object already inside, while the following incantation or prayer is repeated: [...] ‘Supreme Being, upon whom men lean and do not fall, (whose day of observance is a Saturday). Earth Goddess, (whose day of worship is a Thursday), Leopard, and all beasts and plants of the forest, to-day is a sacred Friday; and you, Ta Kwesi (the particular god for whom in this case the shrine was being prepared), we are installing you, we are setting you (here), that we may have long life; do not let us get “Death”; do not let us become impotent; life to the head of this village; life to the young men of this village; life to those who bear children, and life to the children of this village. ‘O tree, we call Odum Abena, (to whom belongs the silk cotton tree), we are all calling upon you that you may come, one and all, just now, that we may place in this shrine the thoughts that are in our heads. ‘When we call upon you in the darkness, when we call upon you in the sunlight, and say, “Do such a thing for us”, you will do so. ‘And the laws that we are decreeing for you, you, this god [Page 149] of ours, are these-if in our time, or in our children's, and our grandchildren's time a king should arise from somewhere, and come to us, and say he is going to war, when he tells you, and you well know that should he go to the fight he will not gain the victory, you must tell us so; and should you know that he will go and conquer, then also state that truth. ‘And yet again, if a man be ill in the night, or in the daytime, and we raise you aloft and place you upon the head, and we inquire of you saying, “Is So-and-so about to die?”, let the cause of the misfortune which you tell him has come upon him be the real cause of the evil and not lies. ‘To-day, we all in this town, all our elders, and all our children, have consulted together and agreed without dissent among us, we have all united and with one accord decided to establish your shrine, you, Ta Kwesi, upon this, a sacred Friday. ‘We have taken a sheep, and a fowl, we have taken wine, we are about to give them to you that you may reside in this town and preserve its life. From this day, and so on to any future day, you must not fly and leave us. From this day, to any future day, you, O Tano's fire, in anything that you tell us, do not let it be a lie. Do not put water in your mouth and speak to us. To-day you become a god for the chief, to-day you have become a god for our spirit ancestors. Perhaps upon some to-morrow the Ashanti King may come and say, “My child So-and-so (or it may be an elder) is sick”, and ask you to go with him, or may be he will send a messenger here for you; in such a case you may go and we will not think that you are fleeing from us. And these words are a voice from the mouth of us all.’ [417]//'The various sacrifices are then made, and in each case the blood is allowed to fall upon the contents in the brass pan.' [418]//'I have had many similar accounts of the consecration of a new shrine as the temporary home of a new manifestation of a spirit universal and always present, but not subject to control.' [419]//'An Akan priest, okomfo, dancing in a state of possession [Page 29] main shrine who remit one-third of their profits to Akonnedi Some of the functions of these priestesses are the diagnosis and prescription of action for innumerable ills, mostly done while possessed. Western medicine is not incompatible with this type of tradition, since the ills treated here are sometimes psychical treated by means of supernatural powers or occult forces invoked by a priest (abosom okomfo) and sometimes physical i.e. bacterial diseases, treated by herbal medicine administered by a herbalist (odunsifo). These shrines are important in regulating social behaviour. A person may invoke the shrine in an oath, an extra-judicial outlet for emotions. The public is forced, then to take cognizance of a problem not within the bounds of the courts.' [420]//'Much traditional medical treatment is of a religious nature. Traditional explanations of sicknesses, besides purely organic causation familiar to westerners, include preordained destiny, retribution of angered ancestors, witchcraft and sorcery, the result of anti-social behaviour on the part of the sufferer. This supernatural aspect of the Akan theory of medicine helps maintain a balanced mental and social health. The diagnosis of those illness attributed to spiritual causes is the determination of social wrongs and the cure involves the righting of that wrong. Many Akan live in a delicate equilibrium with disease parasites (e.g. malarial and intestinal [Page 30]' [421]//'A Priest, okomfo, sitting inside his shrine [Page 31] worms), any social stress in the form of human hatreds or jealousies tends to weaken the person's natural resistance to such parasites. The importance of the priest in seeking out and curing the social disturbance is thus of paramount importance in removing the stress and allowing the patient to move back into an equilibrium with his parasites.' [422]//'The folk healers of the sick can thus be classified into three groups: (1) the herbalist (dunsini), (2) the herbalist who also deals in charms for witchcraft (abirifo; bayi/bonsam okomfo) and (3) the priest (bosomfo okomfo) who has a knowledge of herbs, charms for witchcraft, and is the attendant of a god (bosom). Nature is revered by these people, but it is also used to man's satisfaction.' [423] 'When an Ashanti falls ill, and the sickness does not yield to the ordinary household remedies (really household magic), or cannot be diagnosed, it then becomes necessary to call in a doctor. The doctor, as we have already seen, may be either what we should call a general practitioner, or a specialist. The Ashanti word for the former is Sumanni (pl. Sumankwafo), or sometimes Oduruyefo, and for the latter Bonsam 'Komfo. The exact derivation of these terms is interesting. Sumanni is just one who deals in suman, i. e. charms. If we studied his methods superficially, we should say he was a herbalist, and so he is, in so far as he works with leaves and roots and plants; but there is this great difference-his medicines are not efficacious because of their antitoxic properties, but because of their magic properties. The disease, for which he sets out to prescribe, is itself caused by superhuman agencies, and can only be cured by similar counter-measures. [Page 148] It is spirit acting upon spirit, not antitoxin upon toxin. There are many allied diseases in the spiritual pharmacopoeia, with all of which the sumankwafo are capable of dealing. There is one, however, which he cannot treat, the most dreaded scourge in Africa, a malady which I suppose it is no exaggeration to state has taken toll of tens of thousands of lives-i.e. witchcraft. Against this disease the Ashanti calls in the specialist, the Bonsam 'Komfo. Now okomfo is really a priest, one upon whom akom (possession) may come, and Bonsam is a male witch. I have already dealt with the craft of witch-doctors, or white witches, or whatever we may decide to call them, and we have seen how an analysis of their title explains the source of their inspirations, for these are men who have learned to use and control black magic in order to defeat black magic. As a general rule their methods of treatment are indirect, for they strive to cure the patient by stamping out the cause of the disease at its source, i. e. the discovery and exposure and killing of the witch. This quest, as we shall see presently, does not end with the death of the doctors' patient, for this ‘priest of the powers of evil’ will even call the spirit of the dead man, whom he has been unable to cure, to help him in his search for the murderer.' [424]//'A man or woman who is ill may also consult a priest of one of the many abosom (gods) as to the nature, cause, and probable ending of his sickness, and in many cases is informed by the god, through the medium of its mouthpiece the priest, that ‘ samanfo ye fwe fwe wo’ (‘the spirits of your ancestors are seeking for you’). This affords us a further clue as to another possible source of sickness and death.' [425]//'Townspeople come and ‘drink the medicine’ at a cost of about a shilling a head and as many fowls as need be. The candidate for protection must cut the throat of a fowl and fling the dying bird before the shrine. If the bird dies breast upwards the gift is accepted by the god: if the back is upwards the gift is rejected and the candidate is not approved by the god. The rejected suppliant then publicly confesses a few sins and tries again. He repeats this till his gift is accepted. He then drinks the ‘medicine’-which consists of water ceremonially treated by the priest-sometimes takes a herbal bath or is marked on the face with spots of white clay, and is then secure against witchcraft, bad medicine, theft and adulterous intrigue. Any one who tries to bewitch him, harm him magically, rob him or entice away his wife will be ‘caught by the medicine’. He himself must practise neither witchcraft, bad medicine, theft nor adultery or he too will be ‘caught’. Any one so ‘caught’ is smitten with sickness: if he confesses quickly and is taken to the shrine and cleansed, he recovers; if not, he dies.' [426]//'Many a morning does the word go round a town, ‘The medicine has caught somebody’, and the victim is carried to the shrine. Often this victim is a thorough-going neurotic, more often than not he has a rankling guilt-complex and is greatly benefited, if not cured, by confession. Often an astonishing tale of misdemeanours emerges. Nearly always venereal disease is somewhere at the bottom of the tales of marital unhappiness, envy and neurosis.' [427]//'Workers of ‘bad medicine’ are also often ‘caught by the medicine’. I have seen at the shrines amazing collections of apparatus ( suman) handed over by penitents. These include suman designed to cause other peoples' death, to cause accidents with cutlasses, hoes and motor-lorries, to ‘suck away’ others' money and enrich the suman-owner, to cause others' wives to leave them and to make others unsuccessful in obtaining wives.' [428]//'The shrines are thus the resort of mental patients in every stage of unbalance. Sometimes reports of their dramatic behaviour are circulated outside. District Officers and other Europeans are prone to put the cart before the horse and accuse the ‘fetish’ of ‘having a bad effect on people’. For instance, one woman patient on her way home from a shrine, committed an indecent act which would have surprised no one familiar with any of the standard works on psychopathology, but which, coming to official ears, was described as an ‘indecent ceremony’ and assumed to be part of the unwholesome ritual of the ‘fetish’. In actual fact the shrine-keepers themselves are quite as much shocked by indecorous behaviour as any European could be-in many cases more so. I recall a shrine-keeper whom I found one day anxiously purifying his shrine and his whole village with sacrifices because a woman patient had subjected him to the same fantastically indecent insult, identical in all its details, which Professor Jung, as he relates, once suffered at the hands of a woman patient. The Professor was, however, less horrified than was the shrine-keeper.' [429]//'We now turn to individual protection by “medicines”. Akropong students have written: “Some protective ‘medicines’ may be in the form of black powder injected into the body through vaccination or ‘drunk into the body’ with water. It is believed that these ‘medicines’ make your blood bitter so that no witch cares to taste it. For infants, the powder is put into a cream and the child's body is painted with it about twice a day”. “Some of the powder is mixed with palm wine and drunk”. “The black powder is filled into little bags or bottles carried on the body or round the neck”, “tied into a handkerchief and put under the beds and pillows”. “Medicated or herbal water is used for bathing in order to make the flesh bitter and nasty to the taste”. “Small cuttings, in groups of three or five, are made on all the joints and the ‘medicines’ are rubbed in, thus making one bold to withstand the witches”. “Powder mixed with oil is smeared on the body of a sick person”. Universal powders are generally sold by the anti-witchcraft doctors or medicine men, but one need not necessarily be a specialist in witchcraft in order to do so; they are just “house medicines” like cough syrups. The marks of the cutting for “vaccination” against witchcraft can be seen on many people on the wrist, while little bottles containing the powders can be seen hanging round the necks of many children. They are not only used against witchcraft, but for other “medical” reasons, and there are many different kinds of black powders (boto).' [430]//'Powders can be used to protect communities as well as individuals: “A whole community is protected through the bosomfoo (priest of a tutelar spirit) who may place some ‘medicine’ upstream of the water supply of the town. As both witches and non-witches drink from the same stream, they all come under the control of the cult, and a practising witch will be checked from the start”. This type belongs to the anti-witchcraft shrines.' [431]//'The idea of some of these medicines is “to drive out witchcraft by witchcraft”, e.g. a Ewe one, made from the feathers of a bird which was really a transformed witch: “Some people catch ‘witchcraft’, burn it and prepare medicine with it. Anyone who is injected with this medicine gains immunity from witch attack. When the ‘agent of witchcraft’ is caught, in the form of a bird or in any other guise, he is killed and the witch dies”. Rev. Spieth tells of a Ewe medicine made from seven torches, seven shells, a black fowl, a small pot of palm wine and a toad. This is smeared over the patient's body, making it slippery and magically immune to witchcraft. It would seem to be a method of healing the patient from witchcraft possession.' [432]//'In another case the reason for acquiring a new tutelar spirit was the illness of a chief which could not be cured by the local priests. This typical case has been well described by catechist J. P. Atiemo in the Christian Messenger of 1909. The local priests, instead of being killed for failing to cure the chief, as would have happened in the old days, before “the knife was lost” (i.e. the old customs prohibited by the Government), proclaimed that [Page 110] “their obosom had told them the town was full of witches and that they should therefore obtain ‘a medicine’ against them”. Messengers were sent to Nkoranza for permission to bring the “Barakune” or “Witchkiller” (Okum abayifo) shrine into town. (Sometimes a chief even applied to the District Commissioners “for a road pass for his fetish man in Car No. XX travelling to Bole”, because the chief said “I am sending this man to bring me something very necessary for my town's welfare”, or “to wash away the evil fate in the state”.)' [433]//'The week's festivities being over, the time had come when Barakune could at last enter K. Each one had to go individually to the person carrying the “medicine”. He would be told: “I bring you Kune” to which he had to answer: “I receive him and drink his medicine”.' [434]//'This old ceremony of “drinking obosom”, falsely translated as “drinking fetish” is “a potion drunk when swearing an oath of allegiance or mutual fidelity” (Christaller) attested for since the earliest times of contact between Europeans and Africans in Ghana. This drinking of medicine at anti-witchcraft shrines, also arises from the ancient healing practices of imbibing medicated water and is some sort of an ordeal. By drinking the medicine the person is brought into close contact with the anti-witchspirit, and the medicine is then “in him”; if he were doing evil or practising witchcraft, the “medicine” or the spirit would “catch him”.' [435]//'These potions were, and are of varied composition. According to Rev. Lädrach, that of Aberewa consisted of “an evil smelling concoction of rats, snakes, mice, lizards, spiders, kola nuts, pepper, herbs, bark, etc.”, and also contained “blood of sacrificed fowls and sheep. It stank so evilly that it must have affected the digestion of many, and much rum was drunk afterwards to drown the smell”.' [436]//'People confessing before the shrines sometimes describe their experience in this way: “When I was brought before the shrine, I refused at first to say what I had done. But last night I felt a heavy hand pressing me down and urging me to reveal the truth”. People suddenly falling ill might realize that they had sinned against a taboo or were “caught” because they had attacked somebody who was protected by a shrine. Or perhaps a local shrine, acting as a sort of “general practitioner” might tell them that such and such a spirit had caught them. Only then may they consult the anti-witchcraft shrine concerned. A student described the “catching” as follows: “When a person is a witch, Tigare's priest overhears it. He possesses a magic padlock, strengthened with blood, which he holds in his hand. He murmurs the name of the suspected witch three or seven times and ‘locks her up’ with the key. The person so padlocked in spirit becomes fever stricken…if the suspect has been a Tigare adherent, he is at once hurried to the shrine…”.' [437]//'A full confession must always precede the healing. The methods of the shrines for the curing of incipient witches and the driving away of witchspirits, are basically the same as those applied by herbalists specializing in the combating of witchcraft, who are frequently invoked by people believing themselves to be forced against their will into becoming witches.' [438]//'This neurotic state of fear is much more difficult to cure than the full blown witch state, and in severe cases can even produce hysteric blindness and lameness. One herbalist said: “you become sick and shrink”. His treatment consisted of giving his patient some medicine to put into a bucket of water. At midnight he had to proceed in utter darkness to the town rubbish heap, and bath in the water. This had to be done on seven consecutive nights, the climax of the treatment coming when the anti-witchcraft doctor tore off the person's cloth and burned it, all tendency towards witchcraft in the patient thus being destroyed. A new cloth was then given to him, and two fowls were sacrificed and shared by patient and anti-witchcraft doctor in a hearty meal of rejoicing. The fee for this treatment he said to be seven pounds, seven shillings and seven pence.' [439]//'Not only do the sects offer protection and healing, they are also thought of as a powerful agency to find out witches and evil spirits and to exorcise them. Witches are said to feel themselves urged to go to the prophets and there to confess their evil doings, and to ask for deliverance from the spirit possessing them ( cp. Plate 57).' [440] Debrunner also describes exorcisms performed by Christian 'prophets', but it is unclear whether what he describes for them also applies in similar fashion to non-Christian ritual conventions around witchcraft, possession, and healing.
