♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ ♥ (i.e. an individual who is not considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ ♥ (i.e. an individual who is considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ ♥ (e.g. sacrificing the first-born son)
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ ♥ Anti-witchcraft shrine-related cults: This ritual is awaiting an expert check to decide whether it should be coded here or not.Exorcism of witch spirits before the Kune shrine; Healing and possession rituals are also described in the colonial-era sources, but some sources maintain that these practices were a response to the colonial encounter rather than an element of 'traditional' Akan practice. We have therefore decided not to code for these in the pre-Ashanti period. We have nevertheless included some descriptive paragraphs, in case a pre-colonial predecessor can be identified: 'A spirit may take possession of a man and he may appear to have gone mad, and this state may last sometimes even for a year. Then the priest of some powerful god may be consulted and he may discover, through his god, that it is some spirit which has come upon the man (or woman). The one upon whom the spirit has come is now bidden to prepare a brass pan, and collect water, leaves, and ‘medicine’ of specific kinds. The possessed one will dance, for sometimes two days, with short intervals for rest, to the accompaniment of drums and singing. Quite suddenly he will leap into the air and catch something in both his hands (or he may plunge into the river and emerge holding something he has brought up). He will in either case fold this thing to his breast, and water will be at once sprinkled upon it to cool it, when it will be thrust into the brass pan and quickly covered up. The following ingredients are now prepared: clay from one of the more sacred rivers, like the Tano, and the following medicinal plants and other objects: afema [Justicia flavia], Dama Bo [Abras precatorius]; the bark of the odom, a creeper called hamakyem, leaves and bark of a tree called domine, another creeper called hamakyerehene, any root that crosses a path, a projecting stump in a path over which passers-by would be likely to trip, also roots and stumps from under water, the leaves of a tree called aya-those are chosen which are seen to be quivering on the tree even though no wind is shaking them-the leaves, bark, and roots of a tree called Bonsam dua (lit. the wizard's tree), a nugget of virgin gold (gold that has been in use or circulation must not be used), a bodom (so called aggrey bead), and a long white bead called gyanie. The whole of these are pounded and placed in the pan, along with the original object already inside, while the following incantation or prayer is repeated: [...] ‘Supreme Being, upon whom men lean and do not fall, (whose day of observance is a Saturday). Earth Goddess, (whose day of worship is a Thursday), Leopard, and all beasts and plants of the forest, to-day is a sacred Friday; and you, Ta Kwesi (the particular god for whom in this case the shrine was being prepared), we are installing you, we are setting you (here), that we may have long life; do not let us get “Death”; do not let us become impotent; life to the head of this village; life to the young men of this village; life to those who bear children, and life to the children of this village. ‘O tree, we call Odum Abena, (to whom belongs the silk cotton tree), we are all calling upon you that you may come, one and all, just now, that we may place in this shrine the thoughts that are in our heads. ‘When we call upon you in the darkness, when we call upon you in the sunlight, and say, “Do such a thing for us”, you will do so. ‘And the laws that we are decreeing for you, you, this god [Page 149] of ours, are these-if in our time, or in our children's, and our grandchildren's time a king should arise from somewhere, and come to us, and say he is going to war, when he tells you, and you well know that should he go to the fight he will not gain the victory, you must tell us so; and should you know that he will go and conquer, then also state that truth. ‘And yet again, if a man be ill in the night, or in the daytime, and we raise you aloft and place you upon the head, and we inquire of you saying, “Is So-and-so about to die?”, let the cause of the misfortune which you tell him has come upon him be the real cause of the evil and not lies. ‘To-day, we all in this town, all our elders, and all our children, have consulted together and agreed without dissent among us, we have all united and with one accord decided to establish your shrine, you, Ta Kwesi, upon this, a sacred Friday. ‘We have taken a sheep, and a fowl, we have taken wine, we are about to give them to you that you may reside in this town and preserve its life. From this day, and so on to any future day, you must not fly and leave us. From this day, to any future day, you, O Tano's fire, in anything that you tell us, do not let it be a lie. Do not put water in your mouth and speak to us. To-day you become a god for the chief, to-day you have become a god for our spirit ancestors. Perhaps upon some to-morrow the Ashanti King may come and say, “My child So-and-so (or it may be an elder) is sick”, and ask you to go with him, or may be he will send a messenger here for you; in such a case you may go and we will not think that you are fleeing from us. And these words are a voice from the mouth of us all.’ [441]//'The various sacrifices are then made, and in each case the blood is allowed to fall upon the contents in the brass pan.' [442]//'I have had many similar accounts of the consecration of a new shrine as the temporary home of a new manifestation of a spirit universal and always present, but not subject to control.' [443]//'When he first started behaving strangely no one could decide whether he was mad or whether “an obosom wanted to come”, though it seems certain that the strange behaviour came in fits and starts. He often flung off his clothes, strode about naked and staring and made attempts to run to bush. Sometimes he seized hold of a passing sheep, cut its throat, carried the carcase to the abonsam stone, and came back, remaining quite mute the while. On recovery from the attacks he remembered nothing of his actions and was startled when told of them. In some of his attacks he would career wildly up and down the town, gibbering an unintelligible “language”. Sometimes he had ten or a dozen attacks in one day: he told me, “It hardly left me alone long enough to let me eat.” He was taken to all the country's most famous oracles and medicine-men for diagnosis and treatment and cost his kinsmen, in all, about £300 before one medicine-man diagnosed “a very strong obosom, too big for us to control” and recommended a visit to the shrine at Mframaso. This was made. The old priest of Mframa was then alive and he not only endorsed the diagnosis but undertook to keep the youth under his care, train him and, after training, help him to set up in practice in Nsuso. The old priest accepted nothing for his training, board and lodging, but said he could pay off his debt when he started to work.' [444]//'At the shrine the possessed priest questions the supplicant as he does those who complain simply of physical sickness, and if he elicits family strife and anxiety he advises concerning it. If the supplicant is on good terms with his wife, he usually brings her with him. If she is absent the priest asks why. A goldsmith whose wife had refused to come with him was told, after answering leading questions about her, “She is the cause of your plight. Leave her and take a better woman.” When the supplicant is paranoid and says, “People envy me and want to keep me down”, or, “Please kill the person who is doing this to me”, or, “Witches have caused people to dislike me”, the priest usually falls into step, diagnoses witchcraft or bad medicine and gives a reassuring promise of protection. He makes no identification of the witch or medicine-maker, but simply says, “The cause is among your own kinsmen”, or, “There are witches in your house.”' [445]//'Most commonly the deity diagnoses witchcraft. The witches have stolen away the supplicant's womb or penis-that is the spiritual counterpart of the organ-and have either eaten it (in which case there is no hope) or broken it in pieces, or hidden it in a river. The supplicant is told to lay his need before the deity, make a sacrifice to the river in which the damaged organ is hidden, and the deity will do his best to repair and restore it. Sometimes the sufferer is told that no evil has been at work: his childlessness is “from God” and is his destiny ( nkrabea). Occasionally, but not often, the supplicant is told to carry out some unusual ritual, such as bringing the obosom a live cat-fish, or a live cat or a doll whose calico wrapping is taken into the sanctuary for special rites: it is then hoped that the obosom will intercede with his father, the Supreme God, and get the supplicant's destiny changed.' [446]//'When a supplicant comes asking for the deity's protection the priest usually finds out first whether this is simply a prudent precaution-an insurance policy, as it were-or whether the supplicant is in specific anxiety. When the supplicant offers a cow or any more valuable gift than the usual sheep in return for a year's protection, he is certain to be unusually worried. If the supplicant comes alone he is asked why the husband or wife is absent. The questioning technique is the same as that [Page 123] The questioning technique is the same as that employed in investigating anxiety-begotten illnesses and the same kind of fears are laid bare. Where there is family or marital disharmony and suspicion the supplicant usually fears that the adversary will employ bad medicine against him. The priest generally discovers who started any such dispute and if the supplicant himself is at fault he is told he will get protection conditionally on making amends.' [447]//'Workers of ‘bad medicine’ are also often ‘caught by the medicine’. I have seen at the shrines amazing collections of apparatus ( suman) handed over by penitents. These include suman designed to cause other peoples' death, to cause accidents with cutlasses, hoes and motor-lorries, to ‘suck away’ others' money and enrich the suman-owner, to cause others' wives to leave them and to make others unsuccessful in obtaining wives.' [448]//'The shrines are thus the resort of mental patients in every stage of unbalance. Sometimes reports of their dramatic behaviour are circulated outside. District Officers and other Europeans are prone to put the cart before the horse and accuse the ‘fetish’ of ‘having a bad effect on people’. For instance, one woman patient on her way home from a shrine, committed an indecent act which would have surprised no one familiar with any of the standard works on psychopathology, but which, coming to official ears, was described as an ‘indecent ceremony’ and assumed to be part of the unwholesome ritual of the ‘fetish’. In actual fact the shrine-keepers themselves are quite as much shocked by indecorous behaviour as any European could be-in many cases more so. I recall a shrine-keeper whom I found one day anxiously purifying his shrine and his whole village with sacrifices because a woman patient had subjected him to the same fantastically indecent insult, identical in all its details, which Professor Jung, as he relates, once suffered at the hands of a woman patient. The Professor was, however, less horrified than was the shrine-keeper.' [449]//'The week's festivities being over, the time had come when Barakune could at last enter K. Each one had to go individually to the person carrying the “medicine”. He would be told: “I bring you Kune” to which he had to answer: “I receive him and drink his medicine”.' [450]//'This old ceremony of “drinking obosom”, falsely translated as “drinking fetish” is “a potion drunk when swearing an oath of allegiance or mutual fidelity” (Christaller) attested for since the earliest times of contact between Europeans and Africans in Ghana. This drinking of medicine at anti-witchcraft shrines, also arises from the ancient healing practices of imbibing medicated water and is some sort of an ordeal. By drinking the medicine the person is brought into close contact with the anti-witchspirit, and the medicine is then “in him”; if he were doing evil or practising witchcraft, the “medicine” or the spirit would “catch him”.' [451]//'These potions were, and are of varied composition. According to Rev. Lädrach, that of Aberewa consisted of “an evil smelling concoction of rats, snakes, mice, lizards, spiders, kola nuts, pepper, herbs, bark, etc.”, and also contained “blood of sacrificed fowls and sheep. It stank so evilly that it must have affected the digestion of many, and much rum was drunk afterwards to drown the smell”.' [452]//'People confessing before the shrines sometimes describe their experience in this way: “When I was brought before the shrine, I refused at first to say what I had done. But last night I felt a heavy hand pressing me down and urging me to reveal the truth”. People suddenly falling ill might realize that they had sinned against a taboo or were “caught” because they had attacked somebody who was protected by a shrine. Or perhaps a local shrine, acting as a sort of “general practitioner” might tell them that such and such a spirit had caught them. Only then may they consult the anti-witchcraft shrine concerned. A student described the “catching” as follows: “When a person is a witch, Tigare's priest overhears it. He possesses a magic padlock, strengthened with blood, which he holds in his hand. He murmurs the name of the suspected witch three or seven times and ‘locks her up’ with the key. The person so padlocked in spirit becomes fever stricken…if the suspect has been a Tigare adherent, he is at once hurried to the shrine…”.' [453]//'A full confession must always precede the healing. The methods of the shrines for the curing of incipient witches and the driving away of witchspirits, are basically the same as those applied by herbalists specializing in the combating of witchcraft, who are frequently invoked by people believing themselves to be forced against their will into becoming witches.' [454]//'This neurotic state of fear is much more difficult to cure than the full blown witch state, and in severe cases can even produce hysteric blindness and lameness. One herbalist said: “you become sick and shrink”. His treatment consisted of giving his patient some medicine to put into a bucket of water. At midnight he had to proceed in utter darkness to the town rubbish heap, and bath in the water. This had to be done on seven consecutive nights, the climax of the treatment coming when the anti-witchcraft doctor tore off the person's cloth and burned it, all tendency towards witchcraft in the patient thus being destroyed. A new cloth was then given to him, and two fowls were sacrificed and shared by patient and anti-witchcraft doctor in a hearty meal of rejoicing. The fee for this treatment he said to be seven pounds, seven shillings and seven pence.' [455]//'Not only do the sects offer protection and healing, they are also thought of as a powerful agency to find out witches and evil spirits and to exorcise them. Witches are said to feel themselves urged to go to the prophets and there to confess their evil doings, and to ask for deliverance from the spirit possessing them ( cp. Plate 57).' [456] : Debrunner also describes exorcisms performed by Christian 'prophets', but it is unclear whether what he describes for them also applies in similar fashion to non-Christian ritual conventions around witchcraft, possession, and healing. The week's festivities being over, the time had come when Barakune could at last enter K. Each one had to go individually to the person carrying the “medicine”. He would be told: “I bring you Kune” to which he had to answer: “I receive him and drink his medicine”.' [457]//'This old ceremony of “drinking obosom”, falsely translated as “drinking fetish” is “a potion drunk when swearing an oath of allegiance or mutual fidelity” (Christaller) attested for since the earliest times of contact between Europeans and Africans in Ghana. This drinking of medicine at anti-witchcraft shrines, also arises from the ancient healing practices of imbibing medicated water and is some sort of an ordeal. By drinking the medicine the person is brought into close contact with the anti-witchspirit, and the medicine is then “in him”; if he were doing evil or practising witchcraft, the “medicine” or the spirit would “catch him”.' [458]//'These potions were, and are of varied composition. According to Rev. Lädrach, that of Aberewa consisted of “an evil smelling concoction of rats, snakes, mice, lizards, spiders, kola nuts, pepper, herbs, bark, etc.”, and also contained “blood of sacrificed fowls and sheep. It stank so evilly that it must have affected the digestion of many, and much rum was drunk afterwards to drown the smell”.' [459]//'People confessing before the shrines sometimes describe their experience in this way: “When I was brought before the shrine, I refused at first to say what I had done. But last night I felt a heavy hand pressing me down and urging me to reveal the truth”. People suddenly falling ill might realize that they had sinned against a taboo or were “caught” because they had attacked somebody who was protected by a shrine. Or perhaps a local shrine, acting as a sort of “general practitioner” might tell them that such and such a spirit had caught them. Only then may they consult the anti-witchcraft shrine concerned. A student described the “catching” as follows: “When a person is a witch, Tigare's priest overhears it. He possesses a magic padlock, strengthened with blood, which he holds in his hand. He murmurs the name of the suspected witch three or seven times and ‘locks her up’ with the key. The person so padlocked in spirit becomes fever stricken…if the suspect has been a Tigare adherent, he is at once hurried to the shrine…”.' [460]//'A full confession must always precede the healing. The methods of the shrines for the curing of incipient witches and the driving away of witchspirits, are basically the same as those applied by herbalists specializing in the combating of witchcraft, who are frequently invoked by people believing themselves to be forced against their will into becoming witches.' [461]//'This neurotic state of fear is much more difficult to cure than the full blown witch state, and in severe cases can even produce hysteric blindness and lameness. One herbalist said: “you become sick and shrink”. His treatment consisted of giving his patient some medicine to put into a bucket of water. At midnight he had to proceed in utter darkness to the town rubbish heap, and bath in the water. This had to be done on seven consecutive nights, the climax of the treatment coming when the anti-witchcraft doctor tore off the person's cloth and burned it, all tendency towards witchcraft in the patient thus being destroyed. A new cloth was then given to him, and two fowls were sacrificed and shared by patient and anti-witchcraft doctor in a hearty meal of rejoicing. The fee for this treatment he said to be seven pounds, seven shillings and seven pence.' [462]//'Not only do the sects offer protection and healing, they are also thought of as a powerful agency to find out witches and evil spirits and to exorcise them. Witches are said to feel themselves urged to go to the prophets and there to confess their evil doings, and to ask for deliverance from the spirit possessing them ( cp. Plate 57).' [463] : Debrunner also describes exorcisms performed by Christian 'prophets', but it is unclear whether what he describes for them also applies in similar fashion to non-Christian ritual conventions around witchcraft, possession, and healing. The week's festivities being over, the time had come when Barakune could at last enter K. Each one had to go individually to the person carrying the “medicine”. He would be told: “I bring you Kune” to which he had to answer: “I receive him and drink his medicine”.' [464]//'This old ceremony of “drinking obosom”, falsely translated as “drinking fetish” is “a potion drunk when swearing an oath of allegiance or mutual fidelity” (Christaller) attested for since the earliest times of contact between Europeans and Africans in Ghana. This drinking of medicine at anti-witchcraft shrines, also arises from the ancient healing practices of imbibing medicated water and is some sort of an ordeal. By drinking the medicine the person is brought into close contact with the anti-witchspirit, and the medicine is then “in him”; if he were doing evil or practising witchcraft, the “medicine” or the spirit would “catch him”.' [465]//'These potions were, and are of varied composition. According to Rev. Lädrach, that of Aberewa consisted of “an evil smelling concoction of rats, snakes, mice, lizards, spiders, kola nuts, pepper, herbs, bark, etc.”, and also contained “blood of sacrificed fowls and sheep. It stank so evilly that it must have affected the digestion of many, and much rum was drunk afterwards to drown the smell”.' [466]//'People confessing before the shrines sometimes describe their experience in this way: “When I was brought before the shrine, I refused at first to say what I had done. But last night I felt a heavy hand pressing me down and urging me to reveal the truth”. People suddenly falling ill might realize that they had sinned against a taboo or were “caught” because they had attacked somebody who was protected by a shrine. Or perhaps a local shrine, acting as a sort of “general practitioner” might tell them that such and such a spirit had caught them. Only then may they consult the anti-witchcraft shrine concerned. A student described the “catching” as follows: “When a person is a witch, Tigare's priest overhears it. He possesses a magic padlock, strengthened with blood, which he holds in his hand. He murmurs the name of the suspected witch three or seven times and ‘locks her up’ with the key. The person so padlocked in spirit becomes fever stricken…if the suspect has been a Tigare adherent, he is at once hurried to the shrine…”.' [467]//'A full confession must always precede the healing. The methods of the shrines for the curing of incipient witches and the driving away of witchspirits, are basically the same as those applied by herbalists specializing in the combating of witchcraft, who are frequently invoked by people believing themselves to be forced against their will into becoming witches.' [468]//'This neurotic state of fear is much more difficult to cure than the full blown witch state, and in severe cases can even produce hysteric blindness and lameness. One herbalist said: “you become sick and shrink”. His treatment consisted of giving his patient some medicine to put into a bucket of water. At midnight he had to proceed in utter darkness to the town rubbish heap, and bath in the water. This had to be done on seven consecutive nights, the climax of the treatment coming when the anti-witchcraft doctor tore off the person's cloth and burned it, all tendency towards witchcraft in the patient thus being destroyed. A new cloth was then given to him, and two fowls were sacrificed and shared by patient and anti-witchcraft doctor in a hearty meal of rejoicing. The fee for this treatment he said to be seven pounds, seven shillings and seven pence.' [469]//'Not only do the sects offer protection and healing, they are also thought of as a powerful agency to find out witches and evil spirits and to exorcise them. Witches are said to feel themselves urged to go to the prophets and there to confess their evil doings, and to ask for deliverance from the spirit possessing them ( cp. Plate 57).' [470] : Debrunner also describes exorcisms performed by Christian 'prophets', but it is unclear whether what he describes for them also applies in similar fashion to non-Christian ritual conventions around witchcraft, possession, and healing. 'Anyone considering himself “caught” by a spirit, may have to travel up to a hundred miles to that spirit's main shrine. In order to reach it safely, he pours rum on the ground to appease the spirit, and at the shrine he will have to wait for its special week-day. On that day the priest will be a holy person and no one is allowed to shake his hands. (He has to abstain sexually the night before.) The priest will enter the temple and fall into a trance, in order that the spirit may speak through him ( cp. Plate 24). This may be in a sort of pidgin-Twi (the spirits are often connected with Northern Ghana where this is the form of speech) or it may be completely unintelligible and is often accompanied by a quivering of the mouth and jaws. The person “caught” will then come forward, give his name and state what he has done. He is then questioned until the whole story has been told. The “spirit”, therefore, acts as a sort of court dealing with witchcraft cases theft, adultery, broken taboos, and cases of oath (when the fetish had been invoked as a witness in an argument). The invoking of the fetish is considered a great sin. Confessing witches may name people they have killed or made barren and these names are taken down. They often maintain [Page 126] they have “eaten” their own child. In order that their witch-spirits may lose their power, they may then reveal their secret names, and sing their “witch-song”. They must hand over the objects in which the witch-spirit was supposedly kept-beads, towels, pots, stools, cloth, etc., and at this moment the assembled crowd will sometimes mock triumphantly. At one particular shrine the priest sometimes tells the accursed to show the palm of his hand, from which he pretends to be able to read his guilt. Thieves are either made to return the money they have stolen to the defrauded person, or the priest will himself accept the money and return it to its owner. In addition, the culprit has to pay one or two “sheep” to the shrine for its services (fifteen to thirty shillings. A real sheep, of course, costs much more.). Not all cases are settled at once-some are dismissed, others require further evidence, etc., and those which do not fit into the preconceived pattern of witchcraft belief are rejected as idle tales. The atmosphere at shrines is often psychologically impressive and suggestive, since some of the shrines are far away, and well off the main road. One priest even had a private road constructed to the outskirts of his town, eight miles from the main road. Lorries were not allowed to enter the town itself, and, therefore, the last two hundred yards had to be done on foot. He installed electricity in the town, but as the spirit “told him that he did not like it”, the generator was not used.' [471]//'What happens if a witch has been “caught” by a shrine and has “confessed”? At one time witches were killed, but this has been stopped by the Government, and now the shrines attempt to heal witches or to drive away their witch-spirit. A priest told me: “I cure the witches by water treatment. First an egg is broken over the head of the witch after her confession, then she is thrice sprinkled with medicated water. The recipe of this medicine is my secret”. This is how Mr. Akesson describes the exorcism of witch spirits before the Kune shrine, in his manuscript “Gold Coast Fetishism Explained”: “After a victim's confessions have been heard and his sacrifice of a fowl has been accepted by the fetish, a day is fixed for the final exorcism. The linguist mixes red clay with water and brings with it an old sweeping broom. The victim sits in front of the male fetish. The linguist dips the broom into the liquid and gently strikes the top of the victim's head three times saying: ‘Yeyi wo bayie’ (we drive out your witchspirit). In the same [Page 127] manner, the face and the joints of the victim are struck thrice daily. After this the victim is asked to stand facing his house or town. The linguist then holds the neck and pushes him to give him a start to run away to his house without looking behind. As he runs away, the spectators hoot at him at the top of their voices until the victim has disappeared. This done, the patches of hair on his head are cut off for him by one of the fetish servants”. A full confession must always precede the healing. The methods of the shrines for the curing of incipient witches and the driving away of witchspirits, are basically the same as those applied by herbalists specializing in the combating of witchcraft, who are frequently invoked by people believing themselves to be forced against their will into becoming witches. This neurotic state of fear is much more difficult to cure than the full blown witch state, and in severe cases can even produce hysteric blindness and lameness. One herbalist said: “you become sick and shrink”. His treatment consisted of giving his patient some medicine to put into a bucket of water. At midnight he had to proceed in utter darkness to the town rubbish heap, and bath in the water. This had to be done on seven consecutive nights, the climax of the treatment coming when the anti-witchcraft doctor tore off the person's cloth and burned it, all tendency towards witchcraft in the patient thus being destroyed. A new cloth was then given to him, and two fowls were sacrificed and shared by patient and anti-witchcraft doctor in a hearty meal of rejoicing. The fee for this treatment he said to be seven pounds, seven shillings and seven pence. The witches only punishment nowadays consists of fines, and public exposure to mockery and ridicule. Witches caught by some shrines are shamed by being made to dance in public. It is said that witchcraft carries no stigma, and although members of the clan may press the victim to confess, in general a victim nowadays is kindly treated after confession and not maltreated for practising witchcraft. From my research however, I get the impression that while this may be true in some cases, witchcraft on the whole carries with it a social stigma. A witch who has been found out may not be maltreated, but he or she is certainly despised and ostracised, which is a much more severe punishment than the imposition of fines. When witches have been “cured” by a shrine, the protection of the shrine does not provide them with an enhanced social status, although anybody worrying them might “get into trouble with the shrine”.' [472]//'In out of the way places, dances are performed which culminate in direct “discovery” of witches. A District Commissioner told me that he was afflicted by sunstroke when visiting a village in the Goaso region. The priest of the local shrine tried to appease the tutelar spirit of the town, which the D.C. was supposed to have offended. The priest worked himself into an ecstatic, almost epileptic trance turning round and round with a foaming mouth, whipping the drummers when they tried to relax. He then picked out six women and declared them guilty of causing the sunstroke of the European.' [473]//'It is the main purpose of the anti-witchcraft shrines to destroy evildoers and witches. As many people as possible therefore, are urged to “drink the medicine” or join one of the cults. Moral pressure is brought to bear upon the psychic weaklings of society and so a continual supply of self-confessed “poisoners” and “witches” is always available. After the drinking of the medicine some people even die-the number of these seems to have been considerable in the times of the Aberewa cult. It was even said that “she had been sent down to earth to protect men and to prolong their lives, but finding so many evildoers, she was greatly incensed and destroyed indiscriminately rich and poor, young and old alike. It was even said that Aberewa dispatched to eternity more people than those poisoned and killed by all sorcerers and witches whose power she came to abolish”. (30) If any of the adherents break the rules of the shrine, the spirit will “catch” them. Anybody-especially a witch-attacking a devotee of a shrine will also be “caught” by the spirit.' [474]//'On the other side, another officiant was beating the ‘dawuta’ a sort of iron bell or gonggong. He squatted beside a basket containing the little fowls for the oracle. Beside him, beyond the [Page 119] cemented area, two men were standing, and they explained at great length the favour they sought. Onlookers were standing around. When the request had been explained to the spirit whose attention had been attracted by the knocking and the beating of the dawuta, the attendant sitting near the basket passed one of the very small fowls, which could only have been a few days old, to the other squatting attendant who had stopped beating his tattoo. He then made a slit in the throat of the chicken from the beak to the breast, allowed some of the blood to drop on the alter-like block, and then threw the chicken on to the cemented area, while everybody watched the death struggle of the tiny animal. If the fowl died on its back, this meant that the request was granted; if it died on its belly or its side, this signified refusal ( cp. Plates 30-32).' [475]//'The shrines certainly brought life and excitement. They provided festivals with the drumming and dancing so dear to every African, bringing colour and change into the dull life of the country towns ( cp. Plates 21 and 25). Miss Field said that their festivals were indeed “celebrations charged with enthusiasm, spontaniety and genuine gaiety”, and they (23) “far surpassed in heartiness and festiveness any of the older town festivals except that of Assene”. (24)' [476]//'If a person is presumed to have been killed by an anti-witchcraft spirit, his entire property would belong to the priests of the shrine (who would sometimes divide it with the chief of the place), unless the body was “bought” from the priests by the relatives. The body and its property was said to belong to the priests, since the tutelar spirit had captured him as one captures an enemy in war. Furthermore, the relatives had to give a “thank offering” to the priests, because the spirit had delivered them from grave danger threatening them through their evil relative. No customary funeral was allowed, the corpse having to be disposed of in a shamefaced way. In the case of Aberewa and other pre-1914 shrines, a shallow trench was half filled with various thorny branches, and the body was thrown in and hastily covered with a little earth.' [477]//'The intention of all these laws with their terrible threats is obvious: to reknit society by the imposition of new moral and legal sanctions. In this way, they hoped to overcome the various stresses and frictions in society which were brought about by the culture contact.' [478]//'Every priest I met told me that the spirit of his shrine hated jealousy, hatred and evil thoughts. The commandments of Tigare even have a technical term for this: sipe, grudge or ill feeling. It is possible that there is some Christian influence behind this from the commandment to love one another, but it is more probable that it is the modern form of the old ideal of a “good village” where respect and order are maintained. As so often found in popular morality, the stress is more on the “thou shalt not”, than on the positive aspects of the commandments.' [479]//'In his manuscript “Gold Coast Fetishism Explained”, Mr. Akesson describes very well by what agencies such anti-witchcraft shrines from the north were introduced. Sometimes it would be by a labourer from Northern Ghana or even the far north; at others by a driver who hoped to make money in this way. Frequently the setting up of such a shrine will necessitate several journeys to the north. Permission from chiefs there and from a special office of the Asantehene (Paramount Chief of Ashanti) is required. It may also be necessary to get a permit to act as a “native midwife” from a government agent, while expenses for the setting up of such a shrine may easily amount to three hundred pounds.' [480]//'Most of the new shrines dealing in witchcraft are offshoots of those in Northern Ghana. The further people had to travel in order to get to them the more highly were they esteemed. Barakune and Kankamea came from the Dagati. Tongo is at home in the Tong hills near Zuarungu, Kupo at Senyon near Bole (hence Senya-Kupo), Aberewa comes from the region of Boundoukou (6), Tigare from Ypala near Wa, Asasi from the Ivory Coast, etc. In their original homes some of these shrines were of the ordinary protective type, without specialising in witchcraft. But since they were the shrines of far off vigorous tribes not yet under the mental stress and conflicts arising from the culture contact in the South, they attracted the attention of the Southerners who came there to get help from their troubles.' [481]//'Roughly speaking, there have been three main crests in the waves of anti-witchcraft shrines: before 1912, between 1924 and the economic crisis, and in and after World War II. At each of these times the influx of foreign ideas was particularly strong and the country had something of an economic boom.' [482]//'The movement began after the middle of the last century, almost simultaneously with the intensification of Government interference with native customs. The first anti-witchcraft activity on any considerable scale that I could trace in old records, was that of an “anti-witch exorcist” called in by an association of Ga, Efutu and Agona towns, ca. 1855. This was done on the advice of the priests of the traditional tutelar spirits. This witch-hunter's success at Agona-Swedru, and his failure at Obutu owing to the influence of Christianity, have been well described by Rev. Bohner.' [483]//'These were the relatively insignificant predecessors of far greater movements which set in after 1900. British Government control became more strict, and spread over Ashanti bringing durable peace, and at the same time came educational, economic, religious and moral revolution in full. Since that time, the countertide and reaction of the anti-witchcraft shrines has never ceased completely. It comes in waves-sometimes strong-sometimes weak. The names of the shrines often changed, but basically they remained the same phenomenon.' [484]//'Superficial observers have often said that pagan religion in Ghana was weak and unable to withstand the combined attack of the trader, the administrator, the missionary and the teacher, whose several influences destroy the old tribal pattern of culture and religion, at the same time weakening the position of the chief and to a greater extent that of the priests. But longer and closer observation by many missionaries, has led to the discovery that tribal paganism and superstition, have as many heads as the hydra serpent of classical mythology. The introduction to an old missionary pamphlet on the notorious anti-witchcraft shrine of Aberewa says: “as new heads grew up as soon as one of the old ones was cut off, so paganism produces time and again new forms, even when you think it to be almost conquered”. (1) So thought the missionary. On the other hand, the anthropologist who had a more positive attitude to paganism, was thrilled by the observation of the same fact which seemed to him like “an entirely new and growing system…to meet the new needs”, (2) and on the rise of the new anti-witchcraft shrines he comments: “It is quite certain that a vigorous countertide is surging through the great mass of the population and its chiefs. Spontaneously, inarticulately, and without knowledge of what they are doing, they are re-establishing many features of a long abandoned type of organization”. (3) By this, the author (Miss Field) means the old agricultural society as still evidenced in Northern Ghana [Page 106] where life and organization were centred on the worship of nature-spirits.' [485]//'These anti-witchcraft shrines are the most active aspect of paganism in Ghana today, and claim to provide the answer to the new needs which we will now discuss.' [486]//'This possibility has been open at all times, and set the pattern for a later increase of the neurosis of witchcraft belief. It seems that in the past-before 1850-the witches were comparatively few, and no major danger to the society, which knew quite well how to cope with them in traditional ways. This still is the case in Northern Ghana if we are to believe Dr. Meyer-Fortes who has made a very thorough study of the Talensi, a tribe from that area. It is more difficult to prove the assumption that witchcraft played a smaller role in the past in Akan society, but it is noticeable that only one author before 1850 mentions the witches, whilst all others are completely silent on the subject. Witches in the past could easily be appeased by putting a small amount of meat on sticks at the entrance of towns. In this way the neurotics had the satisfaction of being socially recognized and feared, and therefore became more manageable for society. In more severe cases, antisocial elements were dealt with by ordinary justice by the elders and chiefs, in consultation with the priests of the tutelar spirits. In still more difficult cases or where the authority of a court was not in itself strong, there were various ordeals to find the guilty person-the thief, adulterer, murderer, poisoner or witch. Each death and disaster could be explained either by referring it to Nyame as a death of destiny, or by attributing it to the neglect of duty towards the tutelar spirits, the ancestors, the ntoro or the life soul, or to the evil activity of murderers, poisoners, criminals, workers of bad magic and witches. We shall describe these ordeals in a later chapter. The threat and fear of them acted as a powerful help to maintain the existing pattern of culture.' [487]//'It is indeed striking, that just after the final establishment of the “pax britannica” in Ghana in the first years of this century, the first great wave of witchcraft fear and anti-witchcraft shrines was sweeping over the country. Dr. Tooth is right in remarking: “It must be remembered that it is less than fifty years since the Gold Coast was freed from the constant threat of internal warfare. The effect of the removal of the insecurity due to personal danger must alone be considerable, but any individual benefit is probably offset by the breaking up of the communities which owed their existence to the competition of arms, and the need for organised self-defence…the behaviour of the mass of the people is still [Page 66] best explained in terms of a release from the artificial restrictions imposed by the state of the country fifty years ago, coupled with a strong natural curiosity”.' [488]//'Society reacts against the new false “ideal” of the “big man” by imputing witchcraft to rich people. It has been observed in the past, that witch hunting was one of the means by which chiefs and communities were able to check the power of wealthy people. “Big men” were tracked down as witches and forced to pay heavy fines. This destroyed the exaggerated respect paid to them, and diminished their wealth, whilst at the same time, the chief obtained much needed money. (155) The recent witch-hunting of a pseudo-prophet was welcomed by chiefs of the region concerned for that very reason, as I personally observed. Society seeks by these neurotic means to counteract the dangers of the recent economic and social trends, but the answer lies in true social reform.' [489]//'The so-called Nzima-bayi and other supposed ways of making money by magic, are a neurotic attempt to escape from these economic and sociological facts by cutting the Gordian knot ( see appendix B).' [490]
'All these elements contributed to form one of the main causes of the increase in witchcraft belief, and the decline in morality, for example, bribery. As Miss Field says: “Not only did the Cocoa industry bring an increase in witchcraft but also an increase in plain ordinary stealing. Both Cocoa and the money paid out by the cocoa buyers to the small farmer are often stolen. The police and all the tribunals know quite well that the cocoa season is the season of maximum crime. Though a part of this crime can be laid at the door of liquor, on which much of the money is spent, a great part is simple theft. The influx of strangers for cocoa trading, and mining has also increased the tendency of women to be unfaithful to their husbands”. (164) This is true not only of the cocoa growing areas, but also for the non-cocoa growing areas, where the men are often absent for weeks if not months, far away on their cocoa farms, leaving the women at home. This militates against stability. What has been said for cases of Cewa witchcraft (the Cewas are a Bantu tribe in South Africa) is therefore equally true of Akan witchcraft: “We may ultimately trace all witchcraft cases described above to conflict between European and Cewa value premises-especially those regarding the nature of property ownership”.' [491]//'This is another helpful line of approach, though very isolated and one which is nowadays almost out of date. Its use is suggested in the notes collected by Rev. Lochmann. In discussing disease, he states that “a fetishman may tell you the reasons for it-either the life-soul went away…or the life-soul is sick…or you may be told that you took leave of God correctly, but that a mischievous enemy hindered you from getting what you should have got, according to your leave taking; go therefore and cut yourself a Nyame dua (God's tree) and put it at the entrance of your yard, kill a fowl and besmear his wings with blood, hang them on the Nyame dua and pray thus to Nyame: that you may get that which you have chosen from God, in your leave-taking”.' [492]//'A student wrote: “A little bit of raw meat or other food is frequently put at the entrance of a village for the witches to eat. This offering also frequently takes the form of a bunch of palm nuts pinned to the ground with a stick” ( cp. Plate 15). “Another way of appeasing the witch is to make an ohoni, a kind of effigy, meant to represent a sick person, which is put at the outskirts of the town for the spirit or witch supposed to be troubling the person. Before it you put some meat, e.g. the leg or shoulder of a sheep on a long pole”. This practice, though once very common, is rarely seen nowadays. Here is another story of witch-appeasing, as told by a student: “Some time ago a child saw a witch spouting fire while sitting on a tree behind his parents' house. The child took the fancy to go there and throw a stone at the tree. At once the fire was quenched and a naked woman stood before him. She looked silently at the child and went up the tree again. The next morning the child was full of deadly sores. Medicine after medicine was given to the child, but the sores did not heal, until at last they asked the child what had happened. Being told, the parents of the child fetched various things: a bathing sponge, eggs, soap, and ten shillings for the witch to ask her forgiveness. When the woman had taken these things, the sores at once died away and the child recovered”. It would seem [Page 90] that the matter was solved peacefully and the psychic conflict in the child's soul was settled in an empirical psychiatric way. Two people were helped, the guilt-complex was taken from the child and the frustration complex from the “witch”, who now saw herself in a somewhat respected and feared position. In this instance belief in witchcraft can be said to be an impetus to retrieve the balance of social relations, and fulfil a valuable social function. This is very marked among the Azande, according to Dr. Evans-Pritchard. “Belief in witchcraft”, he writes, “is a valuable corrective to uncharitable impulses, because a show of spleen, meanness or hostility may bring serious consequences in its train. Since Azande do not know who are witches and who are not, they assume all their neighbours to be so, and are therefore careful not to offend any of them without good cause. The notion works in two ways. Firstly, a jealous man may be suspected of witchcraft by those of whom he is jealous, and will seek to avoid suspicion by curbing his jealousy, and secondly, those of whom he is jealous may be witches and may seek to injure him in return for his enmity, therefore he will curb his jealousy from fear of being bewitched”' [493]//'In order to protect the fields, the sheep are often fenced in. In order to protect a town magically, there are various methods of spiritual “fencing in”. Some anti-witchcraft shrines, e.g. Kankamea, have a “holy area” marked off by a chain which is thought to keep out any evil thinking person. Similarly, a town may be protected by “spiritually isolating it against witches” with a wire drawn round it, as I have seen in Nzima. Another such magic fence is the pampim, “a low fence or obstruction over the foot-path near a town or village, to prevent the entrance of evil spirits”.' [494]//'We now turn to individual protection by “medicines”. Akropong students have written: “Some protective ‘medicines’ may be in the form of black powder injected into the body through vaccination or ‘drunk into the body’ with water. It is believed that these ‘medicines’ make your blood bitter so that no witch cares to taste it. For infants, the powder is put into a cream and the child's body is painted with it about twice a day”. “Some of the powder is mixed with palm wine and drunk”. “The black powder is filled into little bags or bottles carried on the body or round the neck”, “tied into a handkerchief and put under the beds and pillows”. “Medicated or herbal water is used for bathing in order to make the flesh bitter and nasty to the taste”. “Small cuttings, in groups of three or five, are made on all the joints and the ‘medicines’ are rubbed in, thus making one bold to withstand the witches”. “Powder mixed with oil is smeared on the body of a sick person”. Universal powders are generally sold by the anti-witchcraft doctors or medicine men, but one need not necessarily be a specialist in witchcraft in order to do so; they are just “house medicines” like cough syrups. The marks of the cutting for “vaccination” against witchcraft can be seen on many people on the wrist, while little bottles containing the powders can be seen hanging round the necks of many children. They are not only used against witchcraft, but for other “medical” reasons, and there are many different kinds of black powders (boto).' [495]//'Powders can be used to protect communities as well as individuals: “A whole community is protected through the bosomfoo (priest of a tutelar spirit) who may place some ‘medicine’ upstream of the water supply of the town. As both witches and non-witches drink from the same stream, they all come under the control of the cult, and a practising witch will be checked from the start”. This type belongs to the anti-witchcraft shrines.' [496]//'Among the Akan, witches are at times “fumigated away”; “In a house where there is a babe or a sick person supposed to be under the influence of witches, scented gum (caked latex of a particular tree called ohe) is burned in a small broken earthenware pot which is put at the gate, or, when going to bed, at the door leading to the room. This ohe burns slowly and gives off a scented smoke that permeates the whole house, both within and without. It is believed that this scented smell drives away all witches and so wards off any diabolical visiting” (statement from a student). Such fumigating, with ricinus leaves and sharp pepper is common among the Adangmes. (15) The story of Tobias shows us that the Jews used to believe that demons could be driven away by smoke. (16) As Europeans we may well think that such fumigations disinfect rooms and drive away malaria carrying mosquitoes! The idea of some of these medicines is “to drive out witchcraft by witchcraft”, e.g. a Ewe one, made from the feathers of a bird which was really a transformed witch: “Some people catch ‘witchcraft’, burn it and prepare medicine with it. Anyone who is injected with this medicine gains immunity from witch attack. When the ‘agent of witchcraft’ is caught, in the form of a bird or in any other guise, he is killed and the witch dies”. Rev. Spieth tells of a Ewe medicine made from seven torches, seven shells, a black fowl, a small pot of palm wine and a toad. This is smeared over the patient's body, making it slippery and magically immune to witchcraft. It would seem to be a method of healing the patient from witchcraft possession.' [497]//'Charms are often dispensed by the priests of shrines. The Moslem sebe or abansere charms are the most prevalent: they consist of verses from the Koran and Arabic magic formulae sewn into leather. Students describe anti-witchcraft charms thus: “They are rings on the finger, sebe, beads, arm rings”. “These things must always be worn and carried about. The people who invented them are the Northern Territories people and the Togolanders. Some are hung at the gates of houses and doors so that evil doers may not approach. All these things work spiritually” ( cp. Plate 16). [...] The old Ashanti charm Kunkuma and others are still used, but those from the north are thought to be more efficient. There are two reasons for this: Firstly, objects, medicines and charms from far away are always considered to be more efficient. Secondly, the tribes of the Northerners are still more compact and not under the same mental stress as the Southerners and therefore there is more psychic vigour and less fear of the witches in the north. Why? The African answers: “Because their charms are better”.' [498]//'The very same belief was affirmed to me by an anti-witchcraft doctor when I asked him whether the famous tutelar spirit Akonnedi of Larteh could offer protection against witches. “How could he?” was the answer, “the witches serve as his lanterns when he goes on trips at night”. This somewhat curious connection of witches and tutelar spirits may represent a relic of very ancient beliefs, where light phenomena were not associated with witchcraft. There are, however, several ancient abosom who engaged in witch-fighting. These are the shrines of the region round Wenchi in Northern Ashanti among the Brongs.' [499]//'In the past, the ordinary methods of protection by charms and powders described above seem to have sufficed to deal with the witches. There was even a certain antagonism in some cases between the charms and the more aristocratic shrines of tutelar spirits. (23) Hence the anti-witchdoctors could affirm: “the abosom were never consulted for the discovery of bayi (witchcraft), because it was recognised that they would not tell, ‘being afraid of bayi which was more powerful than they’. When I am under the possession of Sasabonsam, a priest will address me as father”.' [500]//'This seems to be another instance of a pre-Akan religion. Local abosom may be conscious of their duty to protect against witchcraft, but, being of the town and related to many townspeople, the priests would find it too risky to make accusations of witchcraft among their relatives. In the terms of witchcraft belief, this is expressed by a student: “So great is the witches' connection with base and evil spirits that they can do very little good but much evil. If there is an obosom in the town which does not allow them to do all they want, they kill his obosom by putting its filthy taboos into the kunkuma (the pot serving as shrine) at the obosom's grove”.' [501]//'And here is another version of the same psychological fact from a different angle recorded by another student: “The tutelar spirits have dominion over their people in town. So they can prevent the wizards from attacking or preying on their subjects, except with permission. So if anybody wants to be free of the pangs of witches and wizards, he should pay homage to the abosom who will protect him. The priests act as the interpreters of the abosom and at times they receive bribes from the witches and allow them to carry off some unfortunate people. So most priests have power to catch witches on active service. But when a priest is becoming somewhat too hostile toward the witches, they form a strong company and try to overthrow him spiritually. So early deaths of some priests are ascribed to the work of the witches”.' [502]//'People nowadays, seldom, if ever, have recourse to the traditional shrines for protection. Dr. Field has rightly remarked that “interest in the archaic, nature-worshipping religion is now disorganized, fragmentary and not bound up with the social organization. Their mediums are usually very old persons…and where a deity fails to possess a medium at all, it is a clear indication that no one is interested in that deity”. Thus the tutelar spirits were not able to cope with the new rise of witchcraft-they were, as we have seen, “driven away by the guns, the church bells and the telephone wires”. Where the tutelar spirits of the old type still function in witchcraft cases, they do so as sort of “general practitioners” and send those they suspect afflicted by witchcraft to the “specialists”-the new shrines of the anti-witchcraft type to be described later. In the past, they could use for their diagnosis the string-oracle called “ntonto-bo”, the drawing of lots. (26) Rev. Jost brought such an oracle home to Switzerland from Brofoyedru in Asen and presented it to the Historical museum of Berne (27) ( cp. Plate 19).' [503]//'In order to find out the guilty person, African justice in the past often resorted to trial by ordeals. In this way thieves, murderers, taboo-breakers and witches were “found out”. Space prevents me from describing these ordeals at length. There were a number of minor ones. The suspects were made to chew dry rice and those who could not swallow it were declared guilty. Medicine men were alleged to possess black powder with which they could make a witch glow or even burn, if they rubbed it on his forehead. After the application of a counter-medicine, the witch would confess. The Gas used some special medicated eyewater which would blind the guilty ones and leave the innocent unharmed. (31) More serious was the ordeal with boiling oil, into which the suspect was to hold his hand. (32) This ordeal was surrounded by an elaborate [Page 102] ritual. Even more fearful was the poison ordeal, where a concoction of the bark of the Odom ( not Odum) tree was drunk by the suspect. Fainting and loss of consciousness were taken as proof of guilt. (33) Such poison ordeals are common all over Africa. (34)The most important Ghana ordeal was the so called “carrying of the corpse”. The dead body of a person who had died a strange death was carried by either two or four men. (Sometimes some objects represented the actual body.) The “corpse” was asked questions and answered “yes” or “no” by the way it “made the carriers sway or knock forward”. In this way the corpse could knock against the guilty person.' [504]//'What happened if an ordeal had designated somebody as a real or “spiritual” murderer, poisoner or witch? The proverb says: “the corpse which is going to knock against someone cares nothing for cries of sorrow”. n olden days a person found guilty by the poison ordeal was caught by the feet, dragged through the scrub and over stones till his body was torn to pieces and he died. This was the procedure among the Gas. Among the Ashantis, a witch's blood may not be shed. She was, therefore, strangled to death, or drowned, or clubbed, or smeared all over with palm oil and cast into a fire. Another method of punishment has also been described by Captain Rattray: “A self confessed witch used to have a firebrand placed in her hand before being expelled from the village. A message was sent to the next village, from which she would also be driven and so on. This punishment really amounted to the death penalty”. Among the Brongs at Boundoukou, the person found guilty was clubbed to death in the forest and his body was just thrown into the bush and not buried-a terrible punishment, if one knows how important for the after life correct burial is esteemed among the pagan. (38) Among the Nkonya (a Guang tribe) the punishment was death by burning, or the payment of a ransom to the value of seven slaves. (39) Among the Agni, the punishment for witchcraft was decapitation. Until a century ago, the person convicted of witchcraft was almost always put to death by torture as Bowdich attests. This was really just a ceremonial form of lynching.' [505]//'A long heartbreaking account of such an execution witnessed by Rev. Mader, dated 29th October, 1856, is preserved in the Archives of the Mission House in Basel. Space prevents me from quoting the well-written report in full. Rev. Mader describes how the asafo (war companies of young men) danced through Akropong in a drunken frenzy. The corpse of a deceased person had knocked at somebody. The Asafo went and pulled down this “accursed house”, and rushed on the person indicted, wounding him with their cutlasses and clubs, and torturing him terribly for three hours-frantically dancing up and down the town hitting the miserable wretch every time they passed him. At last he was decapitated. The skull was to be buried at the feet of the person he was supposed to have killed, and afterwards to be fixed on a war drum. The right hand and the fingers of the left were also cut off, but Rev. Mader did not find out what became of them. The body was not buried, but just thrown into the bush. After the Colonial Government had stopped this lynching, another form of punishment became more frequent: it was that of telling or expecting the person found guilty to commit suicide. (42) The same Rev. Mader reports another case of “carrying the corpse”, where the “guilty person” was a mother of eight children. Through fear of the government-since two soldiers happened to be in town-she was not lynched but socially ostracized. Everybody avoided her. Her relatives told her to take courage and kill herself. She even went to see the paramount chief to ask for her death, but was refused-again for fear of the Government. She was then taken into custody in the house of an elder. There the constant mockery so distressed her, that she finally asked permission to fetch firewood in the bush and there she hanged herself. Another way of avoiding the wrath of the Government was by killing the “guilty person” secretly. This was done in a town near Anamabou, where the person indicated by the ordeal of “carrying the corpse” was secretly drowned in the sea. It took the authorities fourteen years to discover it! This happened about one hundred years ago and the whole procedure has been described at length by the British officer Brodie Cruickshank.' [506]//'In the past, persons thus found guilty of “murder” were either killed, or sold into slavery. (45) The property of the person executed, or forced to suicide on account of an ordeal, or of his being a witch, went to the chief. The relatives, however, could ask the chief for forgiveness and were given part of the goods of the executed [Page 104] person. (46) Since the Government has abolished all this elaborate trial by ordeal and summary punishment, what reaction follows? Similar interference of Governmental authorities in the Sudan made Dr. Evans-Pritchard, write that it brought about “vagueness and confusion”. (47) The same can be said of the Akan. However cruel the old system may look to us today, it maintained some order. Guilty persons were found-it did not matter whether they always really were guilty or not-and the system gave a certain sense of security. This was destroyed by the Government, which, of course, only wanted to prevent cruelty and could not do otherwise than prohibit such customs. The feeling of insecurity which resulted has been reported from the mouth of a Ghana Chief by Mary Kingsley: “A chief complained to me of the way the Government, in the districts under its surveillance, were preserving vermin in the shape of witches. You were no longer allowed to destroy them as of old, and therefore the vermin were destroying the game for, he said, ‘the witches here live almost entirely on the blood they suck from children at night. They used in the old days, to do this furtively…but in districts where the Government says that witchcraft is utter nonsense, and killing its proficients is utter murder which will be dealt with accordingly, the witch flourishes exceedingly, and blackmails the fathers and mothers of families, threatening that if they are not bought off, they will have their child's blood; and if they are not paid, the child dies away gradually…” (48)' [507]//'At one particular shrine the priest sometimes tells the accursed to show the palm of his hand, from which he pretends to be able to read his guilt. Thieves are either made to return the money they have stolen to the defrauded person, or the priest will himself accept the money and return it to its owner. In addition, the culprit has to pay one or two “sheep” to the shrine for its services (fifteen to thirty shillings. A real sheep, of course, costs much more.). Not all cases are settled at once-some are dismissed, others require further evidence, etc., and those which do not fit into the preconceived pattern of witchcraft belief are rejected as idle tales. The atmosphere at shrines is often psychologically impressive and suggestive, since some of the shrines are far away, and well off the main road. One priest even had a private road constructed to the outskirts of his town, eight miles from the main road. Lorries were not allowed to enter the town itself, and, therefore, the last two hundred yards had to be done on foot. He installed electricity in the town, but as the spirit “told him that he did not like it”, the generator was not used.' [508]//'What happens if a witch has been “caught” by a shrine and has “confessed”? At one time witches were killed, but this has been stopped by the Government, and now the shrines attempt to heal witches or to drive away their witch-spirit. A priest told me: “I cure the witches by water treatment. First an egg is broken over the head of the witch after her confession, then she is thrice sprinkled with medicated water. The recipe of this medicine is my secret”. This is how Mr. Akesson describes the exorcism of witch spirits before the Kune shrine, in his manuscript “Gold Coast Fetishism Explained”: “After a victim's confessions have been heard and his sacrifice of a fowl has been accepted by the fetish, a day is fixed for the final exorcism. The linguist mixes red clay with water and brings with it an old sweeping broom. The victim sits in front of the male fetish. The linguist dips the broom into the liquid and gently strikes the top of the victim's head three times saying: ‘Yeyi wo bayie’ (we drive out your witchspirit). In the same [Page 127] manner, the face and the joints of the victim are struck thrice daily. After this the victim is asked to stand facing his house or town. The linguist then holds the neck and pushes him to give him a start to run away to his house without looking behind. As he runs away, the spectators hoot at him at the top of their voices until the victim has disappeared. This done, the patches of hair on his head are cut off for him by one of the fetish servants”.' [509]

Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ ♥
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ ♥
♠ fear ♣ ♥
♠ humiliation ♣ ♥
♠ disgust ♣ ♥
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ ♥ (e.g. vomiting)
♠ pain ♣ ♥
♠ mutilation ♣ ♥
♠ risk of death ♣ ♥

♠ alcohol ♣ ♥
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ ♥
♠ sex ♣ ♥
♠ dancing ♣ ♥
♠ synchronous movement ♣ ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison)
♠ singing ♣ ♥
♠ entertainment ♣ ♥
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ ♥
♠ oath taking ♣ ♥
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ ♥
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ ♥
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ ♥
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ ♥
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ ♥
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ ♥
♠ property/valuable items ♣ ♥
♠ health costs ♣ ♥
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ ♥
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ ♥ (i.e. an individual who is not considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ ♥ (i.e. an individual who is considered part of the group performing the ritual)
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ ♥ (e.g. sacrificing the first-born son)
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)

Phase II Variables (polity-based)[edit]

Institutional Variables[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

♠ Editor ♣ ♥

Note: Writing about the Ashanti period, Arhin describes the power hierarchy from the village upwards: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [510] Major and minor chiefs were also summoned to council: 'Where the paramount King of a state summons the Head-Chiefs of provinces and chiefs of minor communities to attend a State Council, it is the privilege of the Councillors of the several communities composing the State, according to their rank and importance, to accompany their several Heads to the capital and to join in the “palaver,” or discussion, that will take place, the King in person presiding over the deliberations, supported by his own Councillors and principal Linguists. This is the full Parliament of the people, who are thus fully and duly represented in every way from the highest to the lowest. The commands which go forth from this assembly are binding upon every individual family of the entire State, from the most important province to the most insignificant hamlet, and the sanction operates equally upon all.' [511] The attribution of concrete entities to a particular executive level is not always clear. On the executive level it therefore seems best to go with the stool system: 'Every Asante village was a microcosm of the Asante economic, social, and political universe. Its population included both rulers and ruled, both “owners” of the land with the right of succession to the local, divisional, and state stools and free men grouped in other lineages with corporate interests in other political offices.' [512] In the pre-Ashanti period, this hierarchy probably culminated in the rulers of regional Akan states.

However, by making this assumption we might distort historical realities. While some Akan states were politically autonomous, others paid tribute to other polities after having been conquered by Akan competitors. Accordingly, histories of conquest and military expansion predate Ashanti rule over Ghana: 'Akan states, historical complex of gold-producing forest states in western Africa lying between the Comoé and Volta rivers (in an area roughly corresponding to the coastal lands of the modern republics of Togo, Ghana, and, in part, Côte d’Ivoire). Their economic, political, and social systems were transformed from the 16th to the 18th century by trade with Europeans on the coast. Of the northern Akan (or Brong) states the earliest (established c. 1450) was Bono; of the southern the most important were Denkyera, Akwamu, Fante (Fanti), and Asante.' [513] 'Denkyera, also spelled Denkyira, major 17th-century kingdom of the southern Akan peoples, situated in the forested hinterland of modern Ghana’s southwestern coast. According to tradition, its kings migrated from the area of the northern Akan or Brong. By the end of the 17th century they had subjugated the Twifo and the Akan subjects of Axim (to the south), had taken over the rich gold-bearing districts of Wassaw and Aowin (to the west), and had established their dominion over Elmina Castle—the wealthiest market on the Gold Coast.' [514] 'The desire to control the major extractive areas of the gold-mining industry brought Denkyera into conflict with the Asante, against whom it waged a series of ultimately unsuccessful wars between 1699 and 1701. After Denkyera’s final defeat, many chiefs recognized the authority of the Asante king Osei Tutu—by whom they were incorporated into the Kumasi division of his kingdom—while others, moving south of Denkyera’s ancient capital Abankeseso, retained their national identity but acknowledged the Asante’s overlordship. See also Akan states.' [515] Meyerowitz provides the following summary: 'The history of Ghana can be divided into four distinct periods; the first from roughly A.D. 1000 to 1500, the second from about 1500 to 1701, the third from 1701 to 1901, and the fourth from 1901 (when the country became a British colony known as the Gold Coast) to independence in 1957.' [516] 'The history of Ghana is the history of the Twi-speaking peoples who now call themselves Akan — a name which originally denoted one group only. Before that time they were known as Gbon; this name has been forgotten, but the fact may be inferred from the names of several states which they founded after their earlier kingdom in the Niger bend, Dyala, had been destroyed about A.D. 1000 by Islamised Saharan Berbers.' [517] 'States founded in Ghana and surrounding regions at that time were Gonja (the modern name for Gbon-Dya), north of the Black Volta where the river flows from west to east. Close by on the other side of the White Volta (a confluent of the Black Volta) emigrants from Gonja founded the Dagbon (Dya-Gbon) kingdom. To the north of Gonja, Gbon with a Dya royal clan, founded the first Bono (descendants of Gbon) kingdom in the triangle formed by the White and Red Volta rivers, ‘in Mossi’, a kingdom which existed already in about A. D. 1000.' [518] 'Adjacent to Bono ‘in Mossi’ in the west was the Djomo (Dya-Mo) kingdom founded by Adiaka Fante, a branch of the Akan. To the south-west of Dya-Mo on the other side of the Black Volta where the river flows from north to south, Gbon with a Dya royal clan, founded the Bona (descendants of Gbon) kingdom and at a later date another branch of the Gbon founded the Bonda (Gbon-Dva) kingdom to the north of Bona. Further to the west Gbon founded Kpon(g) in the Upper Volta region (Kpon is a variant of Gbon). Kpong, two centuries later, became the capital of the Kumbu kingdom, the original home of the Akan proper. To the north was the kingdom of the Twi-speaking Anyi whose royal clan was related to that of Bono and Bona; and to the far west of Kpong lay the kingdom of a branch of Fante whose name is no longer remembered.' [519] 'In the course of centuries refugees and emigrants from all these kingdoms came and settled (up to about 1600) mostly in the second Bono kingdom which had been founded about 1300 south of Gonja by refugees from the first Bono kingdom ‘in Mossi’. Bono's capital Bono-Manso soon developed into a great and [Page 6] important town owing to its trade, especially the gold trade with the Sudan. Bono being underpopulated welcomed ‘brothers’ from other regions at all times. The brothers' were attracted by the country's prosperity, which grew until its end in 1722-3' [520] 'In the middle of the fourteenth century, a number of people emigrated from Bono, among them Fante, Eguafo, Afutu and Dyabi who eventually founded a number of small states on the central coast among the Etsi who, like the Bono, were Dya-Gbon people from the Niger bend. Contact between the Bono and the coastal people was maintained by means of the north-south road. This was, in fact, no more than a path through still primaeval forest leading from Bono-Manso to Eguafo and from there to the coastal towns; hunters who had set up their camps along this road gave food and shelter to the travellers passing through. A century later this road became of the greatest importance after two events inaugurated the second period of Ghana's history.' [521] 'Shortly before 1500 the Portuguese discovered the coastal people and, attracted by their gold omaments, returned ten years later to build Elmina Castle on Eguafo territory for trading purposes. At the same time in the 1470s, the Bonda kingdom was conquered by Anyi and the Kumbu kingdom ceased to exist after its conquest by the Songhay. Many refugees went in search of new homes, and having heard in Bono-Manso of the trade activities of the Portuguese on the coast, some of the more enterprising Bonda and Kumbu people went south and were able to settle at strategic points. The queenmother Asiriba of Bonda and followers occupied the region along the central part of the north-south road where her successor founded the Akyerekyere kingdom to the south of Bono. Its capital Fomase soon became the clearing house for goods from the coast, mostly of Portuguese origin one may assume, and goods from Bono and various parts of the Sudan.' [522] 'On the other hand, a prince of the former Kumbu royal house who had gone to Bono-Manso gathered a number of young men around him there, marched south, and drove out the Wasa (of Fante origin) from their eastern territory ‘behind Eguafo’, and founded there the Akumu-Akoto kingdom. Its capital Kum-Kunso was situated roughly thirty miles to the north of Elmina Castle. Whereas the Bonda dominated the north-south trade road, the ‘Acanes’ as the Portuguese called the Akumu-Akoto, dominated the old trade road from Eguafo to Begho, the capital of Banda, neighbouring Bono in the west. It had been founded by Dyala peoples who had settled first in Mande, mostly Kara and Kamara Dyula. From Begho the [Page 7] trade road led directly to Mande towns and the Niger bend.' [523] 'Other ‘Acanes’ founded Akyim ‘Great Akan’ bordering on Akyerekyere in the east, and about A.D. 1550 emigrants from Akumu-Akoto founded Akwamu on Akyim lands in the east. From 1660 onwards Akwamu expanded to the north and east and became one of the most powerful states in the seventeenth century.' [524] 'Akyerekyere ceased to exist when Agona from Bono-Manso (immigrants of Mande origin) made themselves rulers of the country which they renamed Denkyira. Like the Akwamu they conquered the surrounding states but were unable to subdue the Anyi who, from 1500 or earlier, had penetrated the westem forest region down to the coast where they founded various kingdoms.' [525] 'In the forest region belonging to Bono, in what is now the Kumasi-Bekwai area, Asantemanso was founded about 1600 by Domaa, emigrants from Akwamu. About fifty years later a civil war broke out which destroyed the town and some of the homeless survivors founded city states to the north-east of Kumasi.
