The Denkyira invaded at once the Asantemanso-Kumasi region and the new city states and ruled its inhabitants mercilessly until, in 1701, under the able leadership of Osei Tutu, the Asantemanso people rebelled and defeated the Denkyira. After this victory they founded the Asanteman, or Ashanti kingdom with its capital Kumasi, and incorporated most of the vassal states of Denkyira. Thus from its inception Ashanti was a powerful state. In 1723, as a result of its defeat of Bono, the whole savannah region between the forest and the Black Volta river came under the suzerainty of Ashanti. Thus the third period in Ghana's history began with the foundation of Ashanti and ended with its defeat by the British in 1901.' [526] Accordingly, the pre-Ashanti history of the Akan states may have been more complex than our usual inference approach allows for.

Some examples of pre-Ashanti Akan states: NKYIRAA: 'The Nkyiraa either no longer remember where their ancestors came from or do not wish to have it known. They arrived in Bono in the middle of the seventeenth century (they had three chiefs before 1700) and were people of the Asona clan who spoke ‘Blong’, a Brong dialect of the type where sentences often start with me daa—‘I say’. Their leaders were Atia Yaw and the queenmother, or headwoman, Twumwaa. Legend has it that they ‘came out of the hill Botene’, one mile from the present Tekyiman, together with Anyima-Asine people and Djomo. As they were numerous they soon spread as far as Taakoti, another hill near Tekyiman, and founded Taakotiso there. Others, among them Atia Yaw and his people, went northwards and founded Boso about six miles from the present Nkyiraa.' [527] 'After some time Atia Yaw and his group separated from the Anyima-Asine, Asine clan people called Anyima after their chief, and founded a few miles away Wurobo-Buem; the chief of the Djomo carried the fire before them when they came ‘out of the ground’.' [528] 'Wurobo-Buem soon attracted people and developed into a big place; Atia Yaw as chief of the Nkyiraa and Djomo took the title Ohene, king, Ntakera. He was succeeded by Kwaku Amforo; in the reign of his successor Boyi Akwatia the ‘Nkoranza-Nafana war broke out, that is the Bono-Nafana war after the destruction of Beeo-Nsoko. Neither Nkoranza nor Banda (the Nafana state) existed at this time. In the Nkiyraa tradition ‘Nkoranza’ took the place of the forgotten Bono-Manso and ‘Banda’, the place of the Nafana who at a later date were to found the Banda state. The Bono must have drafted the Nkyiraa as well as the Anyima-Asine into their shock troops for both suffered enormous casualties. When the survivors returned there was great lamentation and neither people could bear to remain in their towns any longer bereft of their menfolk.' [529] 'The Anyima-Asine emigrated into the region where Nkoranza was built by the Asine prince Adu Denyina of Amakum some twenty years later, while the Nkyiraa and Djomo moved to a place about seven miles from the present Nkyiraa town. There they came ‘out of a hole’—it was actually a cave in a great, big boss of sandstone with a narrow slit above an entrance which is now hidden. In [Page 58] a tiny village, Adunyede, not far from ‘the hole’ lives the descendant of the original priest chief to whom the land belonged, and who still performs the custom for the rock, the home of the ancient god Obotin Kwamena. 2 When they emerged the Nkyiraa settled not far away at Hurubera.' [530] 'In Boyi Akwatia's reign a Nkyiraa princess was given in marriage to the Bonohene Kyereme Pambuo, the predecessor of the last king of Bono, Ameyaw Kwaakye. Their son was Boyemprisi who was to contribute so much to the downfall of Bono. He was called Boyemprisi because at the time of his birth, Kwaku Nyame, a well-known royal hunter (he once caught an elephant alive) had discovered caves ‘in the stomach of a rock’ (hence ‘Boyem’), the source of the rock being sacred to the god Mprisi. The event took place during the annual hunt for squirrels which were eaten by royal guests during the Apo festival.' [531] 'When the Ashanti advanced towards Bono-Manso in 1722/3, Boyemprisi, who realised that the war was lost, fled to Gonja with his people, those numerous young men who had followed him to the capital to celebrate the New Year festival, never to return. 4 Their families may have joined them there, for when Hurubera was taken by the Ashanti, half the people left the town in terror and many settled in Fante states on the coast. Those who stayed on shortly after moved five miles away and founded the present town of Nkyiraa. ' [532] 'Booi Akwatia was succeeded by Kofi Date (Nketia), Kofi Adinkera, Kwame Baah, Kwaku Amo, Amponsa Kwaku, Tabiri Yaw, Kwawe, Yao Amponsa (Ketekye), Afirimu and Kwadja Asabere, in whose reign the following event took place:' [533] 'In the 1740s the Bono-Tekyiman state was created by the Ashanti and Nkyiraa became one of its towns. During the Ashanti-Gyaman war of 1818-19 Tekyiman was forced to send a contingent of warriors and its seven powerful priest-chiefs of the state to help the Asantehene Osei Bonsu to win the war. After the war, believing that the gods of the priest-chiefs had been instrumental in the victory and afraid to leave them at the disposal of the Tekyimanhene, Osei Bonsu annexed the seven towns to serve Ashanti directly and Nkyiraa was one of them. As the Asantehene had been especially impressed by Kwaku Asabere, Nkyiraahene and priest of the god Kukuro, he offered him the post of Sumankwahene in Kumasi, to protect him against evil spirits and witchcraft. Kwaku Asabere accepted and was succeeded at Nkyiraa by his brother Tabiri Kwaku and, in Kumasi, by his son Kwasi Dumde at a later date. Since powers of spiritual origin are regarded as men's affair, the Sumankwahene, a title best translated as ‘chief of magic arts’, is succeeded everywhere patrilineally.' [534] EGUAFO (AGUAFO): 'In Tekyiman it is still remembered that Aguafo (now known as Eguafo with Fante prefix E) who were Guan people, as their name indicates, were among the founders of Bono-Manso but left it in the reign of the second Bonohene Akumfi Ameyaw I roughly between 1330 and 1350. According to Eguafo traditional beliefs, they moved south, accompanied by Dyabi and Evalue, and settled for a time in dense forest in what is now the Twifo-Prasu region. They then founded Eguafo as capital of the Eguafo state some ten or twelve miles north-west of the more recent town of Elmina, on the coast.' [535] 'Nana Kobina Gyan II and his elders at Elmina said that Kwamina Ansa of the Asona clan was their first chief at Eguafo. However, the chief of the Anona clan (the Fante name for the Agwana or Anana, the Guan clan of Bono) was of equal importance and therefore, contrary to matrilineal custom, the queenmother was chosen from the other, Anona clan. They also married contrary to custom, so that their son could succeed who, in turn, married the queenmother, a princess of the Asona clan. Succession in the royal lineage can thus be regarded as patrilineal for succession was from father to son; on the other hand the kings [Page 77] came alternately in each generation from the Asona and Anona clans, so the matrilineal clan organization, it is believed, remained undisturbed. The state and its capital were called after the Guan but the official language is said to have been Bono Twi, for which there is some evidence.' [536] 'In the reign of Kobina Amankwa, Kwamina Ansa's grandson, and something like seventy-five years before the arrival of the Portuguese (considering that Kobina Amankwa was succeeded by Kwagya I and II and Kwamina Kwagya Ansa) the French, it is said, established themselves on the central coast although no documents relating to a French presence at that date have been found so far. Seeing that today the Ghanaians call the Lebanese traders ‘Pataki’, which means Portuguese, the ‘French’ may have been Gonoaese or Castilians.' [537] 'The Etsi claim that their ancestors were the first of the coastal peoples to make contact with these Europeans at the farthest end of the Elmina Lagoon where they had a settlement, but it was the Eguafo who realized that to trade with them might be advantageous and invited them to stay. The ‘French’ then built a lodge (a mile west of Elmina Castle) and labourers from various places on the coast, who helped to construct it, built a village close by called Bantama. The lodge is now in ruins, and only the excavation of the site might identify the people who seem to have been the first Europeans on the west coast of Africa. The surface of part of the site is littered with potsherds, and Dutch canons which were taken from Elmina Castle during the Ashanti invasion of 1807 are embedded in the ground.' [538] 'When the ‘French’ had finally settled Kobina Amankwa, wishing to be nearer them, moved to the coast where he founded Amankwakurom (now called Elmina), leaving his brother Takyi in charge of Eguafo town. In order to know when the ‘French’ ships arrived, he built himself a hut—rebuilt through centuries and still in existence—in which to consult an oracle.' [539] 'At an unknown date the ‘French’ deserted their lodge near Bantama and many Bantama people who had become Christians took possession of the statue of the ‘French’ god Antona (St Antony ?), which they are said to have left behind. When the lodge crumbled the statue was taken to Elmina and the present priest is a descendant of those priests who were taught by the ‘French’ padres. I attempted to see this statue as it seemed possible that it might provide the clue to the nationality of the people who made it, but was refused.' [540] 'As the ‘French’ tried to trade with Afutu and Etsi on the coast Akyene Takyi, a grandson of Kobina Amankwa, was ordered to found a town on the coast ten miles to the west of Amankwakurom. This town was referred to as [Page 78] Little Eguafo, or Akyi Takyi and the name became Aitaco, Akitaki or Ekke Tokki on later Dutch maps.' [541] 'In the reign of Kwamina Kwagya Ansa the Portuguese discovered the Costa da Mina, the coastal region of Eguafo and, in 1482, built San Jorge da Mina (Elmina Castle) for trading purposes at Amankwakurom. Unfortunately, the early, most important, documents in which the Portuguese presumably described the kingdom, its people and customs, and their neighbours, were destroyed in a mid-eighteenth century disaster in Lisbon. 2 Those which survived refer only to trade activities of later periods but indirectly contain information.' [542] 'Of interest are the various kings and chiefs who received gifts from the Portuguese. 3 Thus the ‘King of Kommany’ (Eguafo) received the largest numbers of presentations, since he was the ultimate landlord of the ground on which the fort stood. But he should be called ‘King of the Kommany’ because Kommany was not the name of the kingdom (this was Aguafo at the time), but of foreign traders who lived in the twin town of Amankwakurom, probably called Kommany. Amankwakurom was a double town like all early Akan towns—hence the Portuguese called it aldeia das duas partes, the ‘town of the two parts’. Patrilineal people, which always meant foreigners, had to live in a town of their own.' [543] 'The chief foreigners at Amankwakurom, one can assume therefore, were the so-called Kommany, Kamana or Kamara Dyula (Twi suffix na instead of ra), most of whom probably came from Begho. The bulk of the Kommany, however, judging from the name Kommenda (which is obviously the same as Kommany) would seem to have inhabited the twin town of Akyi Takyi, in view of the fact that the Dutch who followed the Portuguese on the Costa da Mina built a fort there in 1688, which was referred to as Kommenda. 4 Today Dutch Kommenda is the capital of Kommenda, a small state independant of Eguafo; a Kommany or Kommenda state did not exist in Portuguese times.' [544] 'On the other hand the patrilineal Afutu from the kingdom bordering Eguafo in the east did not appear to have lived in the ‘town of two parts’ but in a village of their own close by on land granted to them by the Eguafohene seeing that they were involved in a landlord relationship with the Portuguese. 5 The Afutu, like the Eguafo, came ultimately from Bono ‘in Mossi’ but their government language' was Guan in contrast to Eguafo where ‘Bono Twi’ was the chief language spoken.' [545] 'Eustache de la Fosse, who visited Amankwakurom two years before the fort was built, mentioned ‘the mansa and caramansa who are the king and viceroy’. 6 [Page 79] Mansa is the Mande (Manding) word for ‘king’ or ‘chief’ and the mansa was, there can be no doubt, the king of Eguafo, and the caramansa probably the local chief of the Kara Dyula who acted here as okyeame or royal spokesman. (In the past, an Akan king did not speak in public, the okyeame spoke for him). Eustache de la Fosse who saw only how prominent he was, believed him to be the viceroy, a mistake which was not rectified in view of the difficulty of explaining the institution of spokesman as there was no such official in Europe.' [546] 'From Portuguese records it is clear that Mande, Kara and Kamara Dyula, were already trading on the coast when the Portuguese arrived. They probably settled shortly after the founding of Amankwakurom and Akyi Takyi in order to capture the trade with the ‘French’. They must have heard about them, if not in Bono-Manso, then from the Wasa who owned the rich goldfields to the northwest of Eguafo when they visited them to buy gold (see below in the text). There is also good reason to believe that the founders of Wasa, like the Kara and Kamara Dyula, were from Mande, and may have become refugees and immigrants at the same time as the Begho Kara and Kamara Dyula.' [547] 'The next in importance to receive gifts from the Portuguese was the (o)Xarife who, it is evident from the documents, was neither a king nor a chief. Adu Boahen, the Ghanaian historian, interprets Xarife as the personal Twi name ‘Asirife’. 8 But if that is the case then it is not ‘Asirife’ but ‘Asiriba’ and she was the reigning queen(mother) of a state founded by her, which only received its name, Akyerekyere, in the time of her third successor. The so-called Xarife's road ran right through her country, apart from its southem part, which was in the hands of her ally the Asebu, or Sabu, as the Portuguese called them. These people had conquered the Etsi towns along this road (which continued the road through Asebu from the coast) and the Aberem people who lived to the north of Etsi. The Portuguese called their kingdom Aberemu and its king also received gifts. At Prasu (the modern name), or near by, the Pra river had to be crossed to get into Asiriba's domain. The road then went as far north as Fomase (about thirty miles south of Kumasi), the capital of her state where she resided; it was a great meeting place of traders from Bono-Manso and various places in the Sudan, and the coastal people, who exchanged their goods there.' [548] 'It is interesting to note that a Portuguese in alliance with the ‘King of Futu’, attempted to open a trade road to the interior (apparently to Accany to quote McCall, p. 11), but had neglected to get permission from the ‘King of Sabu’. However, a footpath already existed from Afutu to Kum-Kunso, the capital [Page 80] of Akumu-Akoto 9 whose people the Portuguese called ‘Acanes’, therefore something different must have been meant by this passage. I would suggest that what the Portuguese wanted to open was an alternative road to the ‘Backlands’ in the interior (to which they referred as sertao, or alternatively mata, which is a term which contrasts with forest, 10 open savannah country must be meant). This road would have by-passed Asiriba's state: no wonder ‘the Xarife was angry’, for she no doubt wished to retain the monopoly of the interior trade. ' [549] 'Among other personages who received gifts were the kings of ‘Futu’ and ‘Sabu’, Afutu's neighbour in the east. Further the king of ‘Asa’ is listed, who was more likely the chief of an Asa-bu town ( bu, the Guan suffix). The king of ‘Ati’ was almost certainly an Etsi king as Ati was the Twi name for the Etsi, his capital was perhaps the Etsi town at the furthest end of the Elmina Lagoon. The king of ‘Ape’ may also have been an Etsi if Ape is identical with Apam in Assin, but the Assin who carried Begho cotton cloth to the coast at the beginning of the seventeenth century 12 were Djomo from Bono-Manso who had settled among the Etsi after 1600, and founded Gomoaman there with its capital Apam on the coast.' [550] 'One could identify Dampine with Dompin in Wasa whose king also received gifts, which is not surprising in view of the fact that the town was situated to the south of modern Tarkwa, in the region of one of the richest gold deposits in Ghana. The Mande name ‘Toom’ for the country situated in the ‘interior of the Costa da Mina’ from which Begho people got their gold was probably Wasa which at that time was a confederation of five towns, or city states, called Wasa Adumntuanum (and from which the name ‘Toom’ seems to be derived. 13 But most of the gold the Portuguese received from the ‘Acanes’, the Akumu-Akoto people. For the very close relationship between the ‘Acanes’ and the Portuguese, see Chapter VIII. ' [551] FANTE AND DJOMO: 'At the beginning of the reign of the second Bonohene Akumfi Ameyaw I (c. 1328-63), Adiaka Fante from the Dya-Mo kingdom came to Bono and left again to settle on the central coast. There they founded the Abuka state with Kwaman as capital, built near a pool not far from Afutu and later, founded another Kwaman on the sea close to the present Saltpond. 1 When the Portuguese came to trade they called this town ‘Fante Pequena’, or ‘Little Fante’, to distinguish it from ‘Fante O'Grande’ or ‘Great Fante’, the inland town where the chief resided.' [552] 'At about the same time that the first Fante came to Bono, Nana Okesedu's Asona people, refugees from the Timbuktu region, arrived in Bono-Manso and founded a quarter there. 3 They left centuries later, together with some Djomo, Anana clan people and the so-called Adminadze Fante, during the period that chaos reigned in Bono following the war with the Mande (in the 1590s). [Page 88] Wandering southwards they stopped, before reaching the sea, at Akerakurom, an Etsi town, and seeing that the Etsi spoke a language resembling Bono Twi, ‘but a bit lighter’, the immigrants built their town Mankesim next to the Etsi's town on the northern side.' [553] 'After a time a quarrel arose between the Asona, Djomo and Anana people and the Fante, which resulted in the emigration of the Fante chief Kwanza who took the majority of his people and founded Ekumfi south of Mankesim on the sea. Shortly after most of those remaining at Mankesim also left when they discovered that their region was swampy and unhealthy. The Asona and Djomo, going deeper into Etsi country, founded Gomoaman-Djomo-na-man—which means ‘Djomo descendants' state’. 4 The capital Apam was built next to a Ga fishing village and the Etsi town Akeran (Akron on European maps).' [554] 'The Anana clan people, led by Enoo, on the other hand, settled further west of Ekumfi about a mile east of the Etsi town Egya. However, dissatisfied with the site they moved to the Nmambo, or ‘Bird Rock’, close to the Etsi town of Onyinatsiadze and the pool Kakewua in which the Etsi kept their sacred fish and which contained sweet water. Here the land was fertile. The name Anamabu, or Anomabu, is said to be derived from A-Nmambo. Enoo married an Etsi princess by name Nkadias Nkyigyase. 6 Intermarriage between the Anana and the Etsi must have been the rule, since a praise name for the Anomabu people at gatherings is to this day ‘Nsuano Etsi’, or ‘Etsi by the water’. ' [555] 'I was told at Anomabu that the founders of the town spoke Bono Twi, but, according to a Dutch map of 1629, Anomabu was situated in the Fantijn' kingdom. This suggests that in 1629 Anomabu was dominated by Fante and therefore some event must have occurred about which Anomabu tradition is silent. At Eguafo, however, the Fante invasion led by chief Abu Takyi who made himself king is remembered with horror. He was an evil and selfish ruler who killed people mercilessly and, to enrich himself, engaged in slave trading with the Dutch. Finally the Eguafo helped by the Portuguese at Elmina Castle drove out the Fante and captured Abu Takyi who was ‘deported’ by the Portuguese as a ‘slave’. 8 The remnants of his people, it appears, moved on to Anomabu and the two adjacent Fante states—Abuka and Ekumfi—where they established the ‘Fantijn kingdom’ mentioned on the map of 1629.' [556] 'As far as I know no tradition exists which says that these conquering Fante [Page 89] came from either the Mossi region, Gonja or Bono, so that taking various factors into account, they may have come from the same kingdom in the Ivory Coast (suggested by the name Takyi) from where the ancestors of Takyi, or Takyi Firi, the founder of Tekyiman came. It is possible that they were the warriors who are said to have brought royal Fante women and children to safety in Bono-Manso from an area threatened by war (probably the upheavals caused by the Moorish invasion of the Niger bend in the 1590s). The women and children were allowed to stay but not the warriors who refused to retum and presumably went to the coast.' [557] 'After the collapse of the Bono kingdom in 1722/3 the so-called Bore-Bore Fante left Tekyiman. They were Adiaka-Mo by origin and their ancestors must have been among the founders of Bore, or Bole, because the Tekyiman refer to them as Borefo, that is ‘Bole people’ to distinguish them from the Fante from the west, the founders of Tekyiman. The Bore-Bore Fante, according to their tradition, were led south by three priests: Obunumankoma, Dapagyan and Esuon (or Osono), all of whom died on the road, unable to endure the hardship of walking well over three hundred miles. After Esuon's death and following his advice, a bold and courageous man was chosen as chief. When the people finally reached Mankesim, they buried the bones of the three priests in a sacred grove, which came to be known as Nanampow (Nana-mpomu). ' [558] 'In Tekyiman it is still remembered that the Bore-Bore Fante left led by ‘fetish priests’, although their names are not those cited above. Obunumankoma, or Bruma Ankoma, was the heir-apparent and co-ruler of a Bonohene who ruled in the queenmother Akua Gyamfiwaa's time (c. 1643-56), and when he failed to be elected king (Akumfi Ameyaw II succeeded) emigrated with the two chiefs, the Asonahene Dapagyan and the Ananahene Osono, and others who supported his cause. They settled at Mankesim and when they died were buried in a sacred grove where their names were remembered in libations and offerings. The bones of the three priests were also buried there but their names were forgotten in time and replaced by the former far more important persons.' [559] DENKYIRA: 'Akyerekyere prospered and more and more people came to settle there. The first large groups of immigrants were Aduana clan people. They were given land [Page 121] where Akrokeri is situated now and on it built a town called after their chief Nyankumadu Akotene. They also received supplies and generous assistance in the building of their houses from the Akyerekyere who had not forgotten that in the past their ancestors, when they came as refugees to Kong, had been greatly helped by the Aduana people there.' [560] 'Asare Niansa in time was succeeded by Asare Mansa of whom nothing is remembered, and he by Asare Bediako in whose reign the Agona clan people came to settle and, less than a century later, were to wrest power from the Asakyiri and rename the state Denkyira. They were originally emigrants, or refugees, from somewhere in Mande 5 and arrived in Bono-Manso during the middle of the sixteenth century. There the Agona were created a sub-clan of the Anana, totem the parrot, which to this day is the totem of the Denkyira Agona. About 1580, as one can deduce, a group split off, led by their queenmother Ayekeraa and her elder Ansa Kwansagyan, and went to Akyerekyere to apply for land. Their request was granted, and about three miles from Fomase they founded their town Ntutumbe-Apeanyiase.' [561] 'Asare Bediako was succeeded by Asare Butuo and he by Asare Kumi Anini. The latter is remembered for having introduced amanbehwe drumming, now called atopre. He transferred the capital from Fomase to a sparsely occupied area in the south-west, where he founded Adaboie at the junction of the Oda and Ofin rivers (near modern Atowaase) for reasons no longer remembered.' [562] 'In the reign of the next king, Asare Minten, Bona Nkoran people, Beretuo clan people and, towards its end, Asine clan people, arrived in Akyerekyere to settle. The Bona Nkoran were warriors led by general Agyeman Musu and his brother Aboagye Agyem, both of the royal Bona Ayoko clan who, having been defeated in a war, did not dare to go home. They founded Mamponten and Adubiase (near modern Obuasi), but soon a serious quarrel broke out which led to a war in which the Bona Nkoran were defeated. The Akyerekyere pursued them as far as Begoro in Akyem; three hundred prisoners were taken back and settled at Abusu where Asare Minten's son Ntiamoa Amankua was placed in charge of them. It was their fate, and that of their descendants, to be the victims of human sacrifice. At the death of each Akyerekyere king about one hundred of them were killed, their bodies forming a platform for the body of the dead king. Their blood was mixed with ntumu (ochre) and used to mark the funeral designs of the faces and bodies of the mourners. Those Bona Nkoran who evaded capture founded Okakum in Akyim. From that time onwards no Bona Nkoran, or Ayoko clan people, were given permission to settle in the country.' [563] 'Shortly afterwards Beretuo clan people reached Fomase from a country situated in a mountainous region in the north. 6 Their leaders were two princesses, Akusiase Agosum and her sister Asiama Nyame, and two elders of their family, Tutu Kwa and Antwi Kurufa Deaduam. They founded Ayaase, which Asiama Nyame left later with some people to found the village Kukubiase, three miles away, which became known as Ahensan. Seeing that other towns and villages were ruled by chiefs and the office of queenmother-chief was unknown, Akusiase Agosum made Antwi Kurufa Deadum, the first chief of Ayaase. He was succeeded by the other elder Tutu Kwa and he in turn by Aowi Ofori, Baobaeadum, Bosompim Boabae and Apianini Keramo who ruled when the Denkyira kingdom had already been established.' [564] 'At Ahensan Asiama Nyame was succeeded as chief by her elder and relative Safo Agyeman. She had three daughters, Asum Abena who succeeded her as queenmother, Aberewa Kobo and Amoa Awusi.' [565] 'On their arrival the Beretuo built their traditional round thatched huts, with designs on the outside, four huts forming a compound. During the reigns of their first chiefs at Ayaase and Ahensan they changed to building rectangular houses like those of the Akyerekyere. Their bosom, or god, had its shrine in a stone taken from the Ahomfua river.' [566] 'The original home of the Asine clan people was the country where the bewua bead was carved out of a black stone streaked with white (Upper Volta region, Mossi). They came ‘out of the ground’ near Nsansee in a region now called Asante-Akyim, at that time it was Akyim-Fosu. They founded Peminease nearby but, being too many for the land, one group split off and founded Amakum (in the Kumasi region) and another moved into Akyerekyere and founded Kotobumu two miles from Dompoase. Their leaders were the chief Atirakeram and his sisters Twiwampaadu and Asirifa. The princess Twimasiwa became the first queenmother of Kotobumu and married the Asakyiri chief Akwae of the neighbouring town Kusa. Their son was Obiri Agyei who succeeded Atirakeram. The princess Akramoa Sikye of Denyase, another town the Asine had founded, married king Asare Minten and their son was Ewurade Basa who became the founder of the Adanse state.' [567] 'Tabiri Agyei lived four years at Kotobumu and then moved two miles with his people to found Dompoase on the trade road from Ogua (Cape Coast) to Fomase. The Asona chief Berenkante objected to this, as did Gyan Bibi Beposo, the chief of nearby Kukuruantumi, which resulted in a war during which both chiefs were defeated by Tabiri Agyei. Ofori Panyin, a brother of Berankante, thereupon emigrated with a number of people into eastern Akyim where they founded Kyibi [Page 123] which is now the capital of the Akyim-Abuakwa state.' [568] 'By that time the Asine ruled a number of towns founded by them apart from their capital Dompoase, Denyiase, Dwerebon, Asiribi, Bosompin Twiadwan, Adwendease and Apunpungya which was inhabited largely by Wasa people. 8 The Asine built round huts at first but before long constructed rectangular houses like all their neighbours. Their towns had four quarters and there were two main roads leading from north to south and east to west; the chief's house was situated on the north-south main road, its gate facing west, but they were forced to change it so that it faced east. 9 Their chiefs and queenmother's stool was the round puduo.' [569] 'Under Asare Minten's successor, Oti Bereku Asare, the Agona clan people who had wanted power for a long time became active. Their elder Kwansagyan had meanwhile died and was succeeded by Yao Awirre, the husband of their queenmother Ayekeraa, and he by his brother Boadii Anim. Towards the end of her reign Ayekeraa enstooled her son, Anim Kokobo, as first chief. His ambitious successor swore to make himself king but he died soon and his brother Ahi, next on the stool, also had a short reign. His nephew Mumuromfi, the son of Ayekeraa's daughter, vigorous and young, like his uncle swore at his installation ceremony to wrest power from the Asakyiri kings and immediately set about implementing his oath. He consulted a famous priest who advised him to transfer his capital from its present site near Fomase to the Oda river in the south-west, from which he could more easily attack Adaboie further down the river. This was done and Ntibanso became the chief Agona town.' [570] 'At an auspicious moment Mumuromfi with his warriors marched on Adaboie and defeated Akyerekyere in eight days. Adaboie was razed to the ground and their precious bead stool, the Abakandwa, fell into the hands of the Agona. The iron blade of the Afena Kwao, the Sword of Rule, was captured, but the swordbearer was able to hold on to the handle, an incident which, people today claim, symbolized a division of power. In practical terms, however, Akyerekyere became a vassal state, much reduced in territory, of the newly created Denkyira kingdom. Mumuromfi, its first king, took the name of Werempe Ampem; the date for the event has not been established with certainty but it may well have been about 1630. The capital became Abankesieso, ‘Great Palace’, and was situated roughly where Obuasi is today.' [571] 'Oti Bereku was succeeded by Ohene Adu Asare who rebuilt Adaboie. Either in his short reign or in that of Asirifi Dankwamoa, Konna clan people came to settle. They do not remember where their ancestors came from but their brothers, from whom they split off, the Asokore-Konna, still remember that their country [Page 124] of origin was situated ‘behind Fulaniland’ (the Massina kingdom in the Niger bend). They came ‘out of the ground’ at Bugyeikurom near Kokofu (Kumase-Bekwai region). The chief who took them south from there was Ntiri Apao; their head-woman was Buntua. After they had founded Minim, Buntua married the Asine chief Akora Furupa of near-by Dompoase. Conscious of the advantage of being situated along the trade road, they soon moved two miles and founded Fomena. Other Konna towns were Mbetemano and Ahimaso. At Monsea the Konna lived together with Aduana, Agona and Asakyiri. Their national obosom was Bonsam, later adopted by the Ashanti, who had his shrine at Atakro.' [572] 'The Konna were followed by Beretuo clan people from Tena in the far north, led by their queenmother-chief Aso Dagyiwa. They went mainly to Ahensan to settle and took the name Tena to dintinguish themselves from their clan brothers; their descendants claim that they did not intermarry and always considered themselves as one blood.' [573] 'Asirifa Dankwamoa of Akyerekyere had no heir and hence was succeeded by Ewurade Basa, the son of Asare Minten and the Asine princess Akromoa Sikye. Ewurade Basa's aim was to regain some power that had been lost to Denkyira. He had the ‘Sword of Rule’ repaired and took it, together with all his father's possessions, to his mother's town Konokurom. He then named what remained of Akyerekyere ‘Adanse’, meaning ‘The Beginning of Change’, and Konokurom, the capital, he called Adansemanso. At Fomase he put his uncle Ponko Biri in charge as governor and he was later succeeded by Abu Koko.' [574] 'The Denkyirahene Werempe Ampem was succeeded by Boadu Akafu Berempon (Akofo Biaka). According to Ayaase tradition he cut off the beard of Apia Berenya, the son of the Beretuo chief Apianini Keramo of Ayaase, when he heard that Apia Berenya had offended a Denkyira princess. This affair resulted in a war which the Ayaase lost.' [575] 'Another affair nearly caused war with Denkyira. Boadu Akafu Berempon was married to an Asakyiri princess Berebere, who was the queenmother of Odumase. As she seemed unable to give him a child, he sent her, protected by Obeng Entwi with thirty gunners, to the Bonda god at Bondatifi to offer prayers and sacrifices. From there the party went to Fomena after Obeng Entwi discovered that the Konna chief there was a relative of his. Berebere became pregnant by Obeng Entwi and, being afraid to return home, they stayed on. When the Denkyirahene heard about this he ordered the guilty couple to appear in court before Apianini Kaframoa, the half-brother of Ewurade Basa and whose mother was a Beretuo of Ayaase. Apianini Kaframoa, deeply afraid, immediately sacrificed thirty-two people, [Page 125] but did nothing about the case he was to conduct. The Denkyirahene, enraged, sent his okyeame with executioners to Fomena, and Obeng Entwi was killed on the spot. Berebere was brought back to the capital and beheaded. This was regarded in Adanse as a terrible crime because of the taboo that royal blood must never be spilt. The Adanse now feared that Denkyira would declare war on them, which was also anticipated by the Kwamanhene (chief of Kumasi) Obiri Yeboa, whose state was situated to the north of Adanse and who offered help. But Ewurade Basa, no doubt thinking about the recent defeat of the Ayaase people by Denkyira in the Apia Berenya affair, declined.' [576] 'Boadu Akafu Berempon was succeeded by Boa Amponsem (Boa Siante) and some time after a war broke out between the Kwamanhene Obiri Yeboa and Adanse. The war was caused by a misunderstanding: Obiri Yeboa had sent a messenger to Ayaase to get the magical drum of the god Ntoa of which Apianini Kaframoa was in charge, because it was reputed that when drummed facing the enemy it would cause his defeat. The message was never delivered and Obiri Yeboa, urged on by his wife Ampobeng to fight for the drum as she bore a grudge against Ponko Biri governor of Fomase, invaded Adanse. However, Ponko Biri who expected war and was prepared for it, defeated the Kwaman warriors before they reached Ayaase and pursued them to Banda. Since this was neutral territory, the war came to a standstill.' [577] 'At that moment Ampabene, the Asine chief of Denyase, committed treachery. He hated Ewurade Basa for something which had happened in the past 12 and offered to help Obiri Yeboa to win the war, demanding the post of Korontihene in the Kwaman state as his reward. The Kwamanhene agreed and sent his a metal wristlet to conclude the deal. The Denyasehene then spread the rumours among the Adanse warriors that the Denkyira were attacking them from the rear, killing their women and children. Ponko Biri did not believe this, but the warriors mutinied and went home. Apianini Kaframoa, then an old man, threw himself among the troops and seized the ‘Sword of Power’ and the drum of Ntoa. This he brought with a handful of faithful to Dyuman in Bono where it was nailed to the ground in the temple of the god. 13 Ponko Biri and all those who had remained with him were taken prisoner and Ewurade Basa, broken-hearted, died soon after. Apia Kaframoa who returned from Dyuman with the ‘Sword of Power’ hoped to succeed him but, since he was considered too old, Akora Furupa, the Asine chief of Dompoase was elected Adansehene. He left the ill-fated Adansemanso and took all the royal paraphenalia to his wife's town, Fomena, which he made the capital [Page 126] of the Adanse state.' [578] 'In 1700 a war broke out between Osei Tutu, the successor of Obiri Yeboa at Kwaman and Ntim Gyakari of Denkyira, who had succeeded Boa Amponsem in 1692. Many of the Ayaase people left Adanse and settled at Otwereso in Akyim. In the following year Osei Tutu defeated Denkyira and created the Ashanti kingdom; thus Adanse came under the overlordship of Ashanti.' [579] 'The Adansehene Akora Furupa had decided to be neutral in this war and emigrated with his people also to Akyim, the name of the village was not mentioned by my informants. There he joined his father, the Konna chief Bonsera who had hidden there suffering from leprosy. After the war Akora Furupa and his people wished to return to Adanse and having received permission from Osei Tutu, settled at Maniase near Kusa (or Twisa) in Adanse where they remained until Opoku Ware had succeeded Osei Tutu. They then wished to return to Fomena, but meanwhile Akora Furupa's son Abu Bonsera had become Adansehene—his mother had been head-woman Buntua—and so they settled in Minataase. Their descendants at a later date went to Adwenase and to Akrokeri about 1900 when the railway was built. The Akrokeri chief was of the Asakyiri clan and of the family of the founders of Akyerkyere.' [580] 'According to tradition Adanse is the cradle of the Akan peoples for many clans and founders of states trace their origin to Adanse which is said to be the place ‘where God first began the creation of the world’. The tradition recorded above, however, gives an entirely different impression. To sum up:' [581] 'The Asakyiri and Asona clan people came from Kankyeabo (Ivory Coast), the Ayoko-Nkoran from Bona (Ivory Coast) and the Aduana from Kumbu (Ivory Coast). Agona came also from somewhere in the Ivory Coast and Asine came from western Gonja via Akyim; the Konna from ‘behind Fulaniland’ in the Niger bend region, and the Beretuo and Tena from a mountainous country probably situated between the Niger and Upper Black Volta river (Bandiagara). All these people were members of long-established matri-clans, of which the Asakyiri, Asona and Beretuo were among the founders of Bono ‘in Mossi’ and the second Bono kingdom; Agona, Asine and Konna settled in Bono-Manso during the sixteenth century; Kumbu Aduana before 1500 and Gyaman Aduana after 1650.' [582] 'Asakyiri clan people founded the Akyerekyere kingdom and the Agona the Denkyira before Adanse was established on the remains of Akyerekyere. Adanse from the beginning was a vassal state of Denkyira, and after the defeat of Denkyira by Osei Tutu, it came under the overlordship of Ashanti. It is not surprising therefore that Bosman whose book was published in 1705, and Barbot in 1732, were silent [Page 127] about Adanse, which L. Y. Daaku (1966:11) finds ‘particularly strange’ as ‘Adanse was the leading power in the interior’. It was not and never had been.' [583] 'As for the migrations from Adanse: The Bona Nkoran, defeated in war, were the first to leave Akyerekyere to settle in Okakum in Akyim, except for those who were taken back as prisoners. Five Asona groups emigrated from Kokobeante between roughly 1650 and 1700 and settled largely in Kyibi in Akyim. Ofori Panyin, the leader of the first major group is worshipped now as the ancestor of the kings of the Akyim-Abuakwa state. Aduana clan people from Nyankumadu Akotene, led by Otumfi Bi, left about 1600 and founded the village Asafo which is now a quarter of Kumasi. He laid the foundation for the Kwaman (Kumasi) state. There is indirect evidence that the Aduana who founded the small Asumegya state after Asantemanso ceased to exist, came from the Akyerekyere kingdom. The Kumawu state was founded by Akwamu Aduana who, after the destruction of Asantemanso, had settled for a short time in Ahensan in Adanse, but it was not their original home.' [584] 'Ewurade Basa of the Asine clan founded the Adanse state about 1650; Asine clan people from Adanse did not found Amakum, as seems to be generally believed, but joined their brothers in Amakum after the war with the Kwamanhene Obiri Yeboa which they lost. Others joined brothers in the Wenkyi state and the Anyima-Asine in Bono.' [585] 'The Beretuo and Tena clan people left Adanse largely owing to heavy taxation and other frustrations, and finally founded the Mampong state and the Tena the Kwahu state at Abene. Much earlier Beretuo clan people went to Kwaman town where Kerabo Antowaa became the state's first queenmother and enstooled Kwabea Amenfi, the successor of Otumfi Bi. Her grandson Adu Gyamfi became regent of Kwaman before Osei Tutu was elected Kwamanhene. He owned the whole region known as Kwabere and his successor Oberefi Kese founded about 1750 Jamasi as part of the Mampong state.' [586] 'If all these factors are taken into account, it is clear that the migrations of the Adanse people in the late seventeenth century to the regions east and northeast of Kumasi, were not due to disputes concerning land, nor to the desire to secure better opportunities for trading, but simply to the unsettled conditions created by the overlordship of Denkyira.' [587] 'It is generally held that the kinship organisation of the Adanse people was patrilineal and that they adopted a matrilineal system only after 1700 in the reign of Abu Bonsera of the Konna dynasty. This belief is equally erroneous since all the people belonged to old, well established matri-clans. The reason for this misunderstanding [Page 128] is, no doubt, that Ewurade Basa succeeded by virtue of being a son of the Akyerekyere king Asare Minten; however, at a time when there was no legitimate heir. A similar situation arose previously at the death of the queenmother Asiriba Gyehenewa, the founder of the state, and the succession passed to a son of her husband, the co-founder. Moreover, Ewurade Basa was succeeded, not by a prince of his royal lineage but by Akura Furupa. Their relationship is not clear except that both ruled Asine towns. Again owing to the unfavourable political situation at the time, Akora Furupa was not succeeded by a prince of his own Asine lineage, but by his son Abu Bonsera whose mother was of the Konna clan. Since then the Konna royal lineage has been the dominant one. Abu Bonsera reestablished matrilineal succession in the Adanse royal house when the state came under the suzereignty of Ashanti and peace and order were restored.' [588] AKWAMU: 'The heir-apparent Otumfo Asare, as mentioned already, left Kum-Kunso with his followers after his unseccessful attempt to become king, and went first with his people to Abacrampa in Fante. There they decided to settle in Akyim (‘Great Akan’) neighbouring Akyerekyere in the east, and were given land some forty miles or so north of Winneba on the coast. They founded Asaremankese as the capital of a city state called Akumu after Akumu-Akoto, a name which the Dutch corrupted to Aquamboe, today it is Akwamu. 1 Many villages came into existence at the same time—Tafo, Apeda, Apapam, Akyim-Asafo, Akyim-Kwaman and Mbease. In the reign of their second king, Akotia I, the capital was transferred to the top of a neighbouring hill where Otumfi Asare had built a few houses for members of his family.' [589] 'There are grounds for dating the founding of Akwamu at about 1550; in 1515, according to Portuguese records, the Nzima invasion took place ‘at the back of Elmina’ in the times of Ofusu Kwabi of Akumu-Akoto. He was succeeded by Oduro and Adu and during the latter's reign Otumfo Asare left Kum-Kunso. Otumfo Asare, in turn, was succeded in Akwamu by Akotia I and Ansa Sasraku I, who must have died a few years before 1600 as can be calculated from the exodus of the Domaa. Thus the date for the foundation of Akwamu was some time in the mid-sixteenth century.' [590] 'Nothing is known of the country's early history, nor is there any memory of the stool dispute which followed Ansa Sasraku's death and had as a sequel the emigration of the queenmother Nkansa who became the founder of the Domaa-Asantemanso state. She first founded Anwanwiniso (Anwanwereso) on Ga territory, some miles to the south-east of Asaremankese (near the modern Nsawam) but abandoned the town after a defeat by the Ga. The Asaremankese people immediately moved in and subjugated the Ga in a war in which Anwanwiniso was probably destroyed, [Page 138] unless it was destroyed in the previous war for they founded Anyandawaase (Nyanoase) close by as a new capital of their state. The Akwamu now had a foothold outside Akyim and were able to attack it, and create an independent state which included roughly the whole Akwatia-Nsawam region. A Domaa elder at Pamu told me in 1946 that at Anwanwiniso his ancestors ‘became Akwamu’, by which he meant that until then they had lived peacefully at Asaremankese, but once free of Akyim they could start on their famous conquests.' [591] 'On the Dutch map of 1629 a small ‘Aquamboe’ is situated to the south-east of the powerful ‘Akim, Great Accanij’. This Akyim is not to be confused with Akyim-Abuakwa, a state also founded on Akyim territory (about 1650) bordering on Akwamu to the north-east, and which, in 1730, played an important role in the downfall of Akwamu.' [592] 'The rise of Akwamu to become a great and wealthy kingdom has been described in detail by Wilks, The Rise of the Akwamu Empire, 3 and need not be repeated here. One conquest followed another, starting perhaps with the Akyim-Abuakwa region, date unknown. The Guan of Late and Kyerekpon came under the control of the Akwamu in 1646. Between 1677 and 1681 the important Accra kingdom of the Ga was incorporated and the adjacent Ladoku was reduced to a dependancy. The same fate befell Agona in 1689, and about twenty years later Kwahu in the north, not to mention conquests on the other side of the Volta river.' [593] 'By the end of the seventeenth century Akwamu equalled Denkyira in power, they dominated the forest region. But in 1701 Denkyira ceased to exist and in 1730 Akwamu also fell; since 1701 Ashanti was the rising power. The downfall of Akwamu was due to a rebellion of their vassals, assisted by neighbouring states; the surviving remnants of the Akwamu withdrew across the Volta river on the far side of which they established another Akwamu. The defeated warriors, on the other hand, went westwards and carved out of the Wasa kingdom a state of their own called Wasa-Amenfi.' [594] AKYIM ‘GREAT AKAN’, AKYIM-ABUAKWA, AKYIM-KOTOKO AND AKYIM-BOSOME: 'One of the most important kingdoms on the Dutch map of 1629 is ‘Akyim, Great Accanij’; its people are described as ‘very delicate and rich in slaves’. Very little is known about it. According to Reindorf (1966, App. C) its capital was at Akyim-Manso and the state had a Kuntunkrunku dynasty which is said to have had twelve kings although he wrongly attributes these to Akyim-Abuakwa. We also know that the eastern part of Akyim became a vassal of Akwamu, and that the western part, Akyim-Fosu, ceased to exist as a state in 1700 when, as an ally of Denkyira, it suffered a terrible defeat at the hands of Osei Tutu. According to Bosman (1907:76) 30,000 warriors were killed in battle. After the foundation of Ashanti in 1701 it became a province of the Kumasi state and is now known as Asante-Akyim.' [595] 'As one roughly calculates five or six kings to have ruled during one century, Akyim ‘Great Akan’ must have been founded about 1500, at about the same time as Akyerekyere and Akumo-Akoto. I assume that the Twi-speaking founders were Kumbu Akan who moved south from ‘Dwenemu’ via Bono-Manso to settle in the eastern part of the forest. However, if one could trace the town or village where descendants of the old Akyim royal lineage still live, the traditions should still exist there, and could throw light on the foundation of the kingdom and could also tell us from where their ancestors came.' [596] 'Akyim ‘Great Akan’ is now forgotten because Akyim-Abuakwa has taken its place. This was founded at Kyibi as a small state in eastern Akyim by Ofori Atta and his followers from Kokobeante in Adanse after the defeat of their chief Berankante in a war with the neighbouring Dompoase people. ' [597] 'In the course of some fifty years four more Asona groups from Kokobeante came to join their clan brothers in Kyibi. The last group to arrive there were refugees who had left Kokobeante in the time of the Denkyirahene Ntim Gyakari (1692-1701), and had settled first at Yentereso (now called Banso) in Akyim-Fosu, whence they fled to Kyibi when Osei Tutu attacked this state and destroyed it.' [598] 'Kyibi, meaning ‘Kyi people’, 3 appears in seventeenth century records as ‘Oquie or Oqi’. The title of the Akyim-Abuakwa kings is still ‘Okyihene’ which, Nana Ofori Atta II explained to me, has the significance of ‘king’ (hene) of the cultured and civilized’, qualities which are usually attributed to the Twi of which Kyi is an older form. 4 The Kokobeante Asona were Twi-speaking Akan, there can be [Page 140] little doubt therefore that Kyi here is Twi.' [599] 'The Kyibi people insisted that Kyibi was founded in Akyim, the overlordship of Akwamu must therefore have been established after the foundation of the town (about 1640). It came to an end in 1730 when Kyibi rebelled and assisted by allies, defeated and ousted the Akwamu.' [600] 'Today there are three Akyim states, apart from the Akyim-Abuakwa, Akyim-Kotoko and Akyim-Bosome. All these states are said by Reindorf (1964:95) and others to have fought in the war against Akwamu which is correct, but as we know from the traditions of the last-named two states they did not exist at that time in Akyim which is never pointed out; Kotoko was still a state in Kwahu and so was the ancestral state of the Akyim-Bosome people called Bokuruwa Nkatia.' [601] 'The historical background of these two Kwahu states is as follows: Okyere, co-ruler and heir-apparent of the Denkyirahene (most likely Boadu Akafo Berempon) was rejected as king after the latter's death. Feeling, no doubt, humiliated, he emigrated together with his brother Amponsem and others who had supported his cause. They went to Mmeraem in Adanse where they lived for some years, but when a war between Adanse and Akyim-Fosu broke out, they refused to fight on behalf of Adanse and left. 5 Fighting their way through to Ahuren to join brothers, they met the Asamanhene Gyima, his brothers, sons and followers. They were likewise looking for a place of refuge, after their defeat by Nti Koko, ‘King of Lake Bosomtwi’, in the area between Ahantaase and Waase. ' [602] 'Arrived at Ahuren, situated a few miles south east of Kumasi, the two princes were welcomed by their Agona clan brothers and given land on which Okyere, the former co-ruler, founded Amansu (Swedru) about five miles from Ahuren, while Amponsem founded the Oda quarter in Ahuren.' [603] 'Some twenty years or so later, during the reign of the Denkyirahene Ntim Gyakari, a civil war broke out in Ahuren following an event during the funeral ceremonies for the Ahurenhene Oti Awere. The successors of the two Denkyira princes, Friempon Mansu and Osei Twum, left and settled at Kwahu. 8 After a few years Friempon Mansu made himself king at Dampong, the capital of the small but not unimportant Kotoko state. Osei Twum with his people went to Anweam in the Agogo region where he died. 9 His successor Kwaw Baadu moved a few miles further east and settled at Bokuruwa Nkatia. In 1710 the Akwamu attacked the various Kwahu peoples who became vassals of Akwamu, 10 but in 1730 they rebelled together with the Kyibi people and their allies, and the Akwamu suffered total defeat.' [604] 'Not long after the Kotoku people were defeated by Opoku Ware and fled to Fosu in Asante-Akyim and from there went to Kyibi in the Akyim-Abuakwa state. 11 There they were given land on which they founded the Akyim-Kotoko state. The defeated Borukuwa-Nkwatia people fled at the time to Ankaase (the one on the Kumasi-Denkyira road?) but were driven out of there by the Ashanti in 1818. They also moved into the Akyim-Abuakwa state and were given land near Aduasa, on which they founded the small Akyim-Bosome state. Their descendants to this day pay as tribute to the chief of Aduasa parts of the profits from the land of Akyim-Bosome. 12 But they also have lands of their own, see M.J. Field (1948:10).' [605]

Limits on Power of the Chief Executive[edit]

Legal (formal) limits[edit]

♠ Executive power is separate or independent from military ♣ absent ♥ The following refers to the Ashanti period. While the Ashanti infantry mostly consisted of citizen-soldiers who were not specialists in their own right, there was also a nucleus of armed professionals not disbanded during times of peace: 'The local government of Kumasi was in the hands of the Kwaintsirs, a body of men who were the keepers of the golden stool. They formed the Department of War, and the great General Amankwatsia was formerly their Chief. The fact that the Department of War held in its keeping the royal stool illustrates vividly the origin of the kingly office in the Native State, which will be explained later on.' [606] During annual military drills, armed commoners gathered in the capital, where they paraded through the streets with specialists: 'Meanwhile the different regiments, under their several Head-Captains, and all commanded by the Captain-General, are preparing to go through their manoeuvres. To avoid disputes, the several regiments parade through the town one after the other, pouring forth thunderous volleys from their long flint Dane guns. After the parade each regiment presents to the King its flags and emblems, new and old, as an act of homage, which the King returns with suitable words. The several Head-Chiefs next renew their allegiance to the King; and, after more dancing and popular rejoicing, thè King retires to his “compound,” where his vassals subsequently take leave of him, each vassal receiving a suitable present.' [607] The King was assisted in his military duties by secondary commanders and generals:'The King is the Chief Military Officer of his forces. In time of war, he directs the operations; and if he is a man of capacity, he has the leading place in the councils of war. There is generally a Tufu Hin, or Captain-General, of the forces; but his authority is subordinate to that of the King, and he is, in every essential, an officer of the King.' [608] Accordingly, executive power was not separate from the military. We have assumed the same to be broadly applicable to the pre-Ashanti period as well.
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from legislative ♣ absent ♥ Writing in the Ashanti period, Arhin describes the power hierarchy from the village upwards. Stool holders were present in council meetings with elders: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [609] Major and minor chiefs were also summoned to council: 'Where the paramount King of a state summons the Head-Chiefs of provinces and chiefs of minor communities to attend a State Council, it is the privilege of the Councillors of the several communities composing the State, according to their rank and importance, to accompany their several Heads to the capital and to join in the “palaver,” or discussion, that will take place, the King in person presiding over the deliberations, supported by his own Councillors and principal Linguists. This is the full Parliament of the people, who are thus fully and duly represented in every way from the highest to the lowest. The commands which go forth from this assembly are binding upon every individual family of the entire State, from the most important province to the most insignificant hamlet, and the sanction operates equally upon all.' [610] The attribution of concrete entities to a particular executive level is not always clear. On the executive level it therefore seems best to go with the stool system: 'Every Asante village was a microcosm of the Asante economic, social, and political universe. Its population included both rulers and ruled, both “owners” of the land with the right of succession to the local, divisional, and state stools and free men grouped in other lineages with corporate interests in other political offices.' [611] Given how executive leaders held seats in councils, we have assumed that there was no separate legislative body in either time period.
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from judiciary ♣ absent ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as 'Executive'. Executive leaders and elders, not full-time professional judges, presided over judicial proceedings: 'The initial processes applicable to civil, oath, accused or criminal summonses have already been described. In order to meet the clerical service required for these forms, there is attached to the important Tribunals a Registrar's office where summonses and all the other processes are taken. The Registrar has charge of the cause list and the Record Books. In Akim Abuakwa the tribunal sits for five days in the week, Wednesday being excluded by the “Awukudae” custom, and Sunday by the British connexion and other Christian influences. Sittings of Tribunal last for about 6 to 10 working hours each day, and the Omanhene, as responsible judge, is always expected to be present throughout the day's sitting. We have already described the constitution of the Tribunal as consisting of the Omanhene, his Linguists, his four principal Executive Chiefs, the Queen-Mother, the non-Stool owning Elders and Councillors (including in the latter term the Christian Elders and Presbyters). The Tribunal is summoned by the “Kantamanto” or “woni-mini” drum ( q.v.) and on the Omanhene taking his seat at the third beating of the drum, the Registrar proceeds to deal with his cause list.' [612] Accordingly, there was no independent judiciary.

Legal (formal) freedoms[edit]

♠ Right to petition executive ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Critique of executive by non-government ♣ ♥

Power distributed[edit]

♠ Sanction of executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by government ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by non-government ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment ♣ present ♥ Chiefs could be destooled when found incompetent or cruel: 'The Ashanti had a constitutional practice which ensured that the will of the people was given consideration. They had ultimately the constitutional right to destool a chief. As the fundamental principle was that only those who elected a chief could destool him, a destoolment required the consent of the elders. Sometimes they initiated a destoolment themselves when, for example, a chief repeatedly rejected their advice, or when he broke a taboo, or committed a sacrilegious act. The kind of offences for which chiefs were destooled may be gathered from the following instances of destoolments recounted in the traditional histories of the Divisions.' [613] 'Chiefs Kwabena Aboagye of Asumegya, Kwabena Bruku, and Kwasi Ten of Nsuta were destooled for drunkenness; Kwame Asonane of Bekwai for being a glutton ( adidifurum); Kwame Asona, also of Bekwai, for dealing in charms and noxious medicines; and Akuamoa Panyin of Juaben for his abusive tongue, and [Page 22] for not following the advice of his elders. In Kokofu, Osei Yaw was destooled for being fond of disclosing the origin of his subjects (i.e. reproaching them with their slave ancestry), and Mensa Bonsu for excessive cruelty.' [614] 'A chief was also destooled if he became blind, or impotent, or suffered from leprosy, madness, or fits, or if his body was maimed in a way that disfigured him.' [615] According to Danquah, destoolments became more common in the colonial period: 'THE terms “enstoolment” and “destoolment” are used in the Gold Coast to indicate, as to enstoolment (1) the customary procedure of electing and installing a member of the stool family as Chief or King of the tribe or nation over which that stool rules, and, as to destoolment, (2) the converse procedure of deposing a reigning Chief or King from his former position as ruler. Owing to the importance attached to the hereditary position of Chief either as Odikro (Chief of a town), or Ohene (Chief of a sub-divisional state), there has (Paramount Chief of an independent state), there has been much litigation in recent times in connexion with disputes on the legality or otherwise of particular Enstoolments or Destoolments, and instances are not wanting of such disputes passing through the African and British Courts in the Colony to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in England.' [616] 'Many are the causes which have given rise to such frequent disputes, but to examine such causes is not the object of this article, our purpose in writing which is more theoretical than practical. Enstoolment used to be a peaceful and dignified procedure. But the frequency of modern disputed elections has changed the peace and dignity which used to attend the ancient mode of making the best men of the tribe King or ruler.' [617] 'Many political theorists versed in the craft have traced the cause of this frequent deposition of Chiefs to the effects of the Native Jurisdiction Ordinances. We are not prepared to deny or accept this view, but we are inclined to think that the present discontent among the mass of the people against the ruling houses must have one cause in the general administration of affairs, and another in the irreconciled differences existing between the old system of government and the form of government which seems to be demanded by the present generation. However much we may admire the Akan institutions, we should not be doing our duty for the effective maintenance of the best that should be preserved in our institutions were we to suffer both Ormuzd and Ahriman [Page 110] to grow strong together. Where an existing order leads to creation of disorder nothing but a reform of the former would lead to a cessation of the latter.' [618] 'We are not, however, concerned in this treatise with debatable political considerations, and having stated a sufficient preamble for the present subject, we proceed to discuss it so far as present limitations will permit.' [619] However, we have assumed that destoolment was possible in the pre-Ashanti period as well, at least in principle.

Customary (informal) checks on executive[edit]

♠ Informal critique of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal sanction of executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal constraint on executive ♣ ♥
♠ Informal impeachment ♣ ♥

Limits on executive power imposed by religious agents[edit]

♠ Critique of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Sanction of executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Constraint on executive by religious institutions ♣ ♥
♠ Impeachment by religious agents ♣ ♥
♠ Subordination of the chief executive to a religious agent ♣ ♥
♠ Motivation by belief in supernatural agent ♣ ♥

Mechanisms of Power Transfer (from one head of state to the next)[edit]

♠ Customary mechanism ♣ ♥
♠ Legal mechanism ♣ present ♥ The Ohemma played an important role in power transitions: 'As the abrewa, the ohemma was also custodian of ‘custom’. She was officially the foremost authority on the genealogy of the royal matrilineage, and hence the first and final arbiter on who was qualified by blood to be a male ruler; it was said of the ohemma's stool in relation to the male stool that it was the elder stool, akonnua panyin. It was the ohemma who played the leading role in the selection of a successor to a deceased or destooled (removed from office) ohene.' [620] But popular consent was also required: 'If a Chief dies, or “goes to his village”, as the untoward incident is euphemistically described, it remains for the family, after the first funeral obsequies to name a successor to the stool. There are usually in every town, about two or three divisions, or “houses” in the ruling Royal family. It does not rest with any one of these “houses” to say whose turn it is to ascend the stool. It is the will of the people which determines what particular member of the Family taken as a whole is most fit to ascend the stool and to rule over them. The question of the choice of a stool candidate by the materfamilias, which will be explained later, is purely a formal ceremony chiefly dependent upon the people's will. For if the initial selection were the absolute privilege of any individual member of the family, no town or tribal stool would be worthy of the name. It is necessary to remember that the people's allegiance to stools are not as subjects of an absolute monarchy, but as citizens of a more or less democratic country, and were it that they had to accept any haphazard choice thrown upon them by the Head of the Royal Family, the popular veto would seem a shadowy thing. We do not say this to disparage the authority of the Heads of families, we say it to demonstrate the principle that the selection by the female head derives its source from the popular will, and this will is always easily known.' [621] Male members of royal matrilineages were eligible for succession: 'In the case of succession to Stool, be it family, town, tribal, or divisional, either a brother (we speak solely of the female line) or a nephew, an uncle, or a grand-uncle, a cousin or an adult member of the Royal Family, can be selected to succeed a dead or destooled Chief; for, no matter how far removed in blood he may be from the out-going Chief, so long as he belongs to the same recognized Royal Family, any member of the Stool family stands the good fortune of being elected. The mere fact of one being in the second or third house places [Page 111] no bar on one's right to ascend the stool. The same blue blood runs in the veins of any member of the family who can be proved to be a direct descendant in the female line of the known materfamilias. Every member of the Royal Family is, as it were, an heir-presumptive. Character and influence, then, are the determining factors. That stool heir must be fortunate who is unsullied in character, influential withal, and respected by all.' [622] 'However, if the heir-apparent—the eldest sister's eldest son—i.e. the nearest nephew—is of good age, of good repute or character as well as rich, there are but two things that stand between him and the stool. One is foul play. He must guard against being played out. The other danger is general or physical health and bodily accomplishments. He must be strong in body and have no personal and bodily defects. His weakness and bodily defects are enough grounds to destroy his candidature. In Akim Abuakwa, for instance, a circumcised person cannot ascend any stool, be it a cottage or town stool. The stools are considered sacred, and a stool aspirant who is circumcised has, by his own act, rendered himself ineligible to ascend a sacred Akan stool.' [623] Danquah describes the process of selecting a successor: 'After the funeral obsequies of a Chief, or the final determination of the deposition of an unwanted Chief, all who must have a voice in the election of the new Chief assemble in the public place at the invitation of the Chief who is Regent ex-officio. Thereupon, the sub-Chiefs, Elders and Councillors of the town, together with the Captains of the Asafo companies, call upon the female head, or in her absence, the male head of the Royal Family, to name a person fit for the stool. The members of the Royal Family would then retire into council with a view to consult on the question of the proper person to be selected for the stool. The Head of the Family is, however, the moving spirit of the whole. On the return of the Head of the Royal Family with her people, she names a suitable candidate for the election. If the nominee is acceptable to the sub-Chiefs, Elders, and Councillors assembled, the name is submitted to the meeting, and the general approval of the Asafo or “Werempi” Company (of young men) obtained. If he is not acceptable, the Asafo or “Werempi” Company would signify their disapproval through their respective captains, and their opinion being in consonance with that of the sub-Chiefs, Elders, and Councillors, [Page 112] the Head of the Royal Family would have to make other suggestions until the proper candidate desired by the people would be nominated and accepted.' [624] 'The accepted candidate is then taken hold of and beaten, as in a “rag”, he is powdered with white clay and carried on the shoulders by the Asafo or Werempi Company from one end of the town to the other, three times, amid an animated outburst of civic and war songs. After this impressive ceremony of public acclamation by the Asafo Company an “Aseda” money would be taken from the elected Chief when he had been made to sit on the election stool. The amount or value of “Aseda” taken on this occasion is calculated on the relative position of the Chief, and not on the Chief's wealth. Drinks are generally offered by the Chief to all the sub-Chiefs and people there and then assembled. Drumming goes on the whole time, and if there are any State paraphernalia they are brought out in the service of the new Chief.' [625] 'But the elected is as yet little more than an ordinary member of the Royal Family. There remains the ceremony of swearing-in, and then the grander and more solemn ceremony of installation. The swearing-in may be done the same, or on the following day. All the minor Chiefs of the new Chief, the sub-Chiefs so-called, hasten to swear in a renewal of their allegiance to the stool, and then the new Chief would swear to them of his unswerving support and assistance to them in the administration of his dominion. The new Chief has also to swear allegiance to the representative of his superior Chief who must be present before any of the above ceremonies are gone through, and the representative would in turn swear on behalf of his over-lord, never to forsake him but to support and uphold him in the service of the country. This swearing to one's superior Chief's representative does not exonerate one from the obligation of swearing allegiance personally [Page 113] to the superior Chief. It is the very first thing to be observed on any proper occasion that such new Chief comes into the presence of his superior Chief. We may here state that in former times it was not the custom for a newly elected Opakani or Chief to make his appearance at the capital town until three years after his election and installation, when such principal Chief had to swear the Oath of Allegiance to the Paramount Stool. It is difficult to trace the reason for this custom, but its very impracticability in modern chieftaincy has gradually brought it into disuse. Probably it was to permit the newly elected chief to perform his own Odwiratuo, grand triennial festival, at the end of his third year, before coming to see his Paramount Chief.' [626] 'In the Stool-house certain ceremonies are done. The new Chief is given his final initiation into the highest part of the great Order in the nation—the most solemn Order of the [Page 114] worship of ancient stools—and the highest honours that any member of the tribe can obtain are there and then poured on him. The impressive and recordable part of the initiation is that of holding the new Chief suspended three times over a black consecrated stool—the oldest and most famous of the collection—and declaring him lord and ruler of his dominions, by the direction and guidance of the spirits of his departed and august ancestors. The ceremony begins and ends with slaughter of sheep. Among other things the Chief who is being installed must observe that it is improper for him to bring his body in contact with the black consecration-stool on which he is thrice suspended, for it is regarded unlucky, and it is said that the unfortunate person who does so, stands the risk of weakening for ever his organs of reproduction. This assumption is based on the belief that the black consecration-stool is a living force, and that its spirit is so strong that actual contact with human beings is sure to produce disastrous results.' [627] 'After this solemn ceremony the new Chief is worthy enough to regard himself as the most elevated person amongst his peers, and he is now endowed with the right and correlative duty to rule and govern his dominions with the advice and counsel of the members of the Administration.' [628] We have assumed this to be broadly applicable to the pre-Ashanti period as well.
♠ Number of power transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of contested transitions ♣ ♥
♠ Number of successful overturns ♣ ♥

Central Bureaucracy[edit]

♠ State-level administrators ♣ absent ♥ The Ashanti period was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [629] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [630] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [631] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [632] In that period, appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [633] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [634] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [635] We have assumed that this process did not predate the Ashanti period. Functionaries and notables that served regional rulers, such as Omanhenes in various Akan states, probably exercised patrimonial rather than bureaucratic authority.

♠ Prestige of state-level bureaucracy ♣ ♥

Authority over state-level administrators

♠ Direct ♣ ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ ♥
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ ♥

Source of Support of state-level officials

♠ State salary ♣ ♥
♠ Governed population ♣ ♥
♠ Land ♣ ♥
♠ None ♣ ♥
