♠ Other ♣ ♥

Pathologies

♠ Corruption ♣ ♥
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥

♠ Professionalization of state-level bureaucracy ♣ ♥

♠ modal number of years state-level bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥

♠ Promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ ♥

♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials to other positions ♣ ♥

♠ Promotion from lower ranks ♣ ♥

♠ Frequency of promotion of state-level officials from lower ranks ♣ ♥

Local-level officials (provincial, regional, civic administration)[edit]

♠ Number of regional administrative units ♣ ♥

♠ Local-level administrators ♣ absent ♥ The Ashanti period was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [636] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [637] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [638] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [639] In that period, appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [640] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [641] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [642] We have assumed that this process did not predate the Ashanti period. Functionaries and notables that served regional rulers, such as Omanhenes in various Akan states, probably exercised patrimonial rather than bureaucratic authority.

Authority over local-level administrators

♠ Direct ♣ ♥
♠ Indirect ♣ ♥
♠ Diffused ♣ ♥
♠ Mixed ♣ ♥
♠ Governmental control ♣ ♥
♠ Non-governmental oversight ♣ ♥

Source of Support of local-level officials

♠ State salary ♣ ♥
♠ Governed population ♣ ♥
♠ Land ♣ ♥
♠ None ♣ ♥
♠ Other ♣ ♥

Pathologies

♠ Corruption ♣ ♥
♠ Bribery ♣ ♥
♠ Abuse of power ♣ ♥

♠ Professionalization of local bureaucracy ♣ ♥

♠ modal number of years local bureaucrats spend in service ♣ ♥

Legal System[edit]

♠ Multiple legal systems ♣ absent ♥

♠ Courts are supported by the state ♣ present ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as 'Executive'. Chiefs and their councillors presided over judicial hearings: 'The initial processes applicable to civil, oath, accused or criminal summonses have already been described. In order to meet the clerical service required for these forms, there is attached to the important Tribunals a Registrar's office where summonses and all the other processes are taken. The Registrar has charge of the cause list and the Record Books. In Akim Abuakwa the tribunal sits for five days in the week, Wednesday being excluded by the “Awukudae” custom, and Sunday by the British connexion and other Christian influences. Sittings of Tribunal last for about 6 to 10 working hours each day, and the Omanhene, as responsible judge, is always expected to be present throughout the day's sitting. We have already described the constitution of the Tribunal as consisting of the Omanhene, his Linguists, his four principal Executive Chiefs, the Queen-Mother, the non-Stool owning Elders and Councillors (including in the latter term the Christian Elders and Presbyters). The Tribunal is summoned by the “Kantamanto” or “woni-mini” drum ( q.v.) and on the Omanhene taking his seat at the third beating of the drum, the Registrar proceeds to deal with his cause list.' [643] It thus seems that most regional leaders and elders handled judicial matters by themselves rather than having recourse to a centralized, stratified justice system. However, courts were still backed by the state in the sense of being essentially identical with it. In the pre-Ashanti period, this hierarchy may have culminated in the Omanhene.

♠ Criminal Prosecution ♣ absent ♥ According to Rattray, formal punishment was absent prior to the Ashanti period (see punishment variables). If this is true, then the major function of courts may have been dispute resolution and symbolic proclamations of guilt rather than criminal prosecution. Confirmation is needed.

Accessibility of the Legal System

♠ ruling elite ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that, at least in principle, all free residents of Akan states had access to 'proto-courts'. This is in need of confirmation.
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ present ♥
♠ general population ♣ present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ present ♥

Accessibility of Trials

♠ ruling elite ♣ present ♥ We have assumed that, at least in principle, all free residents of Akan states had access to 'proto-courts'. This is in need of confirmation.
♠ non-ruling elite ♣ present ♥
♠ general population ♣ present ♥
♠ foreign groups ♣ present ♥
♠ ethnic groups ♣ present ♥

Accessibility of Courts

♠ Courts in polity capital ♣ present ♥ Courts were present in towns and cities where an Omanhene was present. We are unsure about provincial towns.
♠ Courts in regional capitals ♣ present ♥
♠ Courts in provincial towns ♣ ♥

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in criminal cases ♣ ♥ It appears that criminal prosecution was absent (see above).

♠ Typical speed of judicial proceedings in civil cases ♣ ♥ We have found no reliable data on this.

Informal Justice[edit]

♠ Non-state judiciary ♣ absent ♥ SCCS variable 89 'Judiciary' is coded as 'Executive'. Chiefs and their councillors presided over judicial hearings: 'The initial processes applicable to civil, oath, accused or criminal summonses have already been described. In order to meet the clerical service required for these forms, there is attached to the important Tribunals a Registrar's office where summonses and all the other processes are taken. The Registrar has charge of the cause list and the Record Books. In Akim Abuakwa the tribunal sits for five days in the week, Wednesday being excluded by the “Awukudae” custom, and Sunday by the British connexion and other Christian influences. Sittings of Tribunal last for about 6 to 10 working hours each day, and the Omanhene, as responsible judge, is always expected to be present throughout the day's sitting. We have already described the constitution of the Tribunal as consisting of the Omanhene, his Linguists, his four principal Executive Chiefs, the Queen-Mother, the non-Stool owning Elders and Councillors (including in the latter term the Christian Elders and Presbyters). The Tribunal is summoned by the “Kantamanto” or “woni-mini” drum ( q.v.) and on the Omanhene taking his seat at the third beating of the drum, the Registrar proceeds to deal with his cause list.' [644] It thus seems that most regional leaders and elders handled judicial matters by themselves rather than having recourse to a centralized, stratified justice system. However, courts were still backed by the state in the sense of being essentially identical with it. In the pre-Ashanti period, this hierarchy may have culminated in the Omanhene.

♠ Religious judiciary ♣ absent ♥ See above.

Property Rights[edit]

♠ Private property (land) ♣ absent ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [645] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [646] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [647] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [648] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [649] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [650] But inheritance was divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [651] Households cultivated family farms: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [652] Land became the property of clans through clearing of forests and cultivation. Wilks describes the process of establishing estates: 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [653] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [654] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [655] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [656] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [657] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [658] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [659] Accordingly, land was formally owned by matrilineages and stools rather than individuals. The latter held usufruct rights in lineage land rather than owning it 'privately'.

♠ Usufruct ♣ present ♥ See above.
♠ Exclusivity ♣ inferred present ♥ Land was formally held by stools and matrilineages (see above). It seems likely that holders of 'estates' could exclude members of other clans from their land.
♠ Partibility ♣ ♥ We are unsure about partibility of lineage lands.
♠ Lease ♣ absent ♥ In the Ashanti period, urban families bought land from indebted families and leased it to sharecroppers: 'It must be stressed again, however, that the model of the rural economy developed here is one specifically of relevance to the sector of nonintensive land use (Level III), and in that sense to “subsistence.” But by the late eighteenth century the capital, Kumase, and several other major centers of local administration — Bekwae, Dwaben, Kokofu, and Mampon, for example — had come to offer a wide range of employment opportunities other than farming: in court, in the civil and military administrations, in business, in crafts, and so forth. In the early nineteenth century Kumase was already a town of about 20,000 people, few of whom were directly engaged in food production. As the staple crops are not in general ones that can be transported over long periods of time (and a laden carrier would seldom travel more than ten miles a day in the forest) and as in any case portage added greatly to the sales price of the produce, areas of more intensive agricultural production (Level II) were created around Kumase and the other large towns. Follows were shortened to permit the more intensive exploitation of the land, albeit at the risk of a long-term degeneration in soil fertility, and new patterns in the organization of the social relations of production become discernible. Lineage land purchased by wealthy townsfolk from families that had fallen into debt was parcelled out among sharecroppers — often unfree — who retained [Page 56] a nominal third (abusa) of the produce for their own use and supplied the remainder to the entrepreneur. The sharecropper worked longer hours and suffered a lower standard of living than the free farmer on lineage land. A differential was thus created between dearer and cheaper labor that represented, in a sense, the social cost of feeding the urban population; urban growth depended upon agricultural growth, which in turn involved the appearance of a form of landlord tenure (though not, because of the operations of the system of death duties, of landed estates). The matter is, however, one beyond the scope of this essay.' [660] We have assumed this process did not predate the Ashanti period.
♠ Lease Rights ♣ absent ♥ See comments above.
♠ Transfer of property ♣ present ♥ Property was generally passed on within the matrilineage (see below).
♠ Use of property ♣ absent ♥
♠ Property market ♣ absent ♥ There was no property market for matriclan lands cultivated for household subsistence. In the Ashanti period, more intensive agriculture was practiced around Kumasi. Wealthy urban families bought land from indebted families and leased it to sharecroppers: 'It must be stressed again, however, that the model of the rural economy developed here is one specifically of relevance to the sector of nonintensive land use (Level III), and in that sense to “subsistence.” But by the late eighteenth century the capital, Kumase, and several other major centers of local administration — Bekwae, Dwaben, Kokofu, and Mampon, for example — had come to offer a wide range of employment opportunities other than farming: in court, in the civil and military administrations, in business, in crafts, and so forth. In the early nineteenth century Kumase was already a town of about 20,000 people, few of whom were directly engaged in food production. As the staple crops are not in general ones that can be transported over long periods of time (and a laden carrier would seldom travel more than ten miles a day in the forest) and as in any case portage added greatly to the sales price of the produce, areas of more intensive agricultural production (Level II) were created around Kumase and the other large towns. Follows were shortened to permit the more intensive exploitation of the land, albeit at the risk of a long-term degeneration in soil fertility, and new patterns in the organization of the social relations of production become discernible. Lineage land purchased by wealthy townsfolk from families that had fallen into debt was parcelled out among sharecroppers — often unfree — who retained [Page 56] a nominal third (abusa) of the produce for their own use and supplied the remainder to the entrepreneur. The sharecropper worked longer hours and suffered a lower standard of living than the free farmer on lineage land. A differential was thus created between dearer and cheaper labor that represented, in a sense, the social cost of feeding the urban population; urban growth depended upon agricultural growth, which in turn involved the appearance of a form of landlord tenure (though not, because of the operations of the system of death duties, of landed estates). The matter is, however, one beyond the scope of this essay.' [661] But this process did not predate the Ashanti period, and even then the majority of arable land was held by matriclans and stools.

♠ Other property ownership ♣ present ♥ Heirlooms were transmitted within families: 'According to Rattray, kuduo were classed as agyapadie, a term he translates as ‘heirloom’. Kuduo were clearly regarded as items of great importance, and many thousands survive. Earlier in this century it appears the Asante were reluctant to part with these vessels to outsiders and, although many have since been removed from Ghana, some are still to be found in stool rooms or in the private possession of old people. Many of the kuduo which exist today are heavily corroded, indicating that they have, at some time, been buried.' [662] Husbands gifted clothing and other objects to their wives, which the latter had to repay in the case of divorce: 'The following is only a brief indication of what seems to me to be peculiar in an Akan marriage as compared to the institution in other countries.' [663] 'Such is the state of a married couple that in many instances a wife may well guard against receiving any large presents in the form of clothing, etc., from her husband, or she might one day regret her action. This is so because, should there be a rupture, ending in divorce, all that the husband had since the payment of “Aseda” and during the time of their married life, given to the wife by way of presents, etc., must be returned to the husband. Even in cases where the wife is seeking for divorce without good cause shown or with a view to marrying another man in the immediate future, she has to pay for all the clothing which had become useless by wear and tear. Consequently, while husband and wife are living together, there may be constant dread on the part of the wife to make use of things given to her by her husband, else she may one day be divorced a bankrupt. If she is rich in her own right, the wife will prefer to dress in clothing bought with her own money, and she would not wait for her husband to provide her clothing.' [664] Stools were associated with matriclans: 'Before proceeding further, it is necessary to explain the origin of stools, whether family or public. Where the head of a family has more than one stool, he may give one to a member of the family on appointing him the Penin of a junior branch of the large family. The person so appointed thereby acquires possession of all the goods, chattels, and lands appurtenant to that stool. His own property becomes stool property, and is merged in whatever is given him. The children of the last stoolholder call him father, and the widows become his wives; each woman can, however, obtain her freedom on repayment of the Consawment money, that is, dowry. But a new stool is created in this wise: when the family of a man of wealth or influence on his death so will, they create a family stool which is named after the deceased. For this purpose the favourite chair of the deceased, generally a small one, which was in constant use by him, is cleaned, then rubbed all over with the blood of sheep, and finally smeared with a mixture of soot and eggs. The stool is afterwards wrapped in some skin and safely kept. During this consecration, libation is made and prayers are freely offered for the prosperity of the family, and that its members may, in time to come, attain greater influence and prominence. These stools are added to from time to time, but count is made of only the prominent ones. Too often the name of the original founder of the family is dropped for that of one of his successors of greater eminence. When an old stool is so decayed that it ought to be destroyed, it is burnt, and the ashes thereof are made into a paste with oil, blood, eggs, and other substances. The paste is then daubed on a new stool, which is [Page 13] consecrated as a family stool and named after the old one. When an old stool is lost a new one is specially made and consecrated.' [665] Chiefs owned ceremonial drums: 'Before we enter upon a detailed description of these drums, an account of how they are made, and the ceremonial inseparable from their manufacture, will be of interest. When an Ashanti chief wants a couple of ntumpane or talking drums he will summon the makers (who are not the drummers), and are variously known as 'kyerema nyano (the drummer's nyano) or atwenesenfo (i. e. carvers of the tweneboa tree). Only chiefs of the rank of omanhene, ohene, or safohene have the right to possess such drums. A Queen Mother or other women may not possess a drum.' [666] Kronenfeld provides a general description of the property system: 'Thus, the actual social effects of Fanti inheritance rules depend on the durability of property, 1) The only properties (in Egyaa, at least) durable for a long time are positions: lineage leader ( ebusua panyin) and other chiefships or stools belonging to the ebusua. Informants talked about the inheritance of position in the same way that they talked about the inheritance of property, All stools or chiefships (except possibly for some asafo 2) House sites stay within an ebusua normally, but are common enough in Egyaa not to be worth fighting over. Houses themselves seem usually to last 20-30 years at most before needing rebuilding. (This refers to traditional wattle-and-daub or adobe houses. More recent concrete block houses will probably last longer.) Houses, then, may pass down one generation of inheritance, but not much further. 3) Personal property (clothes, utensils, etc.) also seem to have a short useful life, i.e., 10-20 years. 4) Fishing boats have an expected life span of 10 years, nets around 5 years, and motors around 3 years. 5) Women's fish-smoking ovens only seem to last a couple of years. 6) An active farm will be inherited when its owner dies; in fact, however, particular farms (in [Page 27] Egyaa ) only last for a couple of years, and thus are not too important as inherited property. 7) Finally, there does seem to have been a lot of cash in Egyaa which would represent a worthwhile inheritance. Supposedly, inherited money is kept separately from earned money. But money is constantly loaned out through a kinship-based credit network, and uncollectible debts are common. The net effect, I think, is that money deriving from some particular person only goes through a couple of inheritances at most before disappearing (or going into goods). However, this is only speculation, since money, being less visible and identifiable than goods, was harder for me to follow, and presumably for the same reasons is harder for the people involved to keep track of.' [667] Slavery was also practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [668]

Inheritance System

♠ partible inheritance ♣ present ♥ Inheritance was generally matrilineal, but fathers could pass on property which they had acquired themselves to their sons (see below).
♠ patrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Inheritance was generally matrilineal, but fathers could pass on property which they had acquired themselves to their sons (see below).
♠ matrilineal inheritance ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [669] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [670] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [671] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [672] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [673] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [674] But inheritance could be divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [675] 'An Ashanti father on his death-bed might call his abusua (blood relations) around him, inform them that his son had served him well, and that when he died he wished him to be given some of his (the father's) personal private property. Such a bequest is known as Samansie (that which is left, or set aside, by the ghost). A father might not, however, leave his inherited weapons to his son. They went to his brother or nephew. It will be seen, later, how a claimant, who [Page 16] wishes to be considered for selection to a vacant stool, speaks of ‘taking the gun of the deceased’.' [676] Inheritance rights within the matrilineage were based on seniority and siblingship relations: 'Inheritance rights in Fanti are based on lineage membership and seniority, and lineage membership can be framed in terms of types of siblingship. But yet the basic siblingship and seniority information relevant to inheritance are expressed in Fanti outside of the basic kin terminology. In this paper I want first to show how these kinds of information are expressed and how the information specifically shapes inheritance rights and then to examine the effects of inheritance on lineage segmentation. I will conclude with a look at some linguistic consequences (in the kin terminology) of changes in cultural expectations regarding inheritance — changes which stem from effects of Ghanaian law on inheritance and from changes in the obligations involved in raising children.' [677] 'Each of these issues — siblingship, seniority, inheritance rights, and change — will be examined separately for its interaction with the wider kinship system, and thus for what it contributes to the feedback relations among the kin terminology, the inheritance and socialization relations that shape the terminology, and the kin groups that have precipitated out around these inheritance relations. This discussion of the interrelationship among kin terminology, kin groups, and succession will necessarily raise the further analytic issue of what other linguistic information (beyond that minimally necessary to a formal analysis of the kinship terms themselves) belongs in a kinship terminological analysis — if that analysis is addressed to these kinds of functional questions.' [678] 'Seniority, referring in its core sense to relative age, is important to Fanti kinship and social interaction in several ways. Computed on age and genealogical criteria within a lineage, and relative to the relevant property, seniority defines the ordering of potential heirs to property. The relative seniority of any ego and alter — where seniority can refer to the age and genealogical criteria of inheritance, but where it also can refer to a subtle interaction of power, respect, precedence, and putative authority — is treated as important by Fanti speakers, and importantly affects day-to-day interactions and kin term usage (see Kronenfeld 1973). However, seniority is not coded directly in the kin terminology proper. Instead, seniority is optionally marked via the use of general (i.e., non-kinship-specific) modifiers — usually panyin (senior) and kakraba (junior). These modifiers do not have a primary kinship reference; they can apply to any relationship between non-equals (in age, power, authority, and, even, by extension, size or assertiveness).' [679] 'A woman has the potential of being inherited leviratically by her kun kakraba (who is her husband's “brother”), but not by her kun panyin, and reciprocally a man may inherit his yer panyin (“senior wife” = wife of senior “brother” or “uncle”), but not his yer kakraba (“junior wife” = wife of junior “brother”). As far as I know, there is no equivalent sororate on the woman's side.' [680] 'A nua panyin is older than a nua kakraba and has authority over the kakraba. As children, the elder brother can discipline his junior, subject to control by the father. As adults, the elder is senior in the lineage to the junior and will inherit before the junior (the junior will inherit subsequently). Among brothers, the panyin kakraba distinction is commonly made and seems to be considered an important one. In certain lineage situations (see below) an extended younger nua can be senior ( panyin) to an elder because he has a senior mother.' [681] 'I have explored the concepts of siblingship and seniority not only for the insight they give into the interrelationship among cultural action, terminology, and grammar, but also because of the role they play in the execution of the major corporate function of Fanti lineages: the assignment of inheritance rights. I want now to examine that inheritance role in more detail. Matrilineages (ebusua) are very salient social units to the Fanti. They figure heavily in conversations of various sorts, including discussions of political and economic maneuverings. The lineage represents the primary referent of the English word “family” as it is used by Fanti speakers. The word ebusua is the primary translation equivalent of “family” for Fanti speakers, while in anthropological terms ebusua refers to a matrilineage (the unmarked default sense) or matriclan (a denotatively correct extension).' [682] 'Inheritance is traditionally within the ebusua (lineage). The elders of the ebusua determine who will succeed to the property and positions of a deceased person. The elders are free to pick any member of the lineage as successor, or they can select an outsider to act as custodian of the property and/or as temporary filler of the position. They are supposed to pick successors who are mature and who have the skills needed for effectively using the property or filling the position.' [683] 'There are ideal norms which are followed, insofar as possible, concerning the genealogical relationship of heir to deceased: 1) Normally women inherit from women and men from men. 2) Qualified people of the deceased's own generation take precedence over those of subsequent generations, and seniors do not normally inherit from juniors (i.e., qualified people junior to the deceased come in order of seniority). 3) Genealogical qualification consists primarily in being descended from the [Page 26] mother of the person who first earned or created the property; other lineage members come afterward.' [684] 'There is, therefore, a kind of inheritance seniority (mba mpanyin mu). According to this seniority pattern (see Fig. 2), if a man. A, creates some property, the property ideally should pass to his next younger matrilineally related brother, then to the next younger, etc. In Generation -1 the eldest son of his eldest sister would come first, followed by the eldest son of his next eldest sister and so on. In Generation -2 the eldest son of the eldest daughter of A's eldest sister would come first, etc. B. C, and D inherit only after all of A's younger brothers inherit and after all the descendants of his sisters inherit. This pattern seems also to work for positions, as well.' [685] 'A woman's property descends in the same manner, I believe, from “mother” to “daughter” by seniority.' [686] Inheritance from father to son was possible under certain conditions, but rarely practiced: 'Traditionally, there has also been some limited opportunity for father-son inheritance. A man has been able, by an oral will (or, more recently, a written one), to leave a part of the property that he has earned or created himself to his children and/or wife, subject to the agreement of his ebusua, Furthermore, modern Ghanaian law permits a Fanti man to leave up to a third of his acquired property to his children and up to a third to his wife. However, in spite of the potentiality, I recorded no cases in Egyaa of sons having inherited anything from their fathers: Egyaa men give their children anything they intend for them to receive during their lifetimes, leaving their whole estate to their ebusua heirs. My understanding was that this is a more traditional and common way of transferring property to men's children than oral wills, though I collected no hard evidence on the question.' [687] 'To summarize, the only property a man can transfer to his sons is that which he has personally acquired. His ebusua controls the distribution (normally within the ebusua) of other property which he has held. The persons in the ebusua who are his most likely heirs can be different for different properties since the ordering of likely heirs depends on the genealogical “age” of the property in question.' [688] Kronenfeld provides a general description of the property system: 'Thus, the actual social effects of Fanti inheritance rules depend on the durability of property, 1) The only properties (in Egyaa, at least) durable for a long time are positions: lineage leader ( ebusua panyin) and other chiefships or stools belonging to the ebusua. Informants talked about the inheritance of position in the same way that they talked about the inheritance of property, All stools or chiefships (except possibly for some asafo 2) House sites stay within an ebusua normally, but are common enough in Egyaa not to be worth fighting over. Houses themselves seem usually to last 20-30 years at most before needing rebuilding. (This refers to traditional wattle-and-daub or adobe houses. More recent concrete block houses will probably last longer.) Houses, then, may pass down one generation of inheritance, but not much further. 3) Personal property (clothes, utensils, etc.) also seem to have a short useful life, i.e., 10-20 years. 4) Fishing boats have an expected life span of 10 years, nets around 5 years, and motors around 3 years. 5) Women's fish-smoking ovens only seem to last a couple of years. 6) An active farm will be inherited when its owner dies; in fact, however, particular farms (in [Page 27] Egyaa ) only last for a couple of years, and thus are not too important as inherited property. 7) Finally, there does seem to have been a lot of cash in Egyaa which would represent a worthwhile inheritance. Supposedly, inherited money is kept separately from earned money. But money is constantly loaned out through a kinship-based credit network, and uncollectible debts are common. The net effect, I think, is that money deriving from some particular person only goes through a couple of inheritances at most before disappearing (or going into goods). However, this is only speculation, since money, being less visible and identifiable than goods, was harder for me to follow, and presumably for the same reasons is harder for the people involved to keep track of.' [689] 'Thus positions represent the only property in Egyaa which is likely to be inherited down two generations or more. Other property is very unlikely to last beyond its first owner's immediate heirs.' [690] 'The social effects of inheritance are modified, also, by some frequency considerations. Most people do not have much property to leave anyone. Most inheritance that does occur is brother to brother; only rarely does a nephew inherit from an uncle directly (only once in each generation for any particular property — see Table 2), though eventually the brothers of that nephew (i.e., the other nephews) will get their turn with the property, if they live long enough, and if it lasts.' [691] 'There are some general social consequences of the Fanti inheritance pattern that seem worthy of consideration. One of these consequences concerns the effects of different kinds of property on the presence or absence of internal lineage segmentation. Another concerns the effects, after successive generations, of the inheritance priority assigned to generation (vs. age) on the degree to which some ancestor's property rotates among all of his descendent lines or not.' [692]
♠ primogeniture inheritance by only males ♣ absent ♥ Seniority relations determined the distribution of inherited property (see above), but there was no primogeniture per se.
♠ primogeniture inheritance by males and females ♣ absent ♥ Seniority relations determined the distribution of inherited property (see above), but there was no primogeniture per se.
♠ other inheritance practices ♣ absent ♥
♠ Trusts ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure whether matriclans can be considered trusts. We have assumed this not to be case for the time being.
♠ State expropriation ♣ present ♥ Stools were owed 'death duties' in gold, slaves and movables: '(a) Death Duties (Ayibuadie): Bowdich mentions that the King of Ashanti was ‘heir to the gold of every subject from the highest to the lowest’, and thus, according to Ashanti custom, had to contribute to the funeral custom ‘to validate his claim’. This statement, however, requires considerable qualification. While it is correct to state that, theoretically, a Chief (or rather a Stool) would sooner or later become heir—within the strict limitation implied in the Ashanti meaning of the word—to all his subjects, the majority of such death duties were received by a Stool, indirectly. It has been observed that a Chief only has direct dealings with a minority of his subordinate Chiefs, e.g. with his own Mpanyimfo and with his own Birempon, and that these officials have numerous subjects of their own whom the Head-Chief only attempts to control through them. Let us suppose that a wealthy subject died, who happened to be under one of the Mpanyimfo of the Head-Chief's Birempon. The Opanyini would succeed to a specified amount of his subordinate's private personal [Page 108] movable assets, gold-dust, slaves, cloths, and such like. On the Opanyini's death, the Birempon would take a similar proportion of his estate. The Birempon's Head-Chief, i.e. the Head of the whole Territorial Division, would not get anything on these occasions. Later, however, when the Birempon himself died, the Head-Chief would benefit by receiving the death duties from his estate, which would thus include all that he, the Birempon, had collected and accumulated in death duties from his subjects. The potential wealth of Ashanti Chiefs might thus be very great, the amount of their immediately realizable securities very small. The late Mary Kingsley, whose writings on West Africa are remarkable for observation and intuition, wrote: ‘In the capacity (eventually) to command these things his wealth lies. So take the whole together and you will see how you can have a very rich African, who could not possibly pay down £20, but a real millionaire for all that.’ The unfairness of demanding great sums as war indemnities at very short notice, which had been the policy of some of our civil and military commanders in the wars against Ashanti, may thus be realized.' [693] 'It is necessary to understand that when, in Ashanti, we speak of a Chief taking part of a man's property on death, only his personal self-acquired movable property is meant. Family property, in the possession of the deceased, which on his death reverted to the family, might not be touched. The proportion of the property of a dead man taken by a Chief varied in specified cases, and this will be noted when the Constitution of individual Stools comes under examination. In this chapter I am concerned with general principles rather than with the more minute details. Ayibuadie means literally ‘something to cover over or help the funeral rite’. There is a word in the vernacular, muhoma (lit. that with which to bind the breasts), which has a significance very similar to ayibuadie. Instead of a Chief coming down upon the estate of a dead subject, i.e. sending his Sana Hene (Treasurer) to lock up his rooms and boxes until the value of the estate had been assessed, he might leave the amount to be paid in death duties to the discretion of the relatives of the deceased. The levy then assumed more the appearance of a voluntary contribution on their part, ‘to bind the breast of the Chief’, ‘whose heart was sore’ owing to the loss of his subject and friend. This method of allowing the death duty to be paid was a more delicate and tactful way of going about the collection of this tax than the other more forcible method, but it practically amounted to [Page 109] the same thing in the end. It must not be overlooked that the claim to receive ayibuadie or muhoma involved some special obligations on the part of the recipient. Both these claims may be traced back to the original cell from which most of these more elaborate customs sprang. The house-father succeeded to the property of his dead kinsman, but he also had to see to it that he gave him a good and proper funeral. By a legal fiction, the Chief stood in a similar relationship to his subject, and by taking some of the latter's property on his death placed himself under the fictitious obligation of having to contribute to his funeral custom. By doing so he did not, however, become liable for the debts of the deceased. A Chief would also take care to see that the balance struck between what came in from ayibuadie or muhoma and what went out in funeral contributions ( nsa or nsawa) was in his favour. There is yet another expression which is sometimes confused with the above, i.e. awunyadie. This term, I think, means the inheritance of property by the legal heir.' [694] 'Death duties ( Ayibuadie): The Chief claimed ayibuadie from those subjects who served him directly. He could claim all private property on death of any gyase who was descended down the female line from a gyase female slave. In the case of the descendant of a gyase man who had married a free woman (but a subject of the Chief), a male would enter that company to which his father had belonged, but at his death the Chief would claim only one half of his private belongings, the other half going to his own kindred. The Chief of Kumawu also claimed about two-thirds of the private property of the Heads of the following fekuo (the remaining third went to the Stool of the deceased), the Atum'tufo, Asoamfo, Asokwafo, Barimfo, Obofo, Samanfo, Sodofo. He received from his Mpanyimfo (on their death) a voluntary contribution made by the successor which was known as muhoma, and generally consisted of one of the deceased's wives, a male servant, a cloth, and some gold-dust. The taking of ayibuadie or muhoma implied an obligation to contribute towards the funeral expenses and to present gifts to the dead. In the case of a wealthy man, from whose estate a considerable amount had been received in death duties, this contribution might consist of a velvet pillow ( agopekyi), a silk danta (loin-cloth), in the folds of which was wrapped a suru of gold-dust (£1); 10 s. worth of gold-dust, to mix with the fat which was used to rub down the corpse; the coffin (which it has now become the custom for the children to buy); two or three [Page opp. p 230] [Page 230] cloths, which were buried with the body; a sheep and about 10 s. in gold-dust towards the funeral expenses. In the case of a poor man, the death duties from whose estate would be a small amount, the Chief would give a sheep and a cheap cloth, ‘lest if he did not give anything, the dead should report him to the ' Samanfo (spirits)’. [These obligations are still often observed, possibly from a superstitious dread of reprisals on the part of the dead; the corresponding right to demand ayibuadie, or to expect muhoma, has on the other hand almost entirely lapsed, and this state of affairs is often given as one of the reasons for the impoverished state of Stool finances.] The Chief also informed me of another interesting possible source of revenue in olden times of which I had not previously been aware, though it is possible the custom was not confined to one Division. When the Chief had a son or daughter ( by a wife who was at the same time his own subject), and that child died, the Chief succeeded to all his or her private property and not the child's abusua (kindred group) as would ordinarily be the case. Only a Head-Chief had this right, not the lesser Chiefs—the Mpanyimfo. This rule also applied to the children of the Kyidom Hene, because he was known as the ‘son’ of the Chief.' [695] We have assumed that regional rulers practiced this in some form even before the Ashanti period, but this remains in need of confirmation. We have provisionally considered this to be a form of state expropriation.
♠ Non-state expropriation ♣ absent ♥

Equity[edit]

Sex Class and Race[edit]

Marriage

♠ Monogamy ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [696] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [697] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [698] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [699] Exogamy was the norm: 'Marriage is expected to be exogamous, and is extremely simple. There is no bride-wealth, the union being effected by the transfer of rum or other drink and some money from the groom to the bride's immediate family. Divorce is extremely easy and may be initiated by either men or women. The most usual causes are adultery and the barrenness of wives.' [700] Society was matrilineal, but legitimacy was still important: 'Legitimacy is important both for inheritance and to define a person as having, or not having, slave ancestry. It demands not only a proper marriage, however short, but also a recognized pater: he gives the child his own spiritual identity and his or her name; he admits his responsibility for the child's education, and he has the expectation that the child will carry out the father's funerary rites. [MG]' [701] Multiple residence patterns were present: 'Domestic organization long remained one of the most ambiguous aspects of Akan social structure. It was Fortes who finally delineated the key structural principles and processes through his research in the 1940s in the communities of Asokore and Agogo. He distinguished three major household types each based on a different residence pattern. First are households grouped around a minimal matrilineage, such as a woman and her sister or daughters, or a man and his sister or sister's son. Such households are based on duolocal residence, with a husband and wife living apart in different domestic units; about 62 percent of the households in Agogo were of this type.' [702] 'Second are households consisting of a man, his wife, and their children, sometimes including other kinsfolk; this type of patrilocal or virilocal unit constituted about 22 percent of the households in Agogo. Finally, there are households made up of combinations of the previous types (e.g. a man, his wife, and children) plus his sister's children. Often these reflect an avunculocal residence pattern. The matrilineal domestic group is usually preponderant in the larger communities, while virilocal or patrilocal households are the most common type in small farming villages or hamlets. But all three "types" should be viewed simply as phases in a domestic cycle. In the early years of marriage, residence is predominantly duolocal, but with the passage of time this could shift to avunculocal or patrilocal/virilocal. Thus the composition of a domestic group would evolve over time. [ROL]' [703] Fathers played a prominent role in the arrangement of marriages: 'THERE are two forms of marriage recognised in the Fanti districts of the Gold Coast Colony, ( a) Marriage by native custom, and ( b) Marriage under Ordinance No. 14 of 1884 of the Colony.' [704] 'I intend to deal only with the native custom, and I may here state that I have always relied rather on illiterate natives and chiefs, for my information, than on educated native men, for the following reasons:—the illiterate native tells one all he knows, or all he dares, and, having no reason to lie when he is not in court, he generally relates facts. A chief is the judge of his people, and, with his councillors, is the repository and exponent of the law, and must necessarily be taken as an expert. The scholar studies anything but his own customs, while an educated native is too inclined to embellish those customs, and present them in a form that would do credit to Justinian.' [705] 'According to the Family System of the Tˇw-speaking races of the Gold Coast, although the children belong to the family of the mother, and not of the father, yet the father seems always to have been the person responsible for the marriage of his children.' [706] 'He was liable for their maintenance and up-bringing, and was responsible for their actions. Thus if any of his sons, living under his roof, seduced any woman, the father had to pay satisfaction. If any of his daughters were seduced, he claimed and obtained compensation. He supplied his children with means to trade, or to make a living, and in return was entitled to all their earnings. The liability for the sons ceased on their marriage, or when they became self-supporting, so that it was to the father's advantage to find them wives as soon as possible after they reached the age of puberty, and this became recognised as a duty.' [707] 'Hence it is clear that primitive negro marriages were interparental contracts, in which the consent of the parties themselves was never considered. The father gave his son a peto and a half of gold dust, and the mother contributed half a peto, to start him in life (a peto being roughly an ounce), and he then worked for himself instead of for his father.' [708] 'As time went on fathers came to look on their daughters as sources of income, and demanded sums of money when approached for their hands; this was only natural, as they had nothing to lose by keeping them unmarried, and lost at least their services when they parted with them; whereas unmarried sons were always a possible source of danger.' [709] 'Thus it came about, within historical times, that when a man had a marriageable son he approached a man with a marriageable daughter, and having made a suitable present, which varied from one ackie (4 s. 6 d.) to four ackies (18 s.), the two were betrothed, and cohabitation completed the marriage. [Some reckon the ackie as worth 5 s.]' [710] 'Sometimes it happened, for personal reasons, that children were betrothed before they were mature; in such cases the boy's parent maintained the girl in her father's house and watched her, and was entitled to satisfaction if she were tampered with. When both had reached puberty the marriage was completed by cohabitation. The betrothal could be broken off meanwhile by the boy's parent, on forfeiting the so-called ‘consawment’ money, or by the girl's parent, by returning the money that had been paid.' [711] According to Ffoukes, marriage negotiations became more extensive in the colonial period. There was a lot of regional variation: 'This state continued so long as children quietly submitted to the dictates of their parents, but during the last five centuries the natives have been brought into touch with various European nations, and the much-despised civilisation [Page 33] has tended to modify all their customs and ideas. Sons gradually came to be consulted, and were later allowed to choose their own wives; while the consent of the women was never considered until very recently, and even now it is not usual, except in Coast towns, where girls are far more independent than in the bush.' [712] 'The marriage custom, instead of being the simple process of parents pairing off their children, now entails considerable expense. For instance, the present procedure in Cape Coast is as follows:—The relatives of the man (or more often the man himself) approach the relatives of the girl with rum, and if they appear willing a further “dash” is taken, which varies from £1 to 30 s., according to the suitor's circumstances; this is called Abombo or the “knocking” fee, as the suitor knocks at the door to ask for the girl; the father fixes the amount. On the acceptance of the abombo the girl becomes the affianced bride of the man, and although this is only a moral obligation, it is very strictly adhered to, and breach of promise is unknown to native custom. Occasional presents may now be exchanged, and shortly afterwards her parents receive the Etsir-Nsã (Fantee, Etsir a head, Nsã rum), which consists of two flasks of gin and a sum varying from five dollars (£1) to half an ounce of gold (£2) which is distributed amongst her relatives.' [713] 'Her parents then may or may not make a further claim for dowry or head money, etsirkyeradzi or etsiradzi (from etsir, “head,” kyere “to show” or “prove,” and adzi, “thing”), of one to two ounces of gold, or £6 to £9; and the man further sends a box to the girl containing cloths, handkerchiefs, a comb, lavender-water and pomade, with perhaps pipes and a supply of tobacco, and a day is fixed to hand the girl over.' [714] 'Some time usually elapses between sending the etsir nsã and contributing the etsiradzi, and this, it is alleged, is to give the man and his parents time to watch the character of the girl, as well as to meet the increasing demands of the avaricious parents who fix the dowry; but there is nothing to prevent sending both at once and completing the nuptial ceremony forthwith. However, the negro never does anything in a hurry! No precautions are now taken with the girl other than to warn her not to visit her intended husband's house before she is handed over, and she is never confined before her marriage, but satisfaction must be paid for cohabitation before she is so handed over.' [715] 'In Fanti Yankumase [Assin] the custom varies appreciably from Cape Coast, for here the suitor sends to ask the girl's family, without rum or abombo, and if they agree, both families meet to drink rum or palm wine; this ceremony, to show the couple is engaged, is called Wakagyir. Then the man seals his bond by sending three small bottles of gin to the girl's family, and this is termed etsir nsã. He also [Page 35] gives the town crier 1 s. 6 d. to publish his betrothal, and 4 s. to witnesses. He further sends 8 s. to the girl's mother to maintain her until marriage; this payment is called Ntamboba (= Tanbiba, see infra), which implies, “as the mother has looked after the child, now somebody takes her.”' [716] 'The matter then waits until the man has sufficient money, and if the girl or her family has a debt he pays it; this they call the etsiradzi. At this stage the Assins make sure that the bride-elect is a virgin, and, if not, lay their claim against the seducer. If there are no debts, the bridegroom merely provides a box, with cloths, handkerchiefs, looking-glass, and perfumes, and takes the bride home.' [717] 'In Denkera the matter is much simpler; the man asks the father for his daughter, and notifies the girl's family, if he gets the father's consent, by sending them rum; he then pays her family the abombo, which they fix, and which may vary from £1 to 30 s., and the man takes the girl home; although he may pay a further dowry of £4 or £5, but this is not essential.' [718] Marriage and divorce became more regulated in the colonial period: 'The passing of the 1884 Marriage Ordinance Act attempted to set a standard for monogamous marriage and spousal inheritance of self-acquired property. Conflict over inheritance often ended up in court where officials tried to determine whether or not a spouse was a true and therefore legal wife. Women began to organize in the 1950's to change the distinction between ‘wife’ and ‘non-wife’ in order to protect the interests of women and children. The results were the passage of the Maintenance of Children Bill in 1965 and a new divorce law in 1971. [IS]' [719] Concubinage was practiced, but the rights of concubines differed from those of wives: 'Concubinage is everywhere practised on the Coast, and is generally respected, although civilisation has made educated natives profess to disparage it; the sole difference amongst the Fantis is, that Mpata or satisfaction can be sued for by a married man if his wife commits adultery, whereas he can obtain no redress in the case of a concubine. Further, a native can hardly be said to buy his wife, as all moneys paid by him are received on trust for the good behaviour of the wife during the marriage, and are returnable to the husband if he divorces his wife for her misconduct, only vesting in her family on her death, or the death of her husband.' [720] 'Concubinage is openly permitted, and although it is not encouraged on the Coast, it is widely practised elsewhere. It is really quite as honourable a connection as the native marriage, as couples frequently live through life with no other bond than mutual affection. The essential difference is that for lack of consideration the man cannot claim damages if the woman misconducts herself; and if the man misbehaves, the woman has only to leave him at will. In fact the difference is all in favour of the woman, as will be seen when dealing with divorce. Even a married man may keep a concubine openly if his wife has no objection, but she cooks only at the wife's request; it is when a man keeps concubines clandestinely or against his wife's will that the custom is deprecated, and he has to “pacify” her whenever she finds him out. Wives do not appear to discourage it so long as they themselves get their fair share of attention. Whatever is given to a concubine is given outright, and cannot be reclaimed if she chooses to leave him for someone else. Her children can hardly be called illegitimate, as they still belong to her family, and as in the case of a chieftainess the children succeed to the stool. If she has children, and then marries another man, the natural father usually takes and brings them up, so that they may bury him; but if he does not, the husband is obliged to look after them.' [721] 'There is this great difference, however, that, whereas the father of legitimate children is bound to support them, and he is responsible for all their acts, the natural father is not so bound, the obligation and liability falling on the woman's family; he only does so to keep up his good name, and the children do not participate equally in the funeral expenses.' [722] Levirate was also practiced: 'There is a peculiar exception to one of these prohibitions, for when a Fanti dies he is succeeded by his eldest surviving brother, and if he has no brothers, by his eldest sister's eldest son. If the brother succeeds, he is said to take his [Page 44] place, and part of his duty is to marry the widow; this is called Okuranba; if the nephew ( Awofasepenyin) inherits he has a wider choice, for if the man leaves a daughter the nephew can take his choice between the widow and her daughter, but he cannot marry both. ' [723] Husbands were obliged to pay compensation to the wife in the case of divorce unless a legitimate reason for the dissolution of the marriage could be provided: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [724] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [725] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [726] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [727] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [728] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [729] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [730] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [731] Given how adultery was recognized as constituting legitimate grounds for divorce, we have decided to code 'present'.
♠ Formal Elite Polygamy ♣ ♥ Concubinage was practiced (see above). We are unsure whether chiefs and elites had more wives/concubines than 'commoners', although it seems likely. More material is needed.
♠ Informal Elite Polygamy ♣ ♥
