♠ Elite Concubinage ♣ ♥
♠ Typical number of extramarital partners ♣ ♥

Legal rights are different on the basis of:

♠ Gender ♣ present ♥ Descent was matrilineal: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [732] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [733] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [734] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [735] Female stools and councils complemented male power hierarchies: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [736] 'As members of their respective councils, female stool occupants participated in the legislative and judicial processes, in the making and the unmaking of war, and in the distribution of land, the basic resource of the economy. An ohemma of a state also had her own ntam, oath, a formula for starting the judicial process, and her own court, as well as her own okyeame (spokesman) who in the Akan courts acted as prosecutor and judge.' [737] 'An ohemma was a refuge for a fugitive from the ohene's court who often successfully sought her intervention in cases of the death penalty. Called the ‘mother’ of the ohene, she was the latter's most effective adviser and she had the right to administer to him even a public admonition. The ohemma was the aberewa, wisdom personified: an Akan court panel preceded their retirement to discuss a case before passing judgement by saying that they were going to consult aberewa,the old woman. As the aberewa of the town, the ohemma was the moral guardian of the females of the political community and a kind of moral censor: she examined adolescent girls before the main puberty rites which ushered them into adulthood and licensed their marriage, and was expected to say whether or not pregnancy had occurred before the rites. A girl who was found to have become pregnant before the rites was known as kyiribra, and was punished [Page 94] with ostracism together with her partner. The polity thrived on a sound moral order.' [738] 'As the abrewa, the ohemma was also custodian of ‘custom’. She was officially the foremost authority on the genealogy of the royal matrilineage, and hence the first and final arbiter on who was qualified by blood to be a male ruler; it was said of the ohemma's stool in relation to the male stool that it was the elder stool, akonnua panyin. It was the ohemma who played the leading role in the selection of a successor to a deceased or destooled (removed from office) ohene.' [739] 'The ohemma's role in the succession to a vacant stool can be understood in terms, first, of the composite nature of most of the Akan matrilineages and, secondly, of the Akan rules of succession. The composite nature of the Akan matrilineage lay not in its segmentation over time and space, but in the incorporation into it of ‘stranger’ segments which in time became concealed; even when it was known it was not permitted for outsiders to point it out. ‘Stranger’ segments could be descended from slave women or freeborn women of another clan who, therefore, were not of pure blood and whose descendants were not eligible for the stool. The ohemma was the one who could pronounce on the fitness of potential successors for the stool from the viewpoint of true descent from the founding ancestors/ancestresses.' [740] 'Secondly, while the Akan vested the right of succession in the royal matrilineage, they left open the question of the actual successor among the eligible males, which was resolved by joint consultations between the ohemma, as leader of the royal matrilineage, and the members of the village, divisional, or national council. In the process of consultation the ohemma and the council were governed by the following rules: brothers should succeed each other before sisters' sons in the order of seniority in age; but age could be discounted in favour of superior wisdom and character in a junior person. Seniority in age could also be discounted in favour of a younger successor, if rotational succession among the segments of the royal lineage had been adopted as a ‘convention’ by the lineage and the community as a whole. Where rotation had been adopted as a working rule, both the male and female stools rotated among the segments, so that at any moment the occupants belonged to different competing segments.' [741] 'It was the ohemma who operated these rules and ensured orderly succession to the stool. On the decease or de-stoolment of an ohene, the members of the council formally asked the ohemma to nominate a candidate for their approval, and gave her three succeeding options at the end of which the councillors could in turn present a candidate for her approval. It rarely, if ever, came to this. An ohemma consulted members of her matrilineage, her husband, if she had one, and the community at large through discreet inquiries by her nkotimsefo, [Page 95] household servants, who, like the palace functionaries, were so selected as to represent the various sections of the community. The candidate she turned up was thus more often than not the result of communal consensus. It was easy to arrive at this kind of consensus in the small-scale, face-to-face communities of the period before colonial rule.' [742] However, female heads of household would delegate authority to eldest sons and other male relatives: 'I have mentioned that the eldest member of the family is recognised as the head, but where this member is a woman, and more particularly where the family is connected with a stool, the head delegates her authority to her eldest son, or the eldest male in the family. Women have, however, been [Page 400] known to occupy the stool as reigning chiefs. Adoption proper is unknown, but if a distressed native commends himself to a family, and they approve, he is received by them as a domestic slave, and, as such, becomes absorbed into it. Again, in Fanti Yankumase, for instance, if a member of another tribe settles with them, and his sept, the Kwonna (say) will not help him, he may choose one of the others, who will, and he henceforth is treated as a member of the latter.' [743] According to Rattray, women were not oppressed by husbands and other men due to support from their matrilineage: 'In the chapter on ‘the Ashanti Classificatory System’ it was [Page 79] recorded that wives were inherited in exactly the same way as any other property; even in the case of a chief who is not dead but who has been deposed, or de-stooled as it is called in West Africa, his successor has a perfect right to have his predecessor's wives transferred to him equally with any other stool property. Again, on examination of the marriage laws, it will be found that, under certain circumstances, the native idiom for ‘to marry’ is to 'yere, lit. ‘buy a wife’.' [744] 'These two isolated instances, removed from their proper context, might well lead the casual observer to suppose that an Ashanti wife was little better than a man's chattel and to point to the servile condition of women.' [745] 'But in Ashanti no woman stands alone, for behind the woman stand a united family, bound by the tie of blood, which has here a power and a meaning we can hardly grasp. ‘If you see one parrot do not throw a stone at it, for there are many others,’ runs one of their sayings.' [746] 'The whole conception of ‘mother-right’ affords the woman a protection and a status that is more than an adequate safeguard against the ill-treatment by any male or group of males.' [747] 'Her children belong to her and her clan, not to that of her husband.' [748] 'All her individually acquired and inherited property is hers and her clan's, and her husband cannot touch it. Not only is this so, but when she dies, no male even of her own clan may be her heir until all her female blood (clan) relations are extinct.' [749] 'From these facts it is clear that the position of women in Ashanti is one of great importance.' [750] '‘I am the mother of the man,’ she says, and her meaning we cannot understand until a fuller knowledge of Ashanti social and religious organization shows us what is meant.' [751] '‘I alone can transmit the blood to a king.’' [752] '‘If my sex die in the clan then that very clan becomes extinct, for be there one, or one thousand male members left, not one can transmit the blood, and the life of the clan becomes measured on this earth by the span of a man's life.’' [753] Debrunner claims that the status of senior women declined during the colonial period: In the past, old women beyond child bearing age often had honoured social positions—as senior wives of a compound, female elders, recognized mediums (akomfo), priests, even female chiefs. Nowadays however, this has somewhat changed owing to the unequal spreading of education.' [754] 'The status of women and especially old women has declined. Young school girls are often rated higher than their mothers and grandmothers by society who call them “awuraa”, madam. Secretly the old women resent it and the younger members feel guilty towards them and therefore try to ward off their guilt feeling by accusing the old women of witchery. A student writes: “Because witchery is mostly attributed to old women, any misfortune that occurs in the family of such a woman is accredited to her. If care is not taken, such women will be cast out from family matters entirely”. Administrator Tauxier finds that the old women are accused by society of witchcraft because they have become useless to it—they cannot have children and cannot give pleasure to men.' [755] Farm labour was shared, but participation in crafts was largely restricted to men: 'Men and women share in labor, but both may own farms and houses and both may provide the labor for them. With respect to crafts, only pottery making is a female activity; the others are restricted to male specialists. Even in the case of pottery making, only men are allowed to fashion pots or pipes representing anthropomorphic or zoomorphic figures. [MG]' [756] However, marriage and divorce norms discriminated along gender lines. Husbands could take concubines, but wives could not take (legitimate) lovers (see above). Husbands could divorce their wives: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [757] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [758] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [759] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [760] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [761] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [762] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [763] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [764] We are unsure whether the above comments on divorce also apply to the pre-Ashanti period or whether they only apply to the colonial period. But given how women could not occupy 'male' stools, we have decided to code 'present'. However, it appears that gender complementarity rather than either gender equality or gender stratification was the norm.
♠ Social class ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [765] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [766] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [767] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [768] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [769] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [770] Lineage segments were differentiated along the lines of heritable interest in property: 'Segments: While the lineage as a whole has some corporate concern with sponsoring the funeral of any of its members and with assigning that member's property to an heir, heritable interests in various properties can differentiate lineage members. Subsets of the membership of a lineage — equalling lineage segments — are defined by the existence of any property for which members of the subsets (exclusive of others) are potential heirs. Such sets (subsets of the whole) may range from, at the one extreme, only the actual children of some man's actual sisters (in the case of property that he himself created) to, at the other extreme, all the members of the lineage (in the case of property, in effect, created by the lineage founder). In Egyaa, only chiefly positions fall in the long-lived extreme, while (almost) all other created property (in Egyaa) falls in or near the short-lived extreme. No property in Egyaa falls enough in between the two extremes to matter, but property that survived long enough to be inherited through several generations (but not substantially longer) were such to exist, would create sets of members representing intermediate segments of the lineage's membership.' [771] Slavery was practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [772] Wealthy urban families relied on unfree labour, but wealth stratification had emerged before the colonial and Ashanti periods: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [773] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [774] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [775] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [776] 'ON THE BASIS OF HIS observations of Kumase society in 1817, Bowdich became strongly aware of the degree of social stratification present. Of the many indicators of this—housing, diet, hygiene, toiletry, marriage, and so forth —he commented most fully on matters of the household economy:[Page 140] 'the higher class could not support their numerous followers, or the lower their large families, in the city, and therefore employed them in plantations (in which small crooms [villages] were situated) generally within two or three miles of the capital, where their labours not only feed themselves, but supply the wants of the chief, his family, and more immediate suite. The middling orders station their slaves for the same purpose, and also to collect fruit and vegetables for sale, and when their children become numerous, a part are generally sent to be supported by these slaves in the bush.' [777] 'Bowdich's “higher class” would appear to refer to the wealthy citizens, high officeholders for the most part, whose gyaasefo or “retainers” supported them; his “middling orders” to aspirant citizens in the process of creating, through utilization of slaves, their own gyaasefo; and his “lower class” to those who perforce ensured their survival by the use of family labor. If Bowdich may be understood to be suggesting that the commanding morality of metropolitan society was one of upward mobility based on wealth, then he was undoubtedly correct. Had Bowdich remained in Kumase a few months longer, he would have observed that upward mobility was an institutionalized process.' [778] Accordingly, political influence was tied to wealth. While attributing class structures to non-capitalist economies is difficult, Wilks distinguishes between 'nobles', an emerging urban 'bourgeoisie', free farmers, and unfree servants in the Ashanti period: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class. Unlike both adehyeε and gyaasefo, however, the asomfo class emerged in an urban rather than rural context, and at a much later date: its full development was, therefore, specific to Asante rather than common to Akan society in general.' [779] While this 'bourgeoisie' or group of 'parvenus' may have been absent prior to the Ashanti period, wealth stratification itself was present. Given how leadership titles were tied to matrilineages, we have decided to code 'present'.
♠ Ethnicity or race ♣ present ♥ In Ashanti, the emerging peasant class was largely made up of assimilated non-Asante: 'Arhin's article is a most welcome corrective to ideological arguments which attempt to force complex realities into simple schemes. His argument (re: Fallers) that a culturally distinct peasantry can be identified in precolonial Asante is supported, as he notes, by a large and growing body of historical work. Some of this research amplifies the urban/rural distinction even more than Arhin himself does: e.g., Wilks's (1975) discussion of the importance of the urban mercantile class (the asikafo) and his discussion of the way in which the state, embodied in the city itself, enforced its power. It is impossible to discuss the rise of the Asante state without talking about the rise of Kumasi as an urban center. By definition, the rise of the state therefore presupposes the rise of a hinterland and a peasantry. Unless one were to question whether the state existed at all (which no one is doing), there is not much question about a peasantry's existing, economically, politically, and culturally.' [780] 'There are a few points which could be emphasized: the cultural distinctiveness of the peasantry is due, in part, to the enormous numbers of strangers (particularly northerners) assimilated into Asante. As the slave trade decreased in the early 19th century, after abolition, large numbers of northerners had to be absorbed into the Asante populace. As Wilks describes, the government had very specific policies for carrying out this absorption. Thus, the urban/rural distinction is not simply one of “class” (which Arhin himself says is very unclear), but also, on some level, an ethnic one. In Asante the ethnic lines became more and more blurred, and the assimilationist policy made and continues to make discussion of this issue difficult; but it is clear that in everyone's attempt to be a “Kumasi” person there is also an attempt to certify one's unquestionable (free) Asante origins, which Arhin calls the “distinctively indigenous.”' [781] The same was true of other Akan states: 'Terray has already applied the concept “peasant” to the neighbouring Abron and, comparatively, to Asante (Terray 1974, 1975), but his usage differs from mine, perhaps because the political structures of the Abron and the Asante differ. For Terray the Abron peasant “classes” consist of the subject Kulango people, whom the Akan-Abron conquered before establishing a “conquest state,” a few Abron subjects, and above all slaves acquired through raids and warfare and by purchase. It is from these that the state, dominated by the Abron aristocracy, extracted its surpluses, and it is they that the state exploited. The slaves, in particular, formed the main labour force in the gold mines owned by the aristocrats and provided the main reason for the existence of the state.' [782] 'Strangers' were not part of established kin networks: 'People have travelled from the Northern Territories or the Colony to Ashanti in search of employment. Some of them have settled there more or less permanently. There are many people from these areas who have lived in Ashanti most of their lives, but they are outside the Ashanti political structure. They are ‘strangers’, no matter how long they live there.' [783] 'Even Ashantis are ‘strangers’ outside their own Divisions. There are many Ashantis living in Divisions other than those in which they are subjects by kinship. This is particularly so in Kumasi, where the opportunities of employment have attracted people from all parts of Ashanti. With reference to the kinship political organization, these Ashantis are strangers, just as are the settlers from the Northern Territories and the Colony.' [784] 'These permanent but ‘stranger’ settlers, who have no political status in the traditional organization based on kinship, present the chiefs with a new problem, which has arisen most acutely in connexion with taxation.' [785] The legal rights of 'strangers' were restricted: 'Asante men and women drew power and income from a well-developed internal marketplace system with three distinct types of market, in which chiefly regulations protected their privilege as traders and carriers. Non-Asantes were restricted from trading within Asante during most of the nineteenth century, so goods from outside passed into Asante hands at the officially designated border markets whose location contracted with the limits of effective political control (Wilks 1975). Quantities of imported consumer goods, mainly manufactures and crafts, passed from border markets either to the urban daily markets or directly to the regional periodic markets in leading Asante towns (Akoto 1980). These linked the rural population to the border markets and to other parts of Asante with different food supplies. Urban daily markets in Kumasi and leading provincial capitals served the needs of town dwellers for food and consumption goods of all kinds (Lewin 1974).' [786] Mixed marriages were rare and in-marrying individuals were expected to conform to local norms: 'Mahommedan law has not influenced these marriage or family customs in the slightest degree; on the contrary, if a Hausa marries a Fanti he must conform to Fanti custom, unless the girl first embraces Mahommedanism, which is very rare, and even then her children are still held to belong to the Fanti family. Such mixed marriages are, however, rare, and are altogether unknown to the Omanhin of Denkera.' [787] We have assumed this was also the case in Akan states prior to the Ashanti period.

Discrimination[edit]

Discrimination on the basis of gender (include de facto discrimination even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to both males and females ♣ ♥ The Ashanti period was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [788] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [789] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [790] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [791] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [792] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [793] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [794] However, it appears that this process did not predate the Ashanti period.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to both males and females ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Education is available to both males and females ♣ ♥ There was no public education system (see also education variables below).
♠ Property can be owned by both males and females ♣ present ♥ Property was inherited matrilineally, but fathers could transmit some property to sons as well (see property variables above). Accordingly, both genders could own property.

Discrimination on the basis of social class (include de facto limitations even when there are no explicit legal restrictions)

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all social classes ♣ ♥ The Ashanti period was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [795] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [796] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [797] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [798] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [799] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [800] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [801] However, it appears that this process did not predate the Ashanti period.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all social classes ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Education is available to people from all social classes ♣ ♥ There was no public education system (see also education variables below).
♠ Property can be owned by people from all social classes ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [802] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [803] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [804] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [805] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [806] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [807] But inheritance was divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [808] Households cultivated family farms: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [809] Land became the property of clans through clearing of forests and cultivation. Wilks describes the process of establishing estates: 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [810] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [811] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [812] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [813] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [814] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [815] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [816] While wealth stratification was present, all free individuals could own property in principle. We have assumed this was true of both the Ashanti and pre-Ashanti periods.

Discrimination on the basis of ethnicity/race

♠ Bureaucratic positions are open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ ♥ The Ashanti period was characterized by a trend towards greater bureaucratization and functional specialization: 'State organisation became extremely complex in the Kumasi state because at the close of the 17th century it became the capital of the union of Asante states and, in the course of the following century, the seat of an empire which was roughly coterminous with the boundaries of modern Ghana and southeastern Ivory Coast (Wilks 1975: 374-86). The expansion of the state made necessary administrative reforms within Kumasi itself and for the maintenance of effective relations between the Asantehene, the head of the Asante Union and, by consent, also the head of the Kumasi state, and the heads of the conquered territories. The palace administration ( gyase) was expanded with appointive headships of innumerable functional units or palace associations ( afekuo, sing. fekuo) (Rattray 1929: 81-92; Wilks 1967: 214-28; Hagan 1971). The memberships of the palace associations, each of which had either military or nonmilitary functions, cut across the divisions, so that they formed checks on, and counterpoises to, the traditional power units. The heads of the most important of the palace associations, including the units assigned to the offspring of former and reigning Asantehene (Busia 1951: 95), were included in the state council. Since appointments to the headships of the palace associations were in the gift of the Asantehene, the administrative reform represented an intrusion of patrimonialism (Weber 1947: 347) into the traditional political organisation.' [817] 'The vast area brought under Asante control by force or threat of arms could not be governed unless new methods of controlling it were developed. From the 1760s, beginning under Asantehene Osei Kwadwo, various steps were taken to bring the control of outlying areas directly under Kumase [...] Senior officeholders in Kumase were placed in charge of particular areas of the administration, controlling considerable numbers of lesser officials. Some supervised the trade in ivory and kola, while others oversaw the gold-producing regions which now fell within the borders of Asante. A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [818] 'Significant changes in Asante administrative practice, in the direction of increasing specialization of role, were attributed to Asantehene Osei Kwadwo (1764-1777). The class of administrators was a growing one, but I do not think we should yet speak of an administrative class emerging, one reproducing itself as a class.' [819] The purpose of this new administrative structure was to 'enforce subordination of the conquered rulers to the Asantehene. For this purpose the Asante kings used an administrative staff recruited from their gyase, household organization, consisting of units of functionaries with appointive headships [...] These palace associations, called afekuo (Reondorf, 1895: 119; Rattray, 1929: 91), were recruited from free attendants, warcaptives, purchased slaves (nnonkofo), and other bondsmen; in other words, persons connected by “ties of personal loyalty” (Weber, 1947: 342) to the various Asante Kings.' [820] Appointed officials and other dependents increasingly displaced the hereditary authority of 'traditional' public functionaries: 'From Opoku Ware (1720-50) to Kwaku Duah (1834-67), these personal dependants competed with, and replaced the holders of hereditary authority, occupants of royal stools ( adehye nnwa), in Kumasi and in the component states of the Asante Union in the exercise of authority and the collection of tribute and other payments in the conquered territories. Wilks (1967: 211-214) has called this administrative organization the “Kwadwoan revolution” on the ground that it took firm root in the reign of Osei Kwadwo (1864-77) although it began in that of Opoku Ware, and has identified it as the emergence of Asante “bureaucracy”.' [821] Senior public functionaries had a stool system of their own: 'In Kumasi proper there were seventy-seven stools, representing seventy-seven public functionaries, as, for example, the Bantuma Chief, or the Chief of the Royal Burial Grove, the Ateni Chief, or the Chief of the Lamplighters.' [822] Some foreigners were employed in highly specialized roles: 'A form of treasury partly staffed by literate Muslims was created. Groups within the capital began to build up expertise in particular areas of administration and to concentrate on this as a way to power and wealth. Careers began to open for those with intelligence, negotiating skill and a steady nerve.' [823] However, it appears that this process did not predate the Ashanti period.
♠ Promotion in administrative positions is open to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ ♥ See above.
♠ Education is available to people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ ♥ There was no public education system (see also education variables below).
♠ Property can be owned by people from all ethnic/racial groups ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal clans: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [824] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [825] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [826] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [827] Clans held and transmitted land: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]' [828] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [829] But inheritance was divided between a man's matrilineage and his own offspring: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]' [830] Households cultivated family farms: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [831] Land became the property of clans through clearing of forests and cultivation. Wilks describes the process of establishing estates: 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [832] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [833] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [834] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [835] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [836] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [837] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [838] While wealth stratification was present, all free individuals could own property in principle. We have assumed this was true of both the Ashanti and pre-Ashanti periods.

Social Mobility[edit]

Status[edit]

Elite status

♠ elite status is hereditary ♣ present ♥ Chiefly positions and stools were passed on within matrilineages (see below).
♠ elite status is selected ♣ absent ♥
♠ formal system of hereditary social status ♣ absent ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [839] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [840] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [841] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [842] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and political positions: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]' [843] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior.
