[928] Mixed marriages were rare and in-marrying individuals were expected to conform to local norms: 'Mahommedan law has not influenced these marriage or family customs in the slightest degree; on the contrary, if a Hausa marries a Fanti he must conform to Fanti custom, unless the girl first embraces Mahommedanism, which is very rare, and even then her children are still held to belong to the Fanti family. Such mixed marriages are, however, rare, and are altogether unknown to the Omanhin of Denkera.' [929] We have assumed this to be broadly true of both time periods.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes men and women ♣ present ♥ Descent was matrilineal: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [930] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [931] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [932] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [933] Female stools and councils complemented male power hierarchies: 'Female stools complemented the hierarchy of male stools. In the village the elders, mpanyinfo, heads of the matrilineages, who constituted with the odekro the village council, had their aberewa or obaapanyin, who looked after the women's affairs. The odekro had an obaapanyin who was responsible for the affairs of the women of the village and was a member of the village council; the ohene, head of a division, and the omanhene, head of the autonomous political community, had their female counterparts known as ohemma, female ruler, who sat on their councils. The ohene and the ohemma were all of the same mogya, blood, or clan. The Asantehemma, the occupant of the female stool of the Kumasi state, and therefore of united Asante, since her male counterpart was ex officio the Asantehene, king of Asante, was a member of the Kotoko council, the executive committee or cabinet of the Asanteman Nhyiamu, general assembly of Asante rulers.' [934] 'As members of their respective councils, female stool occupants participated in the legislative and judicial processes, in the making and the unmaking of war, and in the distribution of land, the basic resource of the economy. An ohemma of a state also had her own ntam, oath, a formula for starting the judicial process, and her own court, as well as her own okyeame (spokesman) who in the Akan courts acted as prosecutor and judge.' [935] 'An ohemma was a refuge for a fugitive from the ohene's court who often successfully sought her intervention in cases of the death penalty. Called the ‘mother’ of the ohene, she was the latter's most effective adviser and she had the right to administer to him even a public admonition. The ohemma was the aberewa, wisdom personified: an Akan court panel preceded their retirement to discuss a case before passing judgement by saying that they were going to consult aberewa,the old woman. As the aberewa of the town, the ohemma was the moral guardian of the females of the political community and a kind of moral censor: she examined adolescent girls before the main puberty rites which ushered them into adulthood and licensed their marriage, and was expected to say whether or not pregnancy had occurred before the rites. A girl who was found to have become pregnant before the rites was known as kyiribra, and was punished [Page 94] with ostracism together with her partner. The polity thrived on a sound moral order.' [936] 'As the abrewa, the ohemma was also custodian of ‘custom’. She was officially the foremost authority on the genealogy of the royal matrilineage, and hence the first and final arbiter on who was qualified by blood to be a male ruler; it was said of the ohemma's stool in relation to the male stool that it was the elder stool, akonnua panyin. It was the ohemma who played the leading role in the selection of a successor to a deceased or destooled (removed from office) ohene.' [937] 'The ohemma's role in the succession to a vacant stool can be understood in terms, first, of the composite nature of most of the Akan matrilineages and, secondly, of the Akan rules of succession. The composite nature of the Akan matrilineage lay not in its segmentation over time and space, but in the incorporation into it of ‘stranger’ segments which in time became concealed; even when it was known it was not permitted for outsiders to point it out. ‘Stranger’ segments could be descended from slave women or freeborn women of another clan who, therefore, were not of pure blood and whose descendants were not eligible for the stool. The ohemma was the one who could pronounce on the fitness of potential successors for the stool from the viewpoint of true descent from the founding ancestors/ancestresses.' [938] 'Secondly, while the Akan vested the right of succession in the royal matrilineage, they left open the question of the actual successor among the eligible males, which was resolved by joint consultations between the ohemma, as leader of the royal matrilineage, and the members of the village, divisional, or national council. In the process of consultation the ohemma and the council were governed by the following rules: brothers should succeed each other before sisters' sons in the order of seniority in age; but age could be discounted in favour of superior wisdom and character in a junior person. Seniority in age could also be discounted in favour of a younger successor, if rotational succession among the segments of the royal lineage had been adopted as a ‘convention’ by the lineage and the community as a whole. Where rotation had been adopted as a working rule, both the male and female stools rotated among the segments, so that at any moment the occupants belonged to different competing segments.' [939] 'It was the ohemma who operated these rules and ensured orderly succession to the stool. On the decease or de-stoolment of an ohene, the members of the council formally asked the ohemma to nominate a candidate for their approval, and gave her three succeeding options at the end of which the councillors could in turn present a candidate for her approval. It rarely, if ever, came to this. An ohemma consulted members of her matrilineage, her husband, if she had one, and the community at large through discreet inquiries by her nkotimsefo, [Page 95] household servants, who, like the palace functionaries, were so selected as to represent the various sections of the community. The candidate she turned up was thus more often than not the result of communal consensus. It was easy to arrive at this kind of consensus in the small-scale, face-to-face communities of the period before colonial rule.' [940] However, female heads of household would delegate authority to eldest sons and other male relatives: 'I have mentioned that the eldest member of the family is recognised as the head, but where this member is a woman, and more particularly where the family is connected with a stool, the head delegates her authority to her eldest son, or the eldest male in the family. Women have, however, been [Page 400] known to occupy the stool as reigning chiefs. Adoption proper is unknown, but if a distressed native commends himself to a family, and they approve, he is received by them as a domestic slave, and, as such, becomes absorbed into it. Again, in Fanti Yankumase, for instance, if a member of another tribe settles with them, and his sept, the Kwonna (say) will not help him, he may choose one of the others, who will, and he henceforth is treated as a member of the latter.' [941] According to Rattray, women were not oppressed by husbands and other men due to support from their matrilineage: 'In the chapter on ‘the Ashanti Classificatory System’ it was [Page 79] recorded that wives were inherited in exactly the same way as any other property; even in the case of a chief who is not dead but who has been deposed, or de-stooled as it is called in West Africa, his successor has a perfect right to have his predecessor's wives transferred to him equally with any other stool property. Again, on examination of the marriage laws, it will be found that, under certain circumstances, the native idiom for ‘to marry’ is to 'yere, lit. ‘buy a wife’.' [942] 'These two isolated instances, removed from their proper context, might well lead the casual observer to suppose that an Ashanti wife was little better than a man's chattel and to point to the servile condition of women.' [943] 'But in Ashanti no woman stands alone, for behind the woman stand a united family, bound by the tie of blood, which has here a power and a meaning we can hardly grasp. ‘If you see one parrot do not throw a stone at it, for there are many others,’ runs one of their sayings.' [944] 'The whole conception of ‘mother-right’ affords the woman a protection and a status that is more than an adequate safeguard against the ill-treatment by any male or group of males.' [945] 'Her children belong to her and her clan, not to that of her husband.' [946] 'All her individually acquired and inherited property is hers and her clan's, and her husband cannot touch it. Not only is this so, but when she dies, no male even of her own clan may be her heir until all her female blood (clan) relations are extinct.' [947] 'From these facts it is clear that the position of women in Ashanti is one of great importance.' [948] '‘I am the mother of the man,’ she says, and her meaning we cannot understand until a fuller knowledge of Ashanti social and religious organization shows us what is meant.' [949] '‘I alone can transmit the blood to a king.’' [950] '‘If my sex die in the clan then that very clan becomes extinct, for be there one, or one thousand male members left, not one can transmit the blood, and the life of the clan becomes measured on this earth by the span of a man's life.’' [951] Debrunner claims that the status of senior women declined during the colonial period: In the past, old women beyond child bearing age often had honoured social positions—as senior wives of a compound, female elders, recognized mediums (akomfo), priests, even female chiefs. Nowadays however, this has somewhat changed owing to the unequal spreading of education.' [952] 'The status of women and especially old women has declined. Young school girls are often rated higher than their mothers and grandmothers by society who call them “awuraa”, madam. Secretly the old women resent it and the younger members feel guilty towards them and therefore try to ward off their guilt feeling by accusing the old women of witchery. A student writes: “Because witchery is mostly attributed to old women, any misfortune that occurs in the family of such a woman is accredited to her. If care is not taken, such women will be cast out from family matters entirely”. Administrator Tauxier finds that the old women are accused by society of witchcraft because they have become useless to it—they cannot have children and cannot give pleasure to men.' [953] Farm labour was shared, but participation in crafts was largely restricted to men: 'Men and women share in labor, but both may own farms and houses and both may provide the labor for them. With respect to crafts, only pottery making is a female activity; the others are restricted to male specialists. Even in the case of pottery making, only men are allowed to fashion pots or pipes representing anthropomorphic or zoomorphic figures. [MG]' [954] However, marriage and divorce norms discriminated along gender lines. Husbands could take concubines, but wives could not take (legitimate) lovers (see above). Husbands could divorce their wives: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [955] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [956] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [957] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [958] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [959] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [960] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [961] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [962] We are unsure to which extent these regulations apply to the pre-Ashanti period. Given how women could not occupy 'male' stools, we have decided to code 'present'. However, it appears that gender complementarity rather than either gender equality or gender stratification was the norm.
♠ Ideological thought distinguishes people from different locations ♣ present ♥ See material on ethnicity above.

♠ Ideological reinforcement of inequality ♣ present ♥ See above.

♠ Ideological reinforcement of monogamy ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.' [963] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]' [964] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]' [965] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]' [966] Exogamy was the norm: 'Marriage is expected to be exogamous, and is extremely simple. There is no bride-wealth, the union being effected by the transfer of rum or other drink and some money from the groom to the bride's immediate family. Divorce is extremely easy and may be initiated by either men or women. The most usual causes are adultery and the barrenness of wives.' [967] Society was matrilineal, but legitimacy was still important: 'Legitimacy is important both for inheritance and to define a person as having, or not having, slave ancestry. It demands not only a proper marriage, however short, but also a recognized pater: he gives the child his own spiritual identity and his or her name; he admits his responsibility for the child's education, and he has the expectation that the child will carry out the father's funerary rites. [MG]' [968] Multiple residence patterns were present: 'Domestic organization long remained one of the most ambiguous aspects of Akan social structure. It was Fortes who finally delineated the key structural principles and processes through his research in the 1940s in the communities of Asokore and Agogo. He distinguished three major household types each based on a different residence pattern. First are households grouped around a minimal matrilineage, such as a woman and her sister or daughters, or a man and his sister or sister's son. Such households are based on duolocal residence, with a husband and wife living apart in different domestic units; about 62 percent of the households in Agogo were of this type.' [969] 'Second are households consisting of a man, his wife, and their children, sometimes including other kinsfolk; this type of patrilocal or virilocal unit constituted about 22 percent of the households in Agogo. Finally, there are households made up of combinations of the previous types (e.g. a man, his wife, and children) plus his sister's children. Often these reflect an avunculocal residence pattern. The matrilineal domestic group is usually preponderant in the larger communities, while virilocal or patrilocal households are the most common type in small farming villages or hamlets. But all three "types" should be viewed simply as phases in a domestic cycle. In the early years of marriage, residence is predominantly duolocal, but with the passage of time this could shift to avunculocal or patrilocal/virilocal. Thus the composition of a domestic group would evolve over time. [ROL]' [970] Fathers played a prominent role in the arrangement of marriages: 'THERE are two forms of marriage recognised in the Fanti districts of the Gold Coast Colony, ( a) Marriage by native custom, and ( b) Marriage under Ordinance No. 14 of 1884 of the Colony.' [971] 'I intend to deal only with the native custom, and I may here state that I have always relied rather on illiterate natives and chiefs, for my information, than on educated native men, for the following reasons:—the illiterate native tells one all he knows, or all he dares, and, having no reason to lie when he is not in court, he generally relates facts. A chief is the judge of his people, and, with his councillors, is the repository and exponent of the law, and must necessarily be taken as an expert. The scholar studies anything but his own customs, while an educated native is too inclined to embellish those customs, and present them in a form that would do credit to Justinian.' [972] 'According to the Family System of the Tˇw-speaking races of the Gold Coast, although the children belong to the family of the mother, and not of the father, yet the father seems always to have been the person responsible for the marriage of his children.' [973] 'He was liable for their maintenance and up-bringing, and was responsible for their actions. Thus if any of his sons, living under his roof, seduced any woman, the father had to pay satisfaction. If any of his daughters were seduced, he claimed and obtained compensation. He supplied his children with means to trade, or to make a living, and in return was entitled to all their earnings. The liability for the sons ceased on their marriage, or when they became self-supporting, so that it was to the father's advantage to find them wives as soon as possible after they reached the age of puberty, and this became recognised as a duty.' [974] 'Hence it is clear that primitive negro marriages were interparental contracts, in which the consent of the parties themselves was never considered. The father gave his son a peto and a half of gold dust, and the mother contributed half a peto, to start him in life (a peto being roughly an ounce), and he then worked for himself instead of for his father.' [975] 'As time went on fathers came to look on their daughters as sources of income, and demanded sums of money when approached for their hands; this was only natural, as they had nothing to lose by keeping them unmarried, and lost at least their services when they parted with them; whereas unmarried sons were always a possible source of danger.' [976] 'Thus it came about, within historical times, that when a man had a marriageable son he approached a man with a marriageable daughter, and having made a suitable present, which varied from one ackie (4 s. 6 d.) to four ackies (18 s.), the two were betrothed, and cohabitation completed the marriage. [Some reckon the ackie as worth 5 s.]' [977] 'Sometimes it happened, for personal reasons, that children were betrothed before they were mature; in such cases the boy's parent maintained the girl in her father's house and watched her, and was entitled to satisfaction if she were tampered with. When both had reached puberty the marriage was completed by cohabitation. The betrothal could be broken off meanwhile by the boy's parent, on forfeiting the so-called ‘consawment’ money, or by the girl's parent, by returning the money that had been paid.' [978] According to Ffoukes, marriage negotiations became more extensive in the colonial period. There was a lot of regional variation: 'This state continued so long as children quietly submitted to the dictates of their parents, but during the last five centuries the natives have been brought into touch with various European nations, and the much-despised civilisation [Page 33] has tended to modify all their customs and ideas. Sons gradually came to be consulted, and were later allowed to choose their own wives; while the consent of the women was never considered until very recently, and even now it is not usual, except in Coast towns, where girls are far more independent than in the bush.' [979] 'The marriage custom, instead of being the simple process of parents pairing off their children, now entails considerable expense. For instance, the present procedure in Cape Coast is as follows:—The relatives of the man (or more often the man himself) approach the relatives of the girl with rum, and if they appear willing a further “dash” is taken, which varies from £1 to 30 s., according to the suitor's circumstances; this is called Abombo or the “knocking” fee, as the suitor knocks at the door to ask for the girl; the father fixes the amount. On the acceptance of the abombo the girl becomes the affianced bride of the man, and although this is only a moral obligation, it is very strictly adhered to, and breach of promise is unknown to native custom. Occasional presents may now be exchanged, and shortly afterwards her parents receive the Etsir-Nsã (Fantee, Etsir a head, Nsã rum), which consists of two flasks of gin and a sum varying from five dollars (£1) to half an ounce of gold (£2) which is distributed amongst her relatives.' [980] 'Her parents then may or may not make a further claim for dowry or head money, etsirkyeradzi or etsiradzi (from etsir, “head,” kyere “to show” or “prove,” and adzi, “thing”), of one to two ounces of gold, or £6 to £9; and the man further sends a box to the girl containing cloths, handkerchiefs, a comb, lavender-water and pomade, with perhaps pipes and a supply of tobacco, and a day is fixed to hand the girl over.' [981] 'Some time usually elapses between sending the etsir nsã and contributing the etsiradzi, and this, it is alleged, is to give the man and his parents time to watch the character of the girl, as well as to meet the increasing demands of the avaricious parents who fix the dowry; but there is nothing to prevent sending both at once and completing the nuptial ceremony forthwith. However, the negro never does anything in a hurry! No precautions are now taken with the girl other than to warn her not to visit her intended husband's house before she is handed over, and she is never confined before her marriage, but satisfaction must be paid for cohabitation before she is so handed over.' [982] 'In Fanti Yankumase [Assin] the custom varies appreciably from Cape Coast, for here the suitor sends to ask the girl's family, without rum or abombo, and if they agree, both families meet to drink rum or palm wine; this ceremony, to show the couple is engaged, is called Wakagyir. Then the man seals his bond by sending three small bottles of gin to the girl's family, and this is termed etsir nsã. He also [Page 35] gives the town crier 1 s. 6 d. to publish his betrothal, and 4 s. to witnesses. He further sends 8 s. to the girl's mother to maintain her until marriage; this payment is called Ntamboba (= Tanbiba, see infra), which implies, “as the mother has looked after the child, now somebody takes her.”' [983] 'The matter then waits until the man has sufficient money, and if the girl or her family has a debt he pays it; this they call the etsiradzi. At this stage the Assins make sure that the bride-elect is a virgin, and, if not, lay their claim against the seducer. If there are no debts, the bridegroom merely provides a box, with cloths, handkerchiefs, looking-glass, and perfumes, and takes the bride home.' [984] 'In Denkera the matter is much simpler; the man asks the father for his daughter, and notifies the girl's family, if he gets the father's consent, by sending them rum; he then pays her family the abombo, which they fix, and which may vary from £1 to 30 s., and the man takes the girl home; although he may pay a further dowry of £4 or £5, but this is not essential.' [985] Marriage and divorce became more regulated in the colonial period: 'The passing of the 1884 Marriage Ordinance Act attempted to set a standard for monogamous marriage and spousal inheritance of self-acquired property. Conflict over inheritance often ended up in court where officials tried to determine whether or not a spouse was a true and therefore legal wife. Women began to organize in the 1950's to change the distinction between ‘wife’ and ‘non-wife’ in order to protect the interests of women and children. The results were the passage of the Maintenance of Children Bill in 1965 and a new divorce law in 1971. [IS]' [986] Concubinage was practiced, but the rights of concubines differed from those of wives: 'Concubinage is everywhere practised on the Coast, and is generally respected, although civilisation has made educated natives profess to disparage it; the sole difference amongst the Fantis is, that Mpata or satisfaction can be sued for by a married man if his wife commits adultery, whereas he can obtain no redress in the case of a concubine. Further, a native can hardly be said to buy his wife, as all moneys paid by him are received on trust for the good behaviour of the wife during the marriage, and are returnable to the husband if he divorces his wife for her misconduct, only vesting in her family on her death, or the death of her husband.' [987] 'Concubinage is openly permitted, and although it is not encouraged on the Coast, it is widely practised elsewhere. It is really quite as honourable a connection as the native marriage, as couples frequently live through life with no other bond than mutual affection. The essential difference is that for lack of consideration the man cannot claim damages if the woman misconducts herself; and if the man misbehaves, the woman has only to leave him at will. In fact the difference is all in favour of the woman, as will be seen when dealing with divorce. Even a married man may keep a concubine openly if his wife has no objection, but she cooks only at the wife's request; it is when a man keeps concubines clandestinely or against his wife's will that the custom is deprecated, and he has to “pacify” her whenever she finds him out. Wives do not appear to discourage it so long as they themselves get their fair share of attention. Whatever is given to a concubine is given outright, and cannot be reclaimed if she chooses to leave him for someone else. Her children can hardly be called illegitimate, as they still belong to her family, and as in the case of a chieftainess the children succeed to the stool. If she has children, and then marries another man, the natural father usually takes and brings them up, so that they may bury him; but if he does not, the husband is obliged to look after them.' [988] 'There is this great difference, however, that, whereas the father of legitimate children is bound to support them, and he is responsible for all their acts, the natural father is not so bound, the obligation and liability falling on the woman's family; he only does so to keep up his good name, and the children do not participate equally in the funeral expenses.' [989] Levirate was also practiced: 'There is a peculiar exception to one of these prohibitions, for when a Fanti dies he is succeeded by his eldest surviving brother, and if he has no brothers, by his eldest sister's eldest son. If the brother succeeds, he is said to take his [Page 44] place, and part of his duty is to marry the widow; this is called Okuranba; if the nephew ( Awofasepenyin) inherits he has a wider choice, for if the man leaves a daughter the nephew can take his choice between the widow and her daughter, but he cannot marry both. ' [990] Husbands were obliged to pay compensation to the wife in the case of divorce unless a legitimate reason for the dissolution of the marriage could be provided: 'The Fantis assert that a man may repudiate his wife at will, but, if no substantial reason is given, he forfeits the dowry and all payments made on her behalf, pays all her expenses, and in addition pays her heavy compensation, so that it is never done. Elsewhere repudiation at will is unknown.' [991] 'The following are held to be good grounds on which a husband may divorce his wife:— (1) Adultery. (2) Repeatedly insulting the husband's parents. (3) Refusal on the part of the woman to cohabit, after the man has preferred his claim against an adulterer. (4) If she becomes a notorious thief or criminal. (5) If she persists in not consenting to his taking another wife. (6) If the wife practises witchcraft. (7) Desertion.' [992] 'In all these cases it is usual for both families to meet, and appoint an arbitrator, who may be the chief or any other person to whose decision they agree to submit. The case is gone into in the presence of both families, and if the grounds are held to be sufficient, the man is ordered to “chop” ( i.e., pipe-clay) the neck and breast of the woman, and she has to parade the town to publish the fact, and to show that she is free to marry again. If she was in the wrong, the man could then claim from her family restitution of the dowry, and all the expenses he had incurred throughout the marriage on her behalf, except the actual expense of maintaining her, doctor's bills, and the cloths that she had worn out; all jewels and the cloths that he had given her and which were not worn out are also returned. In Assin she is chalked on the foot. In Denkera she is not chalked at all, and here, although actual current expenses are awarded, they are invariably remitted.' [993] 'In the case of adultery, the husband can turn the woman [Page 47] out on the spot and refuse her all further support. Inquiry might show that she had committeed adultery after gross ill-treatment or desertion; in such cases a divorce would be decreed, but the man would forfeit his expenses. For adultery he also has an alternative, in that he could sue the adulterer for damages (Birebu), which might be more than the expenses that he could claim, and are never less; this depends on his position. In Cape Coast he has to elect, and cannot claim a divorce at the same time; he can only proceed to a divorce if the woman now refuses to pay some small satisfaction, and further refuses to live with him. In Assin he may divorce as well as claim. When a wife repeatedly inveighs against her husband's family, the family take the matter up, and the husband has to get a divorce or break with his family, but all endeavours are first made to persuade the woman to desist.' [994] 'In the case of theft, unless the wife is notorious, she pacifies the husband with a sheep, and the marriage continues. If the husband refuses, he forfeits his moneys; if the woman refuses, he can claim all.' [995] 'Where a woman refuses her consent to a new wife, she is invariably won over by a handsome dash.' [996] Women could not divorce their husbands directly, but courts could order men to divorce their wives on their behalf: 'A wife cannot divorce her husband, and the husband may always claim the Ayifur if she marries any other man without being first chalked. She can, however, take him before a native court on the following grounds:—(1) Continuous illtreatment. (2) His repeated insults to her family. (3) Aggravated assault. (4) If he is a notorious thief. (5) Desertion.' [997] 'If she gets judgment the court orders the husband to “chop” her to show she is free; he further forfeits all his expenses, and has to give up all her property that he has in his possession. Also, if there have been loans or money transactions between them, accounts are rendered and balances struck. In Fanti Yankumase the husband is entitled to recover his expenses in all cases of divorce.' [998] Given how adultery was recognized as constituting legitimate grounds for divorce, we have decided to code 'present'. However, we are unsure to which extent these regulations apply to the pre-Ashanti period. Confirmation is needed.

♠ Ideology reinforces prosociality ♣ present ♥

♠ charity ♣ absent ♥ Cooperation among matrikin was common and expected: 'Two categories of matrikin who have invested in farms must be clearly distinguished: those who from the information might expect a return and those who do not. In addition, when considering rights and obligations of matrikin, we are looking both at individuals and at the matrilineage as a whole. Among the individuals are nephews working for their mothers' brothers while having no independent income of their own. Of the Dominase farmers, several were working with their sisters' sons on a permanent basis. Matrikin were also supervising work on bearing farms elsewhere, but these were more senior kinsmen who themselves had farms, and for them there was no question of expecting a direct return for assistance given. Among this second group of matrikin are mother's brothers and a large number of temporary assistants, who included mothers, sisters, a brother and sisters' sons. Most of the twelve male owners studied at Dominase had received assistance from this category, who were in a position to give rather than to receive. In a number of instances this was in the form of contacts, money, or land to make the venture possible in the first place. In some cases part of their financial backing came from the proceeds of farms which they had inherited and which were therefore lineage property. The position of this group can only be understood if account is taken of the corporate nature of descent groups and the sense of obligation existing between members, doing things for one another because they must, particularly men for their sisters' sons. A good mother's brother is expected to help his sisters' sons, thereby obliging the latter to reciprocate in the next generation either through their own sisters' sons or through other matrilineal dependants (Fortes, 1950). Returns are not always therefore related directly to inputs on farms. Three farmers had each made gifts of farms or land to matrikin which could not be related directly to inputs. One had purchased four pieces of land for the children of four sisters, and one [Page 177] for his oldest sister which was to have been for his own mother, who died before he was able to complete the project. A second had offered land to the adult offspring of his mother's sister. In the first case the only assistance he claimed to have received from matrikin was labour from a grand-nephew when he first arrived at Dominase; whereas the second man did rely financially on matrikin and used the proceeds of a family farm which he had inherited, although he had until then received little help from his grand-nephews. The third farmer said that he had purchased land for a brother who had not worked for him.' [999] However, this does not constitute charity. Families in need had recourse to wealthier relatives, but could not force the latter to support them: 'Mutual assistance within the lineage should be substantial, but it too stops far short of pooling. Even inherited lineage property clearly belongs to one individual heir, who should use it for the benefit of kin but has virtually unchallenged power to decide what uses will serve their long-term benefit. Relatives can ask for help without offense, and pressures from the abusua to agree can be intense, but this help cannot be compelled or assumed. Pleas to wealthier kin are based on needs, not rights, and one certainly cannot use their property as one's own.' [1,000]
♠ production of public goods ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Danquah and Rattray describe 'companies' of young men: 'Asafo. A union or company of men banded together under a leader, chosen from among their number by popular vote, to compel the recognition of a real or imaginary grievance or to further some plan, good or perhaps bad, upon which all are of one mind; or perhaps again, merely for the purpose of joining together to work in turns for each other, say at cultivating or clearing a plantation.' [1,001] 'These companies or confederations adopt a leader, as already [Page 46] stated, and assume an emblem or flag, and the confederation is given a name, generally one explaining the raison d'être for the amalgamation. The following are a few examples of ‘company’ names.' [1,002] 'IF one had to make a choice between a purely social as distinguished from a political institution in the Akan state system it would be difficult to point to a characteristic mark by which to differentiate between the two. “Society” at the stage in which we are studying it among the Akan peoples is not far removed from the idea of association of families, clans, or tribes. Invariably the head of the family is not only the patriarch but also the social leader of that family or clan. Matches between marriageable youths are contracted under his personal advice; free consent of girl or boy to a marriage is only conditional on the sanction of the head of family. Dances are usually held within the family compound and when the youth of two or more families meet for some social purpose they do so under the aegis of the central head of those families. Society is more or less clannish in structure, and in proportion as the family tie is close, the youth of the family or tribe are constrained to model their social intercourse on the structure of the political or tribal units. Thus then starting from the highest structure in the State with the Omanhene as its head, we meet a descending scale of social institutions having some head or other who partakes of the hierarchy inherent in the supreme head. The town with a Chief or Odikro as political head has also a corresponding head for the social activities of the town. This head is directly under the Odikro or Chief, but in so far as members of his association are concerned, he is supreme as supremacy goes in the Akan institutional regime. There are several such institutions in every Akan state, and almost every town in an Akan state has a social association of young men with their own leaders called captains (Asafohene or Asafoatse) and lieutenants (Sripi). These Asafo companies as they are called have very definite functions in the political and social community wherein they are found, and as the host (Asafo) of all the young men in a town or state, they were in historical times the only disciplined association [Page 225] of able-bodied men who fought their country's battles in time of war and did yeoman service in time of peace.' [1,003] 'Thus, then, these Asafo Companies of young men are established with very different and diverse purposes, and their activities in recent years have given cause to much controversy as to whether they should be regarded as indispensable parts of the Akan constitution, or whether they are mere associations of young men working for their own immediate benefit and enjoyment. At one time, the rivalry between the different companies, the so-called “company fights”, became so serious that Government had to institute inquiries into the origin, constitution, and status of the Company System. The result of these inquiries did not make the contemplated abolition of the system necessary or practicable, and, for sociological purposes, the value of such associations admits of no cursory treatment.' [1,004] 'Mr. Casely Hayford deals with the Company System in his Native Institutions, but apparently he has in mind the relation between an Asafo Company and the Chief of a town or division, or between the Government and the Company System. He does not, however, lose sight of the fact that the Asafo Companies are the backbone of the country. Such a company in a town consists really of the whole male inhabitants of a town or village, exclusive only of boys under sixteen or seventeen, and of the Councillors in a Chief's Tribunal. They form a strong body of commons who, besides other duties, have also a distinct voice in the enstoolment or destoolment of local Chiefs. Without them, the governments of the Akan nations would not have that glamour of liberal sanction which makes the government of any free people at once orderly and democratic.' [1,005] 'The Asafo Companies have assumed different forms in successive ages. First there is the company which for services rendered to the town or country in time of war or of peace, has been raised to a status which entitles it to participate in the direct government of the town or country. This is effected by making the Company's captain or leader a Captain-on-Stool ( Okonnuasoni). It should be observed that captains of Asafo companies have, as a fact, no stools, and until a Company captain is created as a stool-holding captain, the succession to the captaincy is always made by vote of the members. In the old days companies were usually formed not by the admixture of different members of various families, as is the case at present, but by a collection of the members of a single family, primarily for [Page 226] defensive and offensive purposes. This class of Asafo Companies is now extinct. They have all of them obtained statutory right to partake in the direct government of the town or country to which they belong.' [1,006] 'The form of the institution now in vogue consists of the young men of a town who have brought themselves together for social intercourse, and for the purpose of devoloping a unified national spirit.' [1,007] We are unsure whether the activities performed by companies count as public goods. We have assumed these organizations were present prior to Ashanti rule.
♠ communal dining ♣ present ♥ Feasting was practiced during festivals. Akan communities celebrated the annual yam harvest with a public festival: 'An annual custom is always held in connection with the first fruits of each staple crop such as yam. The general name for a festival is Afahyε (afa, “festival”; hyε, “fix a day”). The chief's and head priest's house and things are refurbished [Page 35] by singing old women, the blackened stools are taken to the stream and sprinkled with water; pieces of sacrificed and new food crops are put on each stool. The spirits are invoked to start the new year and make it a good one, the new year beginning at different times in different localities.' [1,008]//'The Akan annual yam festival, a purificatory ceremony lasting one-two weeks usually in September or October, is called Odwira, meaning “to purify/cleanse”. (It is sometimes also called apafram). It is similar to the Apo in that all disputes are settled, bringing harmony back to the town. The central part of the festival is the re-purification of the stools and the abosom shrines. It is a festival involving remembrance of the dead, harvest, and thanksgiving.' [1,009]//'The Odwira Festival is the most important yearly celebration among the Ashanti people. It is held in autumn, the time when new yams are ready. They cannot be eaten until the second day of the festival, when they are paraded through the streets. The whole festival lasts for five days is celebrated slightly differently in each community. Throughout the festival, music and drumming abound. On the first day the path leading towards the chief's burial is cleaned. On the second day priests make offerings at the burial chambers and a great yam parade takes place. On the third day people mourn and fast. On the fourth a splendid feast for everyone in the community is held at the local chief's house. That night, everyone stay indoors, to avoid catching sight of the chief's thrones, symbols of the dead men's spirits, which are carried to the river to be ceremonially washed. On the fifth and final day, chiefs and other important clan members dressed in their best, parade through the town in a grand procession to pay homage to the senior local chief. Some are carried shoulder high on litters and shaded with brilliantly coloured umbrellas. Then people play music and dance late into the night.'[1,010]//Warren provides a description of the relevant narratives and proceedings among the Techiman-Bono:'The other major annual Bono Festival is the Yam Festival ( henerεk dibayerefoforo: literally, the chief is going to eat new yams). The myth explaining the origin of the festival states that when the Techiman-Bono people came from the cavern at Amowi, Onyame pointed out forest yams (aha bayere). Seeing that bush pigs and elephants had eaten some of the yams, they cooked a few and saw that the yam was good food. They gave some to their chief, who also enjoyed it. After that, they began to celebrate on an annual basis the day on which they first found yams. After their chief died, they fed his soul (saman) yams on the same day. Later the Bono began to plant yams, and the yam became the most important staple in the Bono diet. Every farmer celebrates the festival to thank Onyame after the harvest. The living and the deceased are all invited to share in the abundance. Every Bono chief and priest celebrates a yam festival, but before the celebrations begin, a man from the village of Kenten whose title is Akokohwedeε (woodhen) first tastes the yam. When he sees that the yam is ripe, early in the morning on the traditional day called Fodwo he informs the god Taa Mεnsah that the yam is ready to be prepared for εto (mashed yams mixed with palmoil).' [1,011]//'The Taa Mεnsah deity celebrates his yam festival on Fodwo, a Monday. The new yam is hung from rafters in the shrine room for some weeks before the Akokohwedeε comes to taste it. After the yam is hung, children may begin to eat new yam and the elders can [Page 57] [Page 58] begin to eat aso bayere (one species of yam). In the evening on Fodwo, the god Taa Mεnsah is prepared to eat yam after being carried on the main street from one end of the town to the other end three times and consulted. After this, the god informs the manhene that he is about to eat yam and the manhene gives the god permission to eat the yam. The manhene sends a yam to the god and it is always this yam which is cooked as εto and placed on the shrine. The next day, Tuesday, the manhene sends a sheep and wine to the god.' [1,012]//'Two weeks after the Taa Mεnsah Yam Festival, the yam festivals for the Queenmother, the Adontenhene, and the Nifahene are celebrated on a Monofie, a Friday. Nwonakusie, a Thursday, is the yam festival day for the Twafohene, the Adaatihene, the Akyeamehene, the Konkontiwahene, and the Krontihene. Fofie, another Friday, is the yam festival day for the manhene, the Gyaasehene, the Ankbeahene, and the Barimhene. The manhene provides about six sheep and a cow for his own yam festival. These are sacrificed, the blood being spilled on the ancestral stools; the meat is cooked and distributed.' [1,013]// The Apo Festival was celebrated annually and included carnivalesque elements: 'Many festivals exist among the Akan; their foundations and functions are found in the traditional religion. The Apo festival is celebrated yearly among the Brong; it is a feast of eight days duration in which complete lampooning liberty (in the form of song) of both superiors and inferiors (without punishment) is given. The people explain that if one's sunsum is hurt, the body becomes ill; often ill health is caused by evil and the hatred another person may have for you. In like manner, if you have a hatred for someone, it affects your own sunsum, so this time is set aside to allow any man to tell any other man what has offended him. This frees the spirit, and both sunsum become relaxed. During this festival there is theoretical sexual license; this isn't really taken [Page 33] [Page 34] advantage of since traditional court action can be initiated after the eight day festival. Punishment is therefore deferred until the rites are over. Should an aggrieved party take action he forfeits the right to investigation, to satisfaction, and he is also heavily fined. During this period all the priests and priestesses of the area are present with their shrines; they touch each shrine with every other one to re-establish communications which might have been lost. The major gods are taken to the river and cleansed of all evil. On the eighth day everyone makes a concerted effort to drive all evil from the area. Around twenty-five distinct Apo songs are sung, and there is a specific Apo dance for the festival.' [1,014]//Purification is a major element in the rituals performed: 'The festival period is, in fact, a period of coming together in which the people from all over the Techiman traditional area, including well-wishers and invitees from other states, meet in the capital to display the traditional Bono culture through singing, dancing, and drumming. The manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene, purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State (man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State. Finally, the Apo is a period during which the shrines of various gods and goddesses are purified. The shrine of the main deity in Techiman Township, Taa Kεse (Taa Mεnsah), is, at this time, purified at the River Agyentoamu during the last hour of the celebration; this serves as a sign of the completion of the Apo Festival.' [1,015]//The festival also served as a check on authority and as a forum for the resolution of mutual resentment: 'The functions of the Apo festival seem to be four: (1) psychological release, (2) a forum for public opinion, (3) a means to periodically check those in authority, (4) a method of enforcing sanctions of behaviour.' [1,016] According to Warren, the restoration of amicable relations is one of the major purposes of the festival: 'This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority-especially the manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [1,017] While the descriptions refer to the Ashanti period, we have assumed that they are broadly applicable to the pre-Ashanti period as well.
♠ morality ♣ suspected unknown ♥

Normative Ideological Aspects of Slavery[edit]

♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-ethnics ♣ absent ♥ Uncles could pawn their nephews and nieces (see below).
♠ Ideology forbids slavery for co-religionists ♣ absent ♥ Uncles could pawn their nephews and nieces (see below).
♠ Ideology forbids slavery universally ♣ absent ♥ Slavery was widely practiced: 'The Akan practiced slavery, obtaining slaves from northern slave dealers, usually Muslims. War captives, criminals, persons who opposed local chiefs, and many local ritual leaders were also enslaved. Slaves were used for domestic and field labor, for sale to traders across the Sahara and Atlantic, and as sacrifices to royal and other ancestors. In the middle of the nineteenth century, slaves amounted to half of the population in many towns. [MG]' [1,018] Uncles could 'pawn' their nephew and nieces: 'An uncle had the power to pawn his nephew or niece. The whole legal position of pawns ( nwowa) will be examined later in detail under that heading. An uncle was expected to give the father of the person he wished to pawn ‘the first refusal’, that is, to ask him if he would not himself like to take his own child as his pawn. In any case, whether the father desired to do so or not, he might not protest or interfere. My Ashanti informants state that the person to be pawned would not wish him to do either, and remarked, Oba ose ose dome abusua (‘A child may resemble his father, but affection (duty) is for the blood relations’); and again, Gyadua si abontene ne hi wo fie (‘The gyadua (tree) may stand in the street, but its roots are in the house). ‘His uncle may not beat or punish your child while he is under your care, but, on the other hand, you may spend much money on your children, consulting the gods, yet when their uncle's house becomes poor he will sell them.’' [1,019] 'An uncle had the power to compel his niece to divorce her husband so that he might pawn her to raise money to ‘buy the head’ of one of his abusua. He would give her husband the option to advance the money, taking his wife as a pawn, but if he could not or would not do so, two courses were open to him: ( a) To put white clay upon his wife's back, i. e. divorce her, to enable her uncle to pawn her elsewhere, or, ( b) Pawn himself or his nephew to pay the debt of his wife's uncle.' [1,020] 'My informant added, ‘If you refused to do either of these things, the uncle would “swear an oath” upon you to buy your wife for some large amount ( tramma), for your wife is the property of her uncle, she is his agyapadie (inherited ancestral property).' [1,021] There were multiple classes of slaves: 'The Akan groups are characterized by matrilineal descent, inheritance, and succession. The Fanti and Ashanti have exogamous patrilineages also, making a double descent system. There is polygamy. In traditional Ghana when custom had determining influence on social life, a preference was given to cross-cousin marriage which among other things ensured that, in spite of matrilineal system of inheritance, the daughters of a man benefited from his property which they and their mother helped him to acquire. Local endogamy and traditional slavery and debt slavery also prevailed. There are no endogamous castes and no initiation schools.' [1,022] 'Slaves were not allowed to mix freely with free-men or allowed to go to the chief's palace; they were required to work harder and to do the dirty work. Moreover they were not accorded a funeral custom. There were four sub-classes of slaves. (1) The akoa (plural nkoa) originally referred only to voluntary servitude of a person to, for example, his MoBr (w[unavailable]fa). The best translation originally would have been “subject”; in reality it came to include persons whom another person had power over, merging with [unavailable]d[unavailable]nk[unavailable], the slave proper. (2) [unavailable]d[unavailable]nk[unavailable] (plural nn[unavailable]nk[unavailable], nn[unavailable]nk[unavailable]fo is a non-Akan purchased expressly as a slave. The second generation would always be termed akoa. They were usually bought at Salaga, a male costing the equivalent in cowries of 9,000 kola nuts, a female costing the equivalent of 14,000 kola nuts. Outside of Ashanti the master had life and death prerogative over his slaves; within Ashanti any execution had to be performed by the Asantehene's executioners. (3) The dommum was a foreign prisoner of war or tribute. All these [Page 40] classes of slaves could marry, own property (including his own slaves), swear an oath, and become heir to his master. A slave could swear an oath to be taken by another master if badly treated. Slaves could be sacrificed, and a reserve of them were kept at a special village (Akyere kurom). (4) An akyere was a slave condemned to death for an offense but saved until a sacrifice was required.' [1,023] Slaves could not hold stools and only inherited their master's wealth if no matrikin were present: 'Inheritance is arranged by the ohurew or executor responsible for all the funeral arrangements. Ideally the ohurew is the deceased's father's younger brother's son, in the same generation but preferably junior to the deceased. For a female deceased the ideal is FaBrDa. A dying declaration (samansew) is binding if there are witnesses. Although the ohurew is required to settle and distribute the estate, there is a constant problem of distinguishing family from self-acquired property. “The uncle seems in theory the heir to the personal property of his nephews, but almost invariably he waives his right in favour of the deceased's next eldest brother” (Rattray 1929:4). Next in line after eldest brother is the next brother in age until all the deceased's brothers are exhausted. Next is SiSo, then MoSiSo, and finally after all the male possibilities are exhausted the females are eligible for male property, beginning with the deceased's eldest sister. If all relatives are dead, the property (but never a stool) is inherited by a slave, even before the man's actual children — who are completely excluded. This same line of inheritance is followed in the succession for a stool, except that the line stops at slaves and women.' [1,024] But slaves could be adopted into matrilineages: 'Douglas has argued that “matrilineal descent groups are organised to recruit members by other means additional to direct lineal descent”; that “matrilineal descent goes with a quality of openness in the texture of effective descent groups”; and that [Page 80] 'because of the open texture of its descent groups and its bias towards a wide-ranging recruitment of manpower, matriliny is well adapted to any situation in which competing demands for men are higher than demands for material resources.' We suggest, then, that this “open texture” may have been at least one of the factors dictating the new form of social organization that appeared [Page 81] at the time of the clearances: the matriclan functioned to facilitate the assimilation of strangers and, to the point, of the unfree labor being drawn into the forest country. From more recent times we know that those of unfree origins were assimilated as rapidly as possible into the class of free Asante commoners and their acquired status afforded full protection of the law. An Ashanti slave,” wrote Rattray, in nine cases out of ten, possibly became an adopted member of the family, and in time his descendants so merged and intermarried with the owner's kinsmen that only a few would know their origin.' But Rattray still failed to allow fully for the “open texture” of the matrilineal group. The view has been expressed to the writer on many occasions that “in the old days” women married at a young age and men at a relatively advanced one; hat a male slave might often become the third, fourth, or even fifth husband of a (by then elderly) free woman, so that any children she bore by him would be free; and that female slaves were often married by free men and their children immediately adopted into the father's lineage.' [1,025] But slaves had no recourse to corporate descent groups of their own and could be ritually sacrificed: 'Such briefly were the rights of an Ashantislave. They seemed in many instances practically the ordinary privileges of any Ashanti free man, with whom, in these respects, his position did not seem to compare so unfavourably. The chief danger in which his peculiar status placed him appears to me to lie in the fact that the slave was generally a solitary creature more or less at the mercy of a single individual. Every one around him was in a sense ‘the slave’ of some one, but such persons had always behind them a whole group of relatives, whose numbers and wealth and power were ever at their disposal. The slave was not ordinarily possessed jointly (a position which would have ensured certain safeguards); at least, not when a member of a family had purchased him with the proceeds of his own individual labour. It seems probable that circumstances generally would have tended towards his kind treatment. An Ashanti slave, in nine cases out of ten, possibly became an adopted member of the family, and in time his descendants so merged and intermarried with the owner's kinsmen that only a few would know their origin. One outstanding fact, however, remained, i.e. that the status of a slave, i.e. an odonko, could never be lost, and, when necessity arose, or the terrible practice of human sacrifice became the vogue, an otherwise kind and considerate master would turn instinctively to the man who had no friend in the world, in order to satisfy the need for money or for a victim. The liability to be sacrificed at funeral customs may have been an ever-present fear in the mind of a West African slave. Many persons indeed were inevitably condemned to such an end. This idea was, as time went on, developed in an extraordinary degree. Whole villages existed where all the inhabitants were looked upon as a human reservoir from which, when occasion arose, sacrificial victims might be drawn. Such villages were called Akyere kurom (village of Akyere). Akyere means a slave who, instead of suffering immediate capital punishment for some offence of which he had been found guilty, was [Page 43] held over till his unhappy services were required. Meanwhile the person thus condemned went about his or her ordinary vocations, possibly was kept waiting for death for many years, married, brought children into the world, who again married and bore grandchildren to the original culprit. All these descendants (through the female line) inherited the liability of their ancestor to suffer capital punishment at any moment, and helped to swell a reserve of potential funeral victims.' [1,026] Slaves featured prominently in the trade with European powers: 'The fact of the matter is, then, that when the Portuguese entered the Akan gold trade in 1471, those they sought to do business with already had strong consumer preferences, formed in the context of their prior involvement with the Wangara. There was, however, one commodity that was not available from the northern traders: firearms. Initially, so it seems, a brisk exchange of guns for gold took place at Elmina, though such transactions were banned by papal decree. Pope Sixtus IV was petitioned to lift the restriction. On 28 January 1481, he forgave those who had transgressed but reaffirmed the ban. The Christian fear that arms sold at Elmina might find their way into Muslim hands was, in the circumstances, not entirely without foundation. The decision to build the fort of São Jorge at Elmina was taken in the belief that other Portuguese-manufactured produce—“silk, woollen and linen cloths, and other domestic goods” —would find a ready market there. Certainly objects of copper and brass did, whether shaving bowls, urinals, chamber pots, water jugs, bells, boxes, or bracelets (manilhas). Portuguese cloth, however, was apparently not so well received, and the Casa de Guiné in Lisbon was obliged to procure North African “lambens,” “aljaravias,” and the like, to service the Elmina trade. Vogt has suggested that in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries cloth accounted for about 40 percent of the business done at São Jorge, and metals for about 37 percent. Next to these was the sale of slaves, accounting for about 10 percent of trade. Duarte Pacheco Pereira's informants on the Gambia spoke, as we have seen, of the merchants of Bitu, “Banbarranaa,” and “Bahaa” going to “Toom,” that is, the Akan country, “to buy gold in exchange for the merchandise and slaves which they take there.” In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries a strong demand for labor arose in forest Akan society as local entrepreneurs, the aberemp[unavailable]n, sought to increase the extent of the cleared land available for tillage (see chapters 2 and 3). Slaves, in other words, could readily be traded against gold. By virtue of their command of the maritime routes, the Portuguese were able to insinuate themselves into this lucrative business. By 1479 Portuguese vessels were already [Page 24] moving slaves to Elmina from as far east as the Benin coast, and after 1515 the islands of São Tomé and Principe were developed as depots for the expanding enterprise. “Both during the life of Don João (1481-95) and of Dom Manuel (1495-1521),” wrote De Barros, 'this sale of slaves continued from Beny [Benin] to Mina, for ordinarily the ships that left this Kingdom went to Beny to buy the slaves, and then carried them to the Mina, until this trade was altered on account of the great inconvenience which arose. A large caravel was wont to sail from the island of S. Thome, where the slaves of the coast of Beny joined those from the kingdom of Congo, because all the vessels that sailed to those parts called there, and this caravel carried them from the island to Mina.' [1,027] 'For the period 1500-35 it has been estimated that the Portuguese imported ten to twelve thousand slaves to Elmina, though the figure takes no account of those landed by smugglers and interlopers. Although their sale accounted for only some 10 percent of the Portuguese trade at Elmina, it was critical in luring the inland merchants to the coast. “An adequate and continuous supply of slaves was indispensable for the success of Portuguese trade at São Jorge da Mina,” Vogt remarks. “Without such slaves, much of the remainder of the trade-goods would not have been sold.” The total cost, including purchase price, transportation, and food, of a slave procured in the Slave Rivers and sold at Elmina was reckoned at about one-third of an ounce of gold. The sale price ranged from about three to six ounces, according to physique.' [1,028] We have assumed the above material is broadly applicable to the pre-Ashanti period as well.

Normative Ideological Aspects of Human Sacrifice[edit]

♠ Human sacrifice ♣ [3-4] ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,029] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,030] Coded as [3-4] because it is not indicated whether the slaves were captured enemies (out-group members) or considered low-status in-group members.

♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ present ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,031] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,032]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ inferred present ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,033] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,034] Uncertain whether slaves were considered in-group members or whether they were all captured out-group members.
♠ human sacrifice of a low-status individual ♣ inferred present ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,035] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,036] Uncertain whether slaves were considered in-group members or whether they were all captured out-group members.
♠ human sacrifice of a criminal ♣ ♥
♠ human sacrifice of a high status individual ♣ inferred absent ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,037] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,038] Uncertain whether slaves were considered in-group members or whether they were all captured out-group members.
