♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ inferred absent ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,039] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,040] Uncertain whether slaves were considered in-group members or whether they were all captured out-group members.
♠ human sacrifice of other ♣ ♥
♠ Maximum known number of victims in a HS event ♣ ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Religious Offenses ♣ ♥
♠ Capital Punishment for Witchcraft ♣ ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ unknown ♥
♠ Influential figure forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ unknown ♥
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice for in-group member ♣ inferred absent ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,041] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,042] Uncertain whether slaves were considered in-group members or whether they were all captured out-group members.
♠ Official cult forbids human sacrifice universally ♣ inferred absent ♥ Rulers and royal lineages were closely connected to the cult: 'The royal ancestors are at the heart of the ritual protection of a kingdom. They are "fed" at shrines in the form of blackened stools of wood and kept in the "stool rooms" in palaces and houses. Traditionally, the stools were anointed with human blood, gunpowder, and spider webs, and given alcoholic drink; human sacrifices are no longer made. Each kingdom and town has, or had in past years, an annual purification ritual, known as ODWIRA, in which the king, the office of kingship, the kingdom, and the town are purified of the pollution of the preceding year; this is often known in the literature as a "yam festival."'[1,043] This summary might be from a much later period. "During the seventeenth century, the Gold Coast and its hinterland had been divided into a large number of small states; Asante emerged as the dominant power in the hinterland at the beginning of the eighteenth century, and eventually overran the coastal area also in the 1800s. Seventeenth century sources refer frequently to the practice of human sacrifice, especially of slaves, at the funerals of chiefs and important men in the coastal kingdoms, and there is one report also of the sacrifice of captives taken in war to a god. Doubtless human sacrifice was practised in the interior at this period also. But nothing suggests that human sacrifice in this area had attained any especially grand scale before the rise of Asante." [1,044]

Moralizing Supernatural Powers[edit]

♠ Moral concern is primary ♣ inferred absent ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is certain ♣ absent ♥
♠ Moralizing norms are broad ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is targeted ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement of rulers ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by elites ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing religion adopted by commoners ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in afterlife ♣ present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement in this life ♣ inferred present ♥
♠ Moralizing enforcement is agentic ♣ present ♥

These data were reviewed by expert advisors and consultants. For a detailed description of these data, refer to the relevant Analytic Narratives, reference tables, and acknowledgements page. [1,045] [1,046] [1,047]

Normative Ideological precepts concerning morality/supernatural beings[edit]

Supernatural beings (e.g., gods, spirits, ancestors)

♠ Number of officially sanctioned supernatural beings ♣ polytheistic ♥ The pantheon was made up of an omnipotent, omnipresent and omniscient high/creator god as well as various other deities, spirits and ancestors. eHRAF provides the following summary: 'Indigenous Akan religion is based upon the worship of a High God, various spirits or deities, and ancestors. The High God-known as Onyame, Onyankopon, and by other names-is the Creator, now otiose; Asase Yaa, the goddess of the earth, accompanies him. The ancestors live in the land of the dead and may demand offerings, in the past including those of slaves.'[1,048] It is unclear how many spirits and gods there were, which is partly due to the fact that different towns and other localities had their own gods. We have focused on the ‘native’ religion, not converts to Christianity.
♠ Omnipresent supernatural beings ♣ present ♥ 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[1,049]
♠ Omniscient supernatural beings ♣ inferred present ♥ The following quote suggests that the creator god had some form of omniscience, but it is not clear that it was the sort of omniscience that allowed him to look into people's thoughts. 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[1,050]
♠ Omnipotent supernatural beings ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[1,051] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.'[1,052]
♠ High Gods (creator gods) ♣ moralizing ♥ Onyankopon created and governs the cosmos: this is clearly expressed in the first two of the following four quotes. The third and fourth clearly show that only those who follow obra (good conduct; e.g. reciprocity, mutual aid) join the Nana (ancestors) in the afterlife, and the third one implies (but, it should be noted, does not state clearly) that Onyankopon decides who has followed obra when it says that the Nana 'show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being.' 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[1,053] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.' [1,054] 'All ancestors are children of Nyame. Ancestors pass on to their children those things required of them by the Supreme Being as his children. They stand (mediate) between their children and the Supreme Being. They show the right way in which mortal man should live so as to come to the Supreme Being. That good or right way is called conduct (obra) or good conduct (obra pa). The Ga people call it dzenba (world-coming) [Page 24] that is, way of being, or living, in this world; the way in which one makes good or behaves himself in the world.'[1,055] 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,056]
♠ Creator Gods ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[1,057]
♠ Supreme Ruler Gods ♣ present ♥ 'In three specific ways Onyankopon is Nana. First, that he is Creator; it was he who made all men, and all men are his children. He made mother and mother gave birth to you, and he is therefore your Nana. In the second place, Onyankopon is Nana because he provides all that man needs for existence; that in the farm and that in the house; that in the field and that in the water; that for conduct and that for life; all are obtained from God, and therefore he is Nana. In the third place: as our drummers know how to indicate, whether we are alive or whether we die, we depend upon Onyankopon. He protects us from all manner of troubles—national troubles, family troubles and troubles of existence, he it is to whom we run for safety, he is the one who saves our lives, he it is who is our supreme commander. He is supremely the Great Being in all these cases, and he is therefore greater even than the Ohene.'[1,058] 'The various strong, or “praise,” names of Onyankopon better indicate his nature or his divine characteristics. He is Totarobonsu, that is to say, “he pours and pours, and the waters are made.” He is never dried up. Another strong name of Onyankopon Kwame is Abommubuwafre, that is to say, “he is the one who when lamentation or weeping comes upon you, you call upon.” When thus called upon, he answers you. Another strong name of Onyankopon is Nya-amane-kose, that is to say, “he is the one to whom if you report (or tell) any need or trouble, he is able to help you.” Onyankopon Kwame's further strong name is Brckyirihuade, that is to say, “he is the one who knows what is happening in his presence as well as behind his back.” He is the knower of the universe of things.' [1,059]

Supernatural Enforcement of Morality

♠ supernatural enforcement against harm ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against murder in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[1,060] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,061]
♠ supernatural enforcement of human reciprocity ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,062] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)"[1,063]
♠ supernatural enforcement of fairness ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity--which may be reasonably argued to include the equitable sharing of resources. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,064] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)"[1,065]
♠ supernatural enforcement of property rights ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against theft in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[1,066] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,067] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of property rights. Ancestral spirits were thought to be the real owners of clan lands: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. … Abandoned land reverted to the stool.’ Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,068] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,069] This suggests some degree of supernatural enforcement.
♠ supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from two things. First, the Akan belief that the gods safeguard morality and the virtuous are rewarded in the afterlife: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,070] Second, the fact that, among the Akan, "lineage identities and kinship groupings are the locis of sets of rights and obligations."[1,071] From these two things, it seems reasonable to infer that one could be rewarded in the afterlife for, among other things, honouring kinship obligations. The following is also relevant, though it does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of kinship obligations. For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups. Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,072] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,073]
♠ supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from belief that the gods safeguarded morality and the virtuous were rewarded in the afterlife, as well as from Akan proverbs emphasising the importance of reciprocity--which may be reasonably argued to include the equitable sharing of resources. 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,074] Proverbs emphasising human reciprocity include: "Man is not a palm-tree that he should be complete (or, self sufficient). (onipa nye abe na ne ho ahyia ne ho)", "The right arm washes the left arm and the left arm washes the right arm. (wo nsa nifa hohorow benkum, na benkum nso hohorow nifa)" and "Life is mutual aid. (Obra ye nnoboa)", where nnoboa specifically means "helping each other work on the farm."[1,075] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of in-group loyalty. For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups. Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,076] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,077]
♠ supernatural enforcement of respect ♣ inferred present ♥ Inferred from two things. First, the Akan belief that the gods safeguard morality and the virtuous are rewarded in the afterlife: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,078] Second, the fact that, among the Akan, respect for elders is an important cultural value, though elders are more likely to be respected if they have had "successful" lives.[1,079] The following is also relevant, though it does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of respect. Seniority was important. It appears that social stratification accelerated during the Ashanti period and largely relied on unfree labour. New formal titles were created, which were subject to wealth payments and ceremonial initiations. According to some sources, obedience to authority was valued. Insulting or attacking the Asantehene or his officials was a capital offence. The stools of ancestral chiefs retained ceremonial importance: 'The [unavailable]manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent [unavailable]manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State ([unavailable]man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State.'[1,080]
♠ supernatural enforcement of bravery ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on supernatural enforcement of bravery specifically. More material is needed. However, it is worth noting that broad supernatural enforcement of morality was present: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,081] The following is also relevant, but does not clearly demonstrate any kind of supernatural enforcement of bravery. 'Bravery, determination, courage and skill in war were emulated by the Akan, and the Ancestor who had these earned a tribute in the dirges of the lineage. Apeanin Kwaforo Amoa's exploits are alluded to: Atakora of Mamp[unavailable]n is represented as a person full of determination; and Hwerebe Akwaa is a notable Ancestress because, although a woman, she took to arms when the occasion demanded it.' [1,082] 'Then comes the special class of chiefs known as the Abirempong. In former times, these were ordinary chiefs but bravery in war led to their being elevated to a new status as warlords. After elevation, an Obirempong had to swear an oath of allegiance to the Asantehene. This time, stressing his willingness to serve during war.' [1,083]
♠ supernatural enforcement of purity ♣ inferred present ♥ Belief that morality flows from the gods in Akan religion, and widespread taboo against sexual transgression in African religions. "According to Opoku (1978), this [Akan] proverb [i.e. "God is against sin or evil"] is a clear indication that morality flows from God, and that the nature of God demands an appropriate response from His creatures. Adding to Opoku (1978), Harris and Sawyerr (1968) also refer to the Mende myth that explains the origin of sacrifice of fowls, performed when someone has offended another to illustrate God’s attitude towards morality. For Mbiti (1969), morality flows from religion. By this assertion, he argues that one should view morality as an authoritative code of conduct directly sanctioned by superhuman being (god, deities and even ancestors). The moral code that Mbiti (1969) refers to is therefore not autonomous, but its autonomy is derived from the creator god. Any breach of the moral code would accordingly be an offence against god and his instruction. Mbiti (1969) points out that there is in existence and operation numerous taboos and prohibitions in African societies which Ghana is of no exemption. These taboos and prohibitions, which have their source from religion according to Mbiti, are instituted to shape the moral lives of the people belonging to that society. Taboos and prohibitions such as, stealing, pre-marital sex, murder, incest, having sexual intercourse in the bush, adultery and suicide were viewed with serious concerns and offenders were seriously punished not by man as such, but predominantly by the gods and the ancestral spirits. By this, the divine (gods and ancestors) inflict drought, infertility and sicknesses on the life of the offender and the entire society."[1,084] The following is also worth noting, especially as it related specifically to this NGA: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,085]
♠ general supernatural enforcement of morality ♣ present ♥ Menstruation was considered unclean, and contact with a menstruating woman made a man vulnerable to "evil powers". 'In the belief system of the Asante, blood (mogya) was the vital force which, transmitted from generation to generation, bound the living and the ancestors together in a web of kinship (abusua). The shedding of blood was therefore seen as fundamentally antithetical to the natural order and was regulated by the Seventy-Seven Laws of Okomfo Anokye. Putting criminals to death and the slaying of persons to accompany the dead in the next world were sanctioned, but had to be carried out by the highly trained and ritually prepared adumfo or public executioners. The same Laws addressed the matter of menstrual blood. Menstruating women were forbidden from entering any regular dwelling house and were provided with special buildings for the duration. They were not allowed to swear an oath, to address any servant of the king (ahenkwaa) or any priest ([unavailable]komfo), or to have sexual intercourse. Pollution was the issue. “Even by indirect contact,” Rattray wrote in 1927, 'an unclean woman is capable of breaking down all barriers which stand between defenceless man and those evil unseen powers which beset him on every side. These protective powers once thus rendered inactive, have to be “recharged”, as it were, by propitiation, extirpation, and augmentation rites, to placate them and build them up anew.' [1,086]
♠ other supernatural enforcement ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on supernatural enforcement of piety specifically. More material is needed. However, it is worth noting that broad supernatural enforcement of morality was present: 'Each man's way of life (abrabo) serves as his conduct before the ancestors. He who lives in the right way is said to have a good soul, and when he dies, he too becomes a Nana (ancestor) and joins the ancestors. He who does not live in the right way is an accursed soul, and when he dies, he is not called Nana; he has not a good soul, and he does not join the Nananom. The sunsum of a wicked or accursed man does not agree with Odomankoma, who is spoken of in succeeding chapters and who created the Thing. He becomes a hovering spirit and is unable to proceed to any desirable habitat.'[1,087]

Human Enforcement of Morality

♠ care/harm ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ fairness/cheating ♣ suspected unknown ♥ We have found no information on care/harm and fairness/cheating norms. More material is needed.
♠ in-group loyalty ♣ present ♥ For most people, the in-group probably coincided with the matriclan. Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage'[1,088] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]'[1,089]. Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,090] Chiefs from related lineages formed close political ties with each other: 'Members of a clan are not a political unit, but are spread over all the Divisions or States of Ashanti in separate lineages, yet the clan has political significance in that chiefs of the same clan treat one another with special cordiality and tend to draw together. There is, for example, a close bond between the chiefs of Kumasi, Juaben, Kokofu, and Bekwai, who are members of the Oyoko clan. They treat one another as brothers, of whom the Asantehene is the senior brother. There is a similar bond between chiefs of the Bretuo clan, of whom the Mamponghene is the senior brother. Every chief belongs to one or other of the seven major clans of Ashanti. The ties of clanship helped to strengthen the Ashanti Union.' [1,091]. (KB: Removed some evidence that seemed to be not necessary; can restore original if this is not ok)
♠ respect for authority ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups rather than castes: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.'[1,092] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]'[1,093] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]'[1,094] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]'[1,095] Seniority was important: 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,096] Wealth stratification was present, although it might have accelerated during the Ashanti period: 'The Portuguese “blueprint” of 1572 associates gold mining, forest clearing, and food production, and implicitly postulates the existence [Page 96] of an appropriating class and a producing class. It is, I suggest, mutatis mutandis, a paradigm of sorts for the early Akan state. Those who controlled the production and sale of gold were those able to procure a supply of unfree labor. Those who procured unfree labor were those able to create arable land within the forest. Those who created the arable were those who founded the numerous early Akan polities. We see, in other words, a class of Akan entrepreneurs emerging: a class of those able to use the strength of the world bullion market, and the availability of labor locally (whether through Wangara or Portuguese suppliers), in such a way as to create the new agrarian system. These entrepreneurs were known as the aberemp[unavailable]n (sing. [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n), literally “big men” but correctly glossed in an early European source as “a superior rich man.” ' [1,097] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [1,098] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [1,099] 'It is virtually impossible to render such terms as adehyeε, [unavailable]manmufo and gyaasefo into English with the appropriate nuances. Adehyeε may preside over the affairs of anything from villages on the one hand to kingdoms on the other. Their power will rest in no small measure upon the sheer numbers of gyaasefo whose services they command; indeed, this is one index of their rank. In 1936 Oheneba Sakyi Djan manfully struggled with the problem, though with reference to the more southerly forest Akan: 'The term “Gyaase”…applies to the most immediate adherents attached to the household of any important personage. In this instance, even an ordinary well-to-do man (rich man) may have his own Gyaase, so much so that the head of a family (Opanyin or Atrankonnua) or a ruler of a town (Odekro), or a head of a division of a state (Ohene) or the supreme head or king of a state (Omanhene) should necessarily have his own Gyaase-men, and the number of the members constituting the Gyaase of each of the above heads depends on the importance of the party concerned. That is to say, the number of the members of the Gyaase attached to the Ohene's household is by far fewer than that attached to the Omanhene household.' It was all to do with achievement. The fortunes of an [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n depended first on his ability to procure the labor that, the estate established, became his gyaasefo, and second on his ability to attract free settlers to the estate. Measured in these terms the relatively unsuccessful [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n emerged as no more than a village head, an [unavailable]dekuro, and was absorbed in time into the aman (qua state) of his more successful peer, the [unavailable]hene of this or that group of towns and villages, and he in turn into the aman (qua kingdom) of those even more successful. We turn to a consideration of the most successful of all.' [1,100] Wilks provides a general description of the class structure as it was present during the Ashanti period: 'It is notoriously difficult to characterize the class structure of precapitalist societies. To this generalization Asante is no exception, though R. A. Kea's studies of a number of seventeenth century Akan polities have provided an invaluable lead. For present purposes the postulate is that a class reproduces itself as a class and that it does so only insofar as it has a determinate and specific, though not necessarily direct, relationship to the means of production. Consider, for example, the Asante class of the adehyeε, a word commonly but inappropriately translated [Page 294] “royalty” in English. “The old adage” (and I quote the collective wisdom of the late Asantehene and his councillors in a judgment passed down in 1964) “is that a royal is one whose ancestor had established or founded a village." This succinct statement of traditional usage defines a class within Asante society by implicit reference to a set of proprietary rights over land exercised by those who were thereby able to appropriate, in the form of tributes, taxes, and services, part of the labor-value of others settled on the land. I have elsewhere suggested that the origins of the adehyeε class are to be sought in the context of the great economic transformations associated with the development of forest agriculture. I have also suggested that the gyaasefo emerged as a servile class in precisely the same context. In this chapter I argue that the asomfo, or those in administrative service, came to constitute a class within Asante society in precisely the same sense of class. Unlike both adehyeε and gyaasefo, however, the asomfo class emerged in an urban rather than rural context, and at a much later date: its full development was, therefore, specific to Asante rather than common to Akan society in general.' [1,101] Obedience to authority was valued: 'It is the duty of the Head of a family to bring up the members thereof in the way they should go; and by “family” you must understand the entire lineal descendants of a head materfamilias, if I may coin a convenient phrase. It is expected of him by the State to bring up his charge in the knowledge of matters political and traditional. It is his work to train up his wards in the ways of loyalty and obedience to the powers that be. He is held responsible for the freaks of recalcitrant members of his family, and he is looked to to keep them within bounds, and to insist upon conformity on their part with the customs, laws, and traditional observances of the community. In early times he could send off to exile by sale a troublesome relative who would not observe the laws of the community.' [1,102] We have assumed this was broadly applicable to the pre-Ashanti period as well, although these attitudes may have been less pronounced then.
♠ purity ♣ present ♥ Menstruation was considered unclean: 'In the belief system of the Asante, blood (mogya) was the vital force which, transmitted from generation to generation, bound the living and the ancestors together in a web of kinship (abusua). The shedding of blood was therefore seen as fundamentally antithetical to the natural order and was regulated by the Seventy-Seven Laws of Okomfo Anokye. Putting criminals to death and the slaying of persons to accompany the dead in the next world were sanctioned, but had to be carried out by the highly trained and ritually prepared adumfo or public executioners. The same Laws addressed the matter of menstrual blood. Menstruating women were forbidden from entering any regular dwelling house and were provided with special buildings for the duration. They were not allowed to swear an oath, to address any servant of the king (ahenkwaa) or any priest ([unavailable]komfo), or to have sexual intercourse. Pollution was the issue. “Even by indirect contact,” Rattray wrote in 1927, 'an unclean woman is capable of breaking down all barriers which stand between defenceless man and those evil unseen powers which beset him on every side. These protective powers once thus rendered inactive, have to be “recharged”, as it were, by propitiation, extirpation, and augmentation rites, to placate them and build them up anew.' [1,103] Women were expected to observe the taboos observed by their husband: 'If a woman marries she must observe both her own and her husband's taboos. The husband need not observe the wife's. Once the wife reaches menopause, she does not recognize her husband's taboos, proof that ntoro has a role in conception.' [1,104] The Odwira festival incorporated elements of ritual purification: 'The annual Odwira festival, during which the whole nation gathers in the capital, is the greatest occasion for up-dating and communicating history. It occurs annually in September and serves the following purposes: to ‘honour’ and ‘propitiate’ deceased kings; to cleanse the whole nation of ritual defilement; to purify the shrines of the ancestral spirits (stools), of the national gods, as well as of the lesser nonhuman spirits. It is also a ‘feast of the dead’ which is associated with new crops and first fruits (Bowdich, 1819: 274-278; Rattray, 1923; 151-171; 1927: 122-143; Busia, 1951; 1954).' [1,105] 'The Akan annual yam festival, a purificatory ceremony lasting one-two weeks usually in September or October, is called Odwira, meaning “to purify/cleanse”. (It is sometimes also called apafram). It is similar to the Apo[unavailable] in that all disputes are settled, bringing harmony back to the town. The central part of the festival is the re-purification of the stools and the abosom shrines. It is a festival involving remembrance of the dead, harvest, and thanksgiving.' [1,106] Warren reports similar rituals for the Apo festival at Techiman: 'The Techiman Apo[unavailable] Festival, an annual eleven-day celebration, originated at Manso, the ancient capital of the Bono Kingdom. This festival allows every person resident in Techiman Traditional State, without regard to class, creed, ethnic group, or race, eleven days of liberty to lampoon, in the form of songs and proverbs, the faults and malpractices of any other person, including those in authority—especially the [unavailable]manhene and his divisional chiefs. In addition, the people may sing the praises of those in authority in appreciation of worthy achievements so as to encourage them to even greater deeds. During this period it is strictly forbidden to fight in any way. The emphasis of the festival is upon the removal of bitterness and misfortune in the State. After all personal grudges, faults, and hatreds are sung and spoken out amicably, the end result is renewed peace and harmony among the Techiman inhabitants; the spirit (sunsum) of the [Page 56] state is cleansed after all the unspoken interpersonal bitternesses are voiced.' [1,107] 'The [unavailable]manhene and his elders, through the Barimhene purify the soul of King Ameyaw (the chief defeated by the Asante in 1723), adorn his grave with the royal regalia of the incumbent [unavailable]manhene, recall the deeds that Ameyaw performed for the State ([unavailable]man), and present drinks, sheep, and food to his soul and those of the other ancestral chiefs of the Techiman-Bono State.' [1,108] 'Finally, the Apo[unavailable] is a period during which the shrines of various gods and goddesses are purified. The shrine of the main deity in Techiman Township, Taa Kεse (Taa Mεnsah), is, at this time, purified at the River Agyentoamu during the last hour of the celebration; this serves as a sign of the completion of the Apo[unavailable] Festival.' [1,109] Purifying sacrifices were also performed during mortuary rituals: 'After the body is prepared, the family, regardless of their religious affiliation, informs the paramount chief of the death and presents him with a bottle of schnapps which is used to pour a libation. At a traditional funeral food called sense is laid in front of the corpse [Page 39] of an elderly person, along with a cup of water; this is an invitation for all the family spirits (nsamanfo[unavailable]) to come to partake. An elderly female has handmade beads placed in a brass pan before her body; these are buried with her. It is said that a spirit-woman called Amokye will not allow women without beads to pass into the ancestral realm. A sheep is slaughtered to purify the town and the lineage stool; this ritual is called the removal of misfortune or evil. Guns, frequently old Danish guns, are fired at intervals; Christians, however, seldom follow this particular custom. The corpse is usually buried the same or the day after death; the actual funeral (ayie) usually takes place a week or so later, after the entire extended family can be informed. The date may be extended further into the future if the family lacks sufficient financial resources. Ideally there are remembrance funeral ceremonies at one week, at two weeks, at 42 days, at 80 days, and at a year (afrenhyia) after a death, although ceremonies subsequent to the first-week funeral may be quite perfunctory. Christians perform only the first ceremony; after that they offer prayers for the dead during the regular church services.' [1,110] 'In the belief system of the Asante, blood (mogya) was the vital force which, transmitted from generation to generation, bound the living and the ancestors together in a web of kinship (abusua). The shedding of blood was therefore seen as fundamentally antithetical to the natural order and was regulated by the Seventy-Seven Laws of Okomfo Anokye. Putting criminals to death and the slaying of persons to accompany the dead in the next world were sanctioned, but had to be carried out by the highly trained and ritually prepared adumfo or public executioners. The same Laws addressed the matter of menstrual blood. Menstruating women were forbidden from entering any regular dwelling house and were provided with special buildings for the duration. They were not allowed to swear an oath, to address any servant of the king (ahenkwaa) or any priest ([unavailable]komfo), or to have sexual intercourse. Pollution was the issue. “Even by indirect contact,” Rattray wrote in 1927, 'an unclean woman is capable of breaking down all barriers which stand between defenceless man and those evil unseen powers which beset him on every side. These protective powers once thus rendered inactive, have to be “recharged”, as it were, by propitiation, extirpation, and augmentation rites, to placate them and build them up anew.' [1,111]
♠ kinship ♣ present ♥ Society was organized in matrilineal kin groups: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.'[1,112] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]'[1,113] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]'[1,114] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]'[1,115] Matrilineages held and transmitted land and also acted as corporate groups in other contexts: 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,116] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,117] Maternal relatives were entitled to heritable lineage property: 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]'[1,118] Individuals were expected to value kin over affines: 'Giving precedence to husbands over kin was actually considered morally wrong and selfish. The ideal model for exchanges between spouses is short-term reciprocity, which is closely monitored by both sets of relatives as well as the spouses themselves (Abu 1983). Marriage serves personal preference, convenience, and pleasure rather than family interest, except in the cases of elite marriages of alliance. For Asantes marriage is structurally optional in a way that motherhood and fatherhood are not, so they talked of it as an individual, idiosyncratic relationship without an absolute moral mandate. Teenagers and young adults under thirty or forty are expected to devote their primary attention to courtship and marriage as part of enjoying a pleasurable stage of life without substantial family responsibility. Mature adults, either men or women, who continue to put a high priority on sexual or marital affairs were described to me by traders as immature, self-indulgent, and frivolous, and they often used sexual insults in such descriptions.' [1,119] Chiefs from related lineages formed close political ties with each other: 'Members of a clan are not a political unit, but are spread over all the Divisions or States of Ashanti in separate lineages, yet the clan has political significance in that chiefs of the same clan treat one another with special cordiality and tend to draw together. There is, for example, a close bond between the chiefs of Kumasi, Juaben, Kokofu, and Bekwai, who are members of the Oyoko clan. They treat one another as brothers, of whom the Asantehene is the senior brother. There is a similar bond between chiefs of the Bretuo clan, of whom the Mamponghene is the senior brother. Every chief belongs to one or other of the seven major clans of Ashanti. The ties of clanship helped to strengthen the Ashanti Union.' [1,120]
♠ bravery ♣ present ♥ Bravery and military skills were valued: 'Bravery, determination, courage and skill in war were emulated by the Akan, and the Ancestor who had these earned a tribute in the dirges of the lineage. Apeanin Kwaforo Amoa's exploits are alluded to: Atakora of Mamp[unavailable]n is represented as a person full of determination; and Hwerebe Akwaa is a notable Ancestress because, although a woman, she took to arms when the occasion demanded it.' [1,121] 'Then comes the special class of chiefs known as the Abirempong. In former times, these were ordinary chiefs but bravery in war led to their being elevated to a new status as warlords. After elevation, an Obirempong had to swear an oath of allegiance to the Asantehene. This time, stressing his willingness to serve during war.' [1,122] 'The Asante see their history very much in terms of wars and victories up to the terrible moment in 1896 when British forces seized the Asantehene, or King, Prempe 1, and many of his most senior chiefs and advisers, took them to the coast and from there into long exile in the Seychelles. Looking back they recall how, until the last quarter of the nineteenth century, they controlled an ever-increasing area which at its peak stretched over 550 km into the interior and encompassed many distinctive groups and regions. Asante armies were powerful and well-organised, equipped with imported firearms scarcely available to poorer and more isolated northern groups. The porcupine (k[unknown]t[unknown]k[unknown]) with its many quills came to stand for these armies and the Asante nation as a whole; a saying emphasises their almost limitless numbers and bravery: ‘ Asante K[unknown]t[unknown]k[unknown] kill thousands and thousands more will come’.' [1,123]
♠ respect for property ♣ present ♥ Land was passed on within matrilineages, although fathers could also transmit some property to sons: 'All Akan groups recognize matrilineal descent. The basic group is the clan, of which there are eight; they are dispersed among the many kingdoms. Members of a subclan tend to occupy a single town or village. The clan is an exogamous group. It is comprised of constituent groups that may be referred to as lineages, but these do not form any kind of segmentary lineage system, lineages being attached to others by propinquity and the power and wealth of the host lineage. Although there has been much confusion in accounts of the Akan peoples between matriliny and matriarchy, authority within clans and lineages is held firmly by men, succession being from a man to his brother or to his closest sister's son.'[1,124] 'A child inherits his or her blood from the mother, and character or temperament from the father. Maternal blood ensures the child's membership in the ABUSUA (clan or lineage); paternity bestows membership in one of nine other groups or categories. Although some accounts claim the Akan descent system is one of double descent, this view appears to be based on a misreading of the actual roles of the two lines of descent. [MG]'[1,125] 'There are groups in which membership is transmitted patrilineally, but these are neither exogamous nor corporate groups; nor are jural or political rights or duties derived from paternal descent. What is involved is the concept of NTORO; the male transmitted NTORO (spirit) which forms a unique spiritual bond between father and son. Following this principle, every person belongs to one of a limited number of named quasi-ritual categories, the ntoro divisions. Members of the same ntoro division are required to observe certain taboos, perform certain rituals, and are believed to have some common personality characteristics. [ROL]'[1,126] 'Consistent with the emphasis on matrilineal descent is the fact that the system of kinship terminology is of the Crow type. [ROL]'[1,127] 'Land was the unalienable possession of the clan--actually the clan's ancestral spirits were considered the true owners of the land and the tribal land's living occupants only trustees or tenants. Security of tenure was based on working the land. Abandoned land reverted to the stool. Rights to land were inherited matrilineally. Today Akan have the right to sell land although leasing seems to be the preferred arrangement. [IS]'[1,128] 'The localized matrilineage tracing descent from a known common female ancestor for a period of 10 to 12 generations is the basic unit for political, legal, and ritual purposes. Succession and inheritance rules stress sex, generation, and age, with men having precedence over women, "brothers" over "sisters' sons," and senior over junior. [ROL]'[1,129] 'Despite being jurally matrilineal, inheritance is to some extent divided between sister's children and a man's own children. The basic principle is that lineage-inherited property goes to sisters' children, and property acquired with the help of a man's wife and children is distributed among the latter at his death. [MG]'[1,130] Wilks describes the formation of farming estates: 'The farm, known in Asante as the afuo, was essentially a smallholding capable of supporting a single family. It consisted of two or sometimes three distinct parts, the afuwa, mfufuwa and mfufuwa-nini. The land currently under cultivation was the afuwa, “the little farm” or field, and the land under fallow was the mfufuwa, literally “the non- afuwa.” A farmer's rights of tenure over his fallow were as secure as those over his land under cultivation. In some cases a farm may have attached to it further land — fallow that has not been brought back into cultivation at the appropriate time because, for example, of unsatisfactory yields or of the inability of the tenants (through illnesses, deaths, or the like) to resume cropping it. Such land is the mfufuwa-nini, literally “barren fallow.” The original tenants and their heirs retain rights to the produce from it — to the fruits of palm and kola trees, for example, and to firewood and poles — but Asante law appears not to have defined with any precision the point in time at which others might acquire rights in it and recommence farming operations. Much litigation results.' [1,131] 'Akan village histories make frequent reference to hunters ranging the forest in search of land suitable for agricultural exploitation—taking account, presumably, of surface relief, water resources, soil, and so forth. The role of the aberemp[unavailable]n in these explorations is often described in considerable detail. By way of illustration I shall cite the cases of two, Tabiri Heman and Akuamoa Panin.' [1,132] 'The aberemp[unavailable]n were essentially developers. They created estates, founding villages and clearing the arable land necessary for subsistence. I refer to such estates as “ beremp[unavailable]n-doms” (by analogy with “kingdoms,” “chiefdoms,” etc.). Of the actual work of felling, clearing, and building, and of how the imported unfree labor was used, we know nothing. Such is not the stuff of tradition. Kea has drawn attention to a possible model, that of Aduafo of Afutu and “other great lords” who had contracted with the Danish African Company to clear a site and construct a trading post for them. They brought 300 of their slaves to the site and divided them [Page 98] into two teams. One carried out the clearing while the other assembled the building materials. This was, however, at a coastal location and is therefore of uncertain relevance.' [1,133] 'If the creation of an estate was predicated on the procurement of unfree labor, its prosperity depended on free settlers being attracted to it. Such was the pressure on land, on arable land, that they came. Sometimes the original estate was subdivided by purchase. For example, Adu Gyamfi, by origin from Adansemanso, founded a settlement named Aboforumu. It lay about 12 miles northwest of what was to become Kumase. He subsequently sold (“as the explorers or the owners of the land”) part of the estate to new settlers, Amma Badu and Antwi, who paid him mperedwan aduosia, 60 peredwans or some 135 oz. of gold. The estate was soon to be divided yet again. We have met Akosua Yitua of Asantemanso and her son Danso Abeam, above. She had five daughters. The third of these settled at Amoaman, but her descendants “became hemmed in at this village.” They moved northward, and their leader, Adu Panin, purchased a block of land from Amma Badu and Antwi. He renamed it Ntonso. The price is not reported. The transaction is said to have occurred at the time of Oti Akenten of Kumase. Other cases did not involve purchase, but contract sometimes sealed by marriage. The case of Kyerewa Akenten and her brother, Kagya, is instructive. They left Asantemanso in search of land and, after rejecting several places as unsuitable, arrived at Oyoko, near Feyiase. They went from there 'to Odum-Anaafuo to ask Berefo Kese, the Chief of the place for some land to settle on. He showed them a site where they built their village which they named “Kagya-kurom” [Kagya's village]. Owing to the large number of the followers of Kagya and his sister, Berefo Kese presented them a large portion of his lands on which they farmed. From Kagya-kurom Berefo Kese married Kyerewa Akenten and after their marriage Berefo Kese added a much larger portion of his lands to that already in their hands and presented it to them.' [1,134] 'Obtaining land involved negotiation with the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n who had developed it, who had (as it were) staked out first claims to it. Matrifiliation as such conferred no rights of settlement. It will follow that the free settlers within a beremp[unavailable]n-dom belonged to different matriclans. In fact these are dispersed almost randomly throughout forest society. As Fortes has remarked, the matriclan “delimits a diffuse field of amity, wide in extent but of minimal structural specificity.” Within the beremp[unavailable]n-dom, of the rule of exogamy, and in that respect was a socially integrative factor. But claims to land were based upon the heritable rights that the [unavailable]beremp[unavailable]n conferred upon the settlers, and the matrilineages that thus arose were tied to specific tracts of land within the estate.' [1,135] 'From the fifteenth century onward numerous estates or beremp[unavailable]n-doms arose as the frontier of farming expanded outward from the Adanse and Amansie regions. Such has been the thrust of the argument. Some were in time to become the capitals of aman, of states; some were to be incorporated into such states; and some were to falter and vanish. The struggles that attended the process are exhaustively chronicled in Akan traditions; the nature of the process itself, whereby a class of entrepreneurs became transformed into a ruling class, is not. The key lies in an understanding of the peculiar features of Akan land proprietorship.' [1,136] 'A cardinal feature of the system is expressed in the maxim, afuo mu yε me deε, asase yε [unavailable]hene deε, “the farm is my property, the land is the king's.” It is necessary to extrapolate from more recent practice, described by Rattray, Busia, and Fortes among others. If the proprietor of the land conferred heritable rights to the arable on those who were permitted to settle, he also reserved or established certain rights to himself and his heirs — to his “stool.” He took an almost token part of the harvest at the time of the annual harvest festival (the odwira), but required a more substantial share of the produce of the land as opposed to the arable: fish, snails, game, kola, minerals, and the like. He could levy a wide range of taxes, such as peato for military expenses, ayieto for funerals, and [unavailable]manto to defray the costs of making regalia and putting up buildings. Most importantly, he could require the provision of labor for military service or, for example, for work on the roads. Such, briefly, were what led Potekhin to refer to “the relatively easy feudal dues of the free members of the community.” Relatively easy” they may or may not have been; there was variation from place to place and time to time. “Feudal” they were not, for the free settlers acquired almost unassailable titles to the land they farmed, while the various taxes and services provided to the landholder were ad hoc and sporadic and did not approximate in character to a rent, whether economic or otherwise.' [1,137] 'The descendants of free settlers became [unavailable]manmufo, citizens. Those of the proprietors became adehyeε, nobility. There remain the unfree laborers. They must surely be those who became the third major element in the composition of an [unavailable]man, namely the gyaasefo. Literally “the people of the hearth,” they were absorbed into Akan society as servants of the adehyeε. They became responsible not only for their own subsistence but for that of the nobles. They farmed for them, assumed responsibility for their debts, and provided them with a wide range of personal services as stool-carriers, drummers, hornblowers, umbrella-carriers, bathroom attendants, messengers, tradesmen, sextons, and so forth. Their masters (or mistresses) were heirs to their property. Their status, unlike that of nobles and citizens, was transmitted through the male line. Rattray commented on the matter: [Page 100] 'There is little doubt that the Gyasefo were in olden times recruited from the slave class. A “Stool” slave became one of the Gyasefo. The descendants of a Gyase woman were of course considered as Gyasefo, down the female line for all time; not only was this so, but the son of a Gyase man would ordinarily also enter the office to which his father belonged, irrespective of the position of his mother.' [1,138] Theft was punished: 'By virtue of his position, all penalties for breach of the [Page 30] tribal or public oath are collected for and paid to the Ohene, in addition to certain court fees, such as Asida, or Atingé. In former times the Ohene of every large town was entitled to fine strangers entering his town bearing arms without his permission so to do. Fines are paid for accidental homicide; such as carelessly wounding a person taking part in the chase. A person found guilty of criminal intercourse with a married woman is liable to pay to the injured husband a fine of two ounces of gold (benda), that is, £7 4 s. In cases of theft the guilty offender is made to restore to the owner the stolen article or its value, and to his ruler he pays a fine. Where a thief is unable to restore a priceless article, he is killed, and his nearest blood relatives are fined, and, if unable to pay, are sold for the amount. The amount of a fine for theft does not depend so much on the value of the article as upon the nature thereof; e.g. it is not considered theft for a starving man to steal any foodstuff to appease his hunger. Among a people who have been accustomed to have all things in common, the sensibility of many persons to the criminality of theft is not so great as in Europe. In the old settlements, however, the standard of morality in this respect is steadily rising.' [1,139] 'The earliest account of these customary dues is that given by Artus, who was trading at Mowre and other Gold [Page 86] Coast ports in the year 1600.
